lines.text: She was the kindest, sweetest girl you'd ever want to meet.  Oh, I adored her.  I supposed I always hoped she'd be back.  After a time, all I could do was pray she had moved on to better things.  Can you get this suitcase to her parents, if you think it's appropriate?

lines.text: As ready as we <u>can</u> be!  I'll report to the Skipper.

lines.text: To navigate, won't you have to... see your way?

lines.speaker: u136
lines.text: Obviously.

lines.speaker: u135
lines.text: <u>That</u> might be a <u>little</u> <u>rough</u>!

lines.speaker: u137
lines.text: Cyclops will have to linger at the Pole to recharge his power banks.

lines.speaker: u138
lines.text: All right - go to it.

lines.speaker: u139
lines.text: This is from three years ago. Some difference, huh?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: What is the Northcountry Development Association?

lines.speaker: u139
lines.text: I went down to Concord to check it out. The president is Mel Gordon. The vice-president and treasurer is Gordon LaRiviere. Those boys are buying up the mountain, Wade. $364,000 this year. I believe that's out of LaRiviere's league.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Twombley involved?

lines.speaker: u139
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: He musta found out. They had to get rid of him. And Jack'll get blamed.

lines.speaker: u139
lines.text: All the figures show is that Gordon LaRiviere is going to be a very rich man using his position as Selectman. In a year or two, you won't recognize this town.

lines.speaker: u140
lines.text: The good news is we haven't got to your car yet. The bad news --

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Just tell me when you'll have it fixed.

lines.speaker: u140
lines.text: -- the bad news is there's a problem with Gordon's truck what somebody drove through the ice last night. Figured you'd know something about that, Wade.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Yeah. I know about that.

lines.speaker: u140
lines.text: LaRiviere says he ain't gonna pay for the fixin' of your car. A couple hundred for the clutch. I got some more bad news. Wanna hear it?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Tell me.

lines.speaker: u140
lines.text: Chub says you're fired.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: He can't fire me. LaRiviere already did that this morning.

lines.speaker: u140
lines.text: He's a Selectman. The town. He said to tell you to turn your badge in and clean out your office. I'm supposed to pull the CB and police light out of your car. They're town property.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I screwed up the divorce. I agreed with everything she said. I wanted her to like me. I just want to be a good father.

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: It would help if you were married, if there was someone at home while you work.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I plan to. Soon.

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: How soon?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: This spring.

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: Good. It would help if there were some drug or alcohol abuse on the part of your ex-wife. Sexual problems upsetting to the child.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: It looks pretty hopeless, don't it?

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: No, not exactly. I'll look at the divorce decree, see if we can get it redrawn. Interview your daughter. Jill, right?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: Fine. I'll need a $500 retainer. You can mail it.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Jesus. How much... how much will the whole thing cost?

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: Hard to say. If we go for custody, depositions, psychiatric evaluations, it could drag on. Ten or twelve thousand dollars. She could win on appeal. If we just want to get the visitation rights redrawn, assuming they're unduly restrictive, it wouldn't be more than twenty-five hundred.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Oh.

lines.speaker: u141
lines.text: You might be better off legally as well as financially to just go for the --

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Yeah. I know. The custody suit thing was just my getting back at her. I'm not as dumb as I look. Whatever you say. I love my daughter.  I'll send you the five hundred.

lines.speaker: u142
lines.text: Open the door, will ya?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Why don't you quit now, you want out so bad?

lines.speaker: u142
lines.text: Open the door. We're late.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I mean it -- you got enough money now. Head out for California. Surf's up, Jack, and you're digging wells in the snow.

lines.speaker: u142
lines.text: What do you mean I got money? I'm as broke as you.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Jill, please, it's alright. Nothing happened.

lines.speaker: u143
lines.text: I want to go home.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Okay, let's go home, then.

lines.speaker: u144
lines.text: Wade, you're done.  Let me have the shop keys.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: You two, don't you get it? He's using you. You're his slaves.  Jesus Christ, Jack, don't you see that?

lines.speaker: u144
lines.text: The key, Wade.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Yeah, you can have the key. It's the key that's kept me locked to you all these years. I give it to you with pleasure.  Now I'm free. See how easy it is, Jack? All you got to do is give back what the man gave you, and you're free of him.  I've got to call my brother.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: No problem. Look, I...

lines.speaker: u145
lines.text: You make me sick. I can't believe you've sunk so low.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Low as what? What have I done? It's bad to want to see your own daughter?

lines.speaker: u145
lines.text: You know what I'm talking about. For what you're doing to me and to the child you say you love so much. Love. You won't get away with it.

lines.speaker: u146
lines.text: Are you okay, Wade? What was wrong? Why were you holding everyone up?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Did you see that sonofabitch in the BMW? He could've killed somebody.

lines.speaker: u146
lines.text: Did you get his number?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I know who it is.

lines.speaker: u146
lines.text: Good. Who?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Mel Gordon.

lines.speaker: u146
lines.text: I still don't understand --

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: From Boston. Evan Twombley's son-in- law -- he was driving. I know where they're headed. Up the lake, Agaway. The old man's out deer hunting with Jack Hewitt, so they probably got some big weekend party planned.

lines.speaker: u151
lines.text: It makes me sad.

lines.speaker: u147
lines.text: Can --?

lines.speaker: u151
lines.text: Makes me sad it was her. Instead of me. I shoulda froze.

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: I said, 'Next time, phone ahead.'

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Jesus Christ. Mr. Gordon, when I come all the way to serve somebody a summons, I don't call ahead for an appointment.

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: What the hell are you talking about?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I'm issuing you a ticket. Moving violation.

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: Moving violation! I just got out of bed and you're telling me you're giving me a goddamn speeding ticket? Now? Are you nuts? Is that it, Whitehouse? You're nuts?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Yesterday morning, you passed a stopped school bus, which was flashing its lights, then you--

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: Hold on!

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Don't ever put your hands on me, Mr. Gordon.

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: You're talking about a goddamned ticket, from when I passed you at the school where you were deciding to hold up traffic while dreaming of becoming a traffic cop or something?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Don't give me a hard time, Mr. Gordon. I'm just --

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: Doing your fucking job. I know. I watch television too.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Yes. Here's your ticket.

lines.speaker: u148
lines.text: You get the hell out of my house now, asshole. And know this -- you are going to be a lucky asshole if I haven't got you fired before the day is out. I can do it with one phone call, and I'm pissed enough to do it now!

lines.speaker: u149
lines.text: Who are you?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I was... I'm Wade Whitehouse. I was wondering, is your husband here?

lines.speaker: u149
lines.text: He's asleep. We were up very late.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Well, yes, I'm... I want to say that I'm real sorry about your father, Mrs. Twombley.

lines.speaker: u149
lines.text: Mrs. Gordon. Thank you.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Well, yeah, I suppose. Sure. I just had a little business to settle with Mr. Gordon. I'm the local police officer.

lines.speaker: u149
lines.text: Something about my father?

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Oh, no. No, it's a... it's a traffic thing. No big deal.

lines.speaker: u149
lines.text: Can't it wait, then?

lines.speaker: u150
lines.text: Wade, I got a message for you.  Jack Hewitt, he's looking for you. Wants you to clear your stuff out of his office in Town Hall.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: His office. You mean my old office.

lines.speaker: u150
lines.text: Well, I guess -- that's what he said.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: He got his deer yet?

lines.speaker: u150
lines.text: No, he's out now. Somewhere on the mountain. I'd stay away from him if I were you. He's real pissed.

lines.speaker: u151
lines.text: Where the Christ you going? You sonofabitch, you leave my fucking truck where it is! I need... Give me the Goddamn keys! I need to get me to town!

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: Crawl!

lines.speaker: u151
lines.text: Nothing in the fucking house to drink. Not a fucking thing. My house, my money, my truck -- stolen!

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: I don't know you. My goddamn father and I don't know you.

lines.speaker: u154
lines.text: To help, Jack, of course -- and to nail those sonsofbitches, the Two Gordons. That's what Alma calls them. Jesus, Rolfe, whose side are you on?

lines.speaker: u152
lines.text: Take care of the little things first, the things that are distracting you from taking care of the big things. Call Chub Merritt, get your car back, call a dentist, for God's sake, and get your tooth pulled, don't trust the locals, get your facts straight and go straight to the state police. Let them work on this.

lines.speaker: u155
lines.text: There they are!

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: Okay, I'm slowing us down.

lines.speaker: u163
lines.text: The pilot says it is does not have the markings of a commercial jet.

lines.speaker: u156
lines.text: Warn then again. If they don't respond... shoot them down. We will not be intimidated.

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: It's cut.

lines.speaker: u157
lines.text: cross it...  The static overwhelms the voice, then cuts out.

lines.speaker: u158
lines.text: Aw, man. You're torn up pretty bad out here, sir. Do you have any elevater control.

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: Sluggish... I think it's jammed too.

lines.speaker: u158
lines.text: Uh, Tower, we got a problem up here.

lines.speaker: u161
lines.text: They've got no chutes. They can't control the plane, their engines are failing and they're losing fuel.

lines.speaker: u159
lines.text: I prefered the terrorists.

lines.speaker: u161
lines.text: That's game, set, and match. There's nothing to do, except call the Chief Justice.

lines.speaker: u160
lines.text: The Iraqi ambassador is claiming it's just an exercise.

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: An exercise in futility. Send the Nimitz back in.

lines.speaker: u177
lines.text: The Chief Justice? What on earth for?

lines.speaker: u161
lines.text: To swear you in as President.

lines.speaker: u162
lines.text: We've stopped dumping... but we've only got about twenty minutes of fuel left.

lines.speaker: u166
lines.text: We're not going to make it.

lines.speaker: u162
lines.text: Not even close. Hell, we can't even make Syria or Iraq.

lines.speaker: u166
lines.text: Where are we now?

lines.speaker: u162
lines.text: Over the Black Sea. I can probably get us to Turkey or Georgia.

lines.speaker: u166
lines.text: No! If we land this plane anywhere else, we will end up another Entebe.  The Americans built a super plane that flies through mushroom cloud, evades missiles and...  refuels in mid-air. Call the White House.

lines.speaker: u165
lines.text: We copy. Stand by...  Tower?

lines.speaker: u176
lines.text: Tower, here.

lines.speaker: u165
lines.text: This is Romeo Tango Zulu changing call signs.  Tower, alert air traffic, Romeo Tango Zulu is now Air Force One.  This is Air Force One... The President is safe onboard.

lines.speaker: u176
lines.text: Copy, Air Force One.

lines.speaker: u166
lines.text: No you won't. You'll compromise... like always.

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: Hold on, Alice.

lines.speaker: u167
lines.text: Finally, we can bargain.

lines.speaker: u177
lines.text: I'm sure we can strike some sort of arrangement. Land the plane and we'll trade you hostages for fuel.

lines.speaker: u168
lines.text: Sir, we stay with the President.

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: That isn't necessary.

lines.speaker: u174
lines.text: WE'RE HOOKED!

lines.speaker: u169
lines.text: We're hooked. Hove into position.

lines.speaker: u184
lines.text: Kruger, Sagittarius.

lines.speaker: u178
lines.text: Commissioner, Aquarius.

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: Dunn.

lines.speaker: u179
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: You better take this.

lines.speaker: u180
lines.text: Request; comprehensive electrical systems check.

lines.speaker: u189
lines.text: Systems check positive.  Look, Elaine, I...

lines.speaker: u180
lines.text: Request; life support systems check.

lines.speaker: u189
lines.text: Life support check.  Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me.  You're a woman. I can relate to that.

lines.speaker: u180
lines.text: Request; self-analysis of ROK hardware and software systems regarding behavioral changes.

lines.speaker: u189
lines.text: There's nothing wrong with me, Elaine. What about tonight -- just you and me.  We can be alone.  I can get rid of everyone else on the ship -- I've already proven <u>that</u>.

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: Come on up, Jimmy.  Say, that's some puppy.  What's his name?

lines.speaker: u181
lines.text: Scraps.

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: Can I hold him?

lines.speaker: u181
lines.text: Sure.

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: He's a boy dog.

lines.speaker: u181
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: Do you like it when Scraps sleeps on his back, Jimmy?

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Joe, you don't want to blow that thing and kill all these innocent people.

lines.speaker: u182
lines.text: I don't want to live anymore.

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Joe, the insurance policy won't help your wife and kids.  You bought auto insurance, not life insurance.

lines.speaker: u182
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: That's right, Joe.  Now, no one's going to hurt you and no one has to know what's wrong with you.

lines.speaker: u182
lines.text: You're sure?

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: I'm sure.

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: No, a bomb.  Now, as discreetly as possible, I want you to move the passengers into the lounge.

lines.speaker: u185
lines.text: What should I say?

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Anything.  Just don't let Salucci think we're onto him.

lines.speaker: u191
lines.text: Whenever your're ready, Captain.

lines.speaker: u186
lines.text: Yes, sir, commander.  This is Mercury One.  Everything seems A- okay up here and ready for count-down.

lines.speaker: u187
lines.text: You folks need any help?

lines.speaker: u192
lines.text: Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.

lines.speaker: u187
lines.text: Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?

lines.speaker: u192
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u187
lines.text: It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.

lines.speaker: u192
lines.text: Let's go, Daddy.  We have to check in.  He was never appreciated at the Institute.

lines.speaker: u187
lines.text: Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.

lines.speaker: u192
lines.text: Now he's D-Y-I-N-Ging and wants to be buried on Mercury.

lines.speaker: u188
lines.text: You can't go in there!

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Don't try to stop me!

lines.speaker: u188
lines.text: But that's not a door.  The door's over there.

lines.speaker: u191
lines.text: Striker.

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Kurtz, you're drunk.  Who's in command of this ship?

lines.speaker: u191
lines.text: That damn computer has taken over.  I'm getting out.

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Then Elaine was right.

lines.speaker: u191
lines.text: Don't talk to me about Elaine.  Outta my way!

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Pull yourself together!  We've got to...

lines.speaker: u192
lines.text: No.  It's hard to L-A-U-G-H when your father's dying.

lines.speaker: u193
lines.text: Well, we laughed.  We laughed all the time.

lines.speaker: u205
lines.text: I'm sure we'll both make it...but just in case one of us...well, is there a message you'd like me to give someone?

lines.speaker: u195
lines.text: No. I'm all alone.

lines.speaker: u205
lines.text: Just in case I don't have a chance to say goodbye, I want you to know that I haven't spent so many pleasant hours for many years.

lines.speaker: u195
lines.text: That's a very nice compliment, and I'd like to say that...you've done the same for me.

lines.speaker: u196
lines.text: ...but after...awhile...you begin to...  ...get used to it.

lines.speaker: u207
lines.text: Shep, no! He gets so excited when new people are here.

lines.speaker: u198
lines.text: No. No one that I know of.

lines.speaker: u197
lines.text: I think you ought to know what our chances are. The life of everyone on board depends on just one thing: finding someone back there who not only can fly this plane, but who didn't have fish for dinner.

lines.speaker: u209
lines.text: Airsick?

lines.speaker: u198
lines.text: I think so, but I've never seen it so acute.

lines.speaker: u209
lines.text: Find out if there's a doctor on board, as quietly as you can.

lines.speaker: u213
lines.text: Good-bye, darling.

lines.speaker: u199
lines.text: Oh, Bill, I'll keep it. I'll keep it with me all the time.

lines.speaker: u213
lines.text: So long, darling. Good-bye. Take care of yourself.

lines.speaker: u199
lines.text: Bill! Bill! Good-bye, Bill.

lines.speaker: u213
lines.text: Good-bye, darling.

lines.speaker: u199
lines.text: Good-bye, darling. I love you. I love you, darling.

lines.speaker: u213
lines.text: Good-bye, darling.

lines.text: He's right on the heading.

lines.speaker: u201
lines.text: How ya doing, honey?

lines.speaker: u211
lines.text: Oh Jack, I'm so warm. I'm burning up.

lines.speaker: u201
lines.text: Here.

lines.speaker: u208
lines.text: I'm an airline pilot.  Ah, Clarence, according to my calculations, with this tailwind we ought to be able to make up an additional fifteen minutes over the Rockies.

lines.speaker: u202
lines.text: I think you're the greatest. But my Dad says you don't work hard enough on defense.

lines.speaker: u208
lines.text: Denver Control, this is Flight two-zero- niner intersecting Victor Airway seven- niner-niner.

lines.speaker: u202
lines.text: ...and that lots of times you don't even run down court.

lines.speaker: u208
lines.text: We are turning left to a heading of zero- niner-niner.

lines.speaker: u202
lines.text: ...and that you don't really try, except during the playoffs.

lines.speaker: u208
lines.text: The hell I don't! I'm out there busting my buns every night.

lines.speaker: u204
lines.text: Hi!

lines.speaker: u210
lines.text: I'm Randy.

lines.speaker: u204
lines.text: I'm Lisa. Oh, you have a guitar!

lines.speaker: u210
lines.text: I thought maybe you'd like to hear a song.

lines.speaker: u204
lines.text: Oh, I'd love to.

lines.speaker: u210
lines.text: Okay, this is one of my favorites.

lines.speaker: u210
lines.text: Yes?

lines.speaker: u206
lines.text: Oh, Stewardess. My husband is very sick. Can you do something, please?

lines.speaker: u210
lines.text: Well, the doctor will be with you in just a moment. One thing: do you know what he had for dinner?

lines.speaker: u206
lines.text: Yes, of course. We both had fish. Why?

lines.speaker: u210
lines.text: Oh, it's nothing to be alarmed about. We'll get back to you very quickly.

lines.speaker: u209
lines.text: No, he's not bothering anyone. Let him stay up here.

lines.speaker: u208
lines.text: All right. But just remember, my name is Roger Murdock.

lines.text: Mr. Striker, the passengers are ready.

lines.speaker: u214
lines.text: Thank you, Randy. You better leave sweetheart. You might get hurt in here.

lines.speaker: u215
lines.text: In there.

lines.speaker: u218
lines.text: Show me.

lines.speaker: u216
lines.text: Well, if it isn't Detective Jetson. Forget you hip waders, big guy?

lines.speaker: u224
lines.text: Lay off, asshole.

lines.speaker: u216
lines.text: I may be an asshole, but at least I'm a real detective, not some outer shit space thing.

lines.speaker: u217
lines.text: Kill them both.

lines.speaker: u219
lines.text: Here?

lines.text: Do it!

lines.speaker: u218
lines.text: You look very good.

lines.text: You said you wanted the biggest thing I could find... Well, this is it.

lines.text: What is it?

lines.speaker: u220
lines.text: Casull .454 Magnum.  You're talking twice the impact energy of .44 Magnum hot loads.

lines.speaker: u224

lines.speaker: u224
lines.text: Don't piss him off, O'Neal.  When he gets like this, I can't control him. I've seen this before.  He got like this once -- I saw him jerk a guy's spine out and show it to him. Nothing I could do.  I hadda go throw up.

lines.speaker: u221

lines.speaker: u224
lines.text: Yeah, I heard of it.

lines.speaker: u223
lines.text: That's all I know.  You want anything more, you ask somebody else.

lines.speaker: u224
lines.text: Get outta there!

lines.speaker: u225
lines.text: I can't!  Do you mind!

lines.speaker: u224
lines.text: I'll cover you!  Get outta there!!

lines.text: Uh,...Apone, I want you to lay down a suppressing fire with the incinerators and fall back by squads to the APC, over.

lines.text: Say again?  All after incinerators?

lines.text: You did okay, Bishop.

lines.speaker: u229
lines.text: Well, thanks, I --

lines.text: We're talking thermonuclear explosion.

lines.speaker: u231
lines.text: Shit.  Apone, collect magazines from everybody.  We can't have any firing in there.

lines.text: We're not making that out too well.  What is it?

lines.speaker: u233
lines.text: You tell me.  I only work here.

lines.speaker: u232
lines.text: Don't be long, Ellen.

lines.speaker: u233

lines.speaker: u237
lines.text: Can't be.  That's inside the room!

lines.speaker: u233
lines.text: It's readin' right.  Look!

lines.speaker: u234
lines.text: You remember you sent some wildcatters out to that plateau, out past the Ilium range, a couple days ago?

lines.speaker: u238
lines.text: Yeah.  What?

lines.speaker: u234
lines.text: There's a guy on the horn, mom-and-pop survey team.  Says he's homing on something and wants to know if his claim will be honored.

lines.text: Christ.  Some honch in a cushy office on Earth says go look at a grid reference in the middle of nowhere, we look.  They don't say why, and I don't ask.  I don't ask because it takes two weeks to get an answer out here and the answer's always 'don't ask.'

lines.text: Sire, only opera can do this. In a play, if more than one person speaks at the same time, it's just noise. No one can understand a word. But with music, with music you can have twenty individuals all talking at once, and it's not noise - it's a perfect harmony. Isn't that marvelous?

lines.speaker: u268
lines.text: Mozart, music is not the issue here. No one doubts your talent. It is your judgment of literature that's in question. Even with the politics taken out, this thing would still remain a vulgar farce. Why waste your spirit on such rubbish?  Surely you can choose more elevated themes?

lines.speaker: u255
lines.text: Elevated? What does that mean? Elevated! The only thing a man should elevate is - oh, excuse me. I'm sorry. I'm stupid. But I am fed up to the teeth with elevated things! Old dead legends! How can we go on forever writing about gods and legends?

lines.speaker: u268
lines.text: Because they do. They go on forever - at least what they represent. The eternal in us, not the ephemeral. Opera is here to ennoble us. You and me, just as much as His Majesty.

And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!

God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.

lines.text: Not at all, sir.  I have a pair of good pistols that have already done execution, and are ready to do it again.

lines.speaker: u466
lines.text: Hoity-toity!  John Best, what's the matter here?

lines.text: I'll tell you what it is, Mr. Dugan. I have had enough of Miss Dugan here and your Irish ways.  I ain't used to 'em, sir.

lines.speaker: u466
lines.text: Well, well!  What is it?  We'll make you used to our ways, or adopt English ones.

lines.speaker: u455
lines.text: It's not the English way, for ladies to have two lovers, and, so, Mr. Dugan, I'll thank you to pay me the sum you owe me, and I resign all claims to this young lady.  If she has a fancy for school-boys, let her take 'em, sir.

lines.speaker: u466
lines.text: Pooh!  Pooh!  Best, you are joking.

lines.speaker: u455
lines.text: I never was more in earnest.

lines.speaker: u456
lines.text: You say he drives after breakfast and before dinner.  When he comes out to his carriage a couple of gendarmes will mount the box, and the coachman will get his orders to move on.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: And his baggage?

lines.speaker: u456
lines.text: Oh!  That will be sent after him.  I have a fancy to look into that red box which contains his papers, you say; and at noon, after parade, shall be at the inn.  You will not say a word to any one there regarding the affair, and will wait for me at the Chevalier's rooms until my arrival.  We must force that box.  You are a clumsy hound, or you would have got the key long ago.

lines.speaker: u457
lines.text: I see you are thinking of a certain young lady at Duganstown.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Is Miss Dugan well?

lines.speaker: u457
lines.text: There's only six Miss Dugans now... poor Dorothy.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Good heavens!  Whatever?  Has she died of grief?

lines.speaker: u457
lines.text: She took on so at your going away that she was obliged to console herself with a husband.  She is now Mrs. John Best.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Mrs. John Best!  Was there another Mr. John Best?!

lines.speaker: u457
lines.text: No, the very same one, my boy.  He recovered from his wound.  The ball you hit him with was not likely to hurt him.  It was only made of tow. Do you think the Dugans would let you kill fifteen hundred a-year out of the family?  The plan of the duel was all arranged in order to get you out of the way, for the cowardly Englishman could never be brought to marry from fear of you.  But hit him you certainly did, Roderick, and with a fine thick plugget of tow, and the fellow was so frightened that he was an hour in coming to. We told your mother the story afterwards, and a pretty scene she made.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: The coward!

lines.speaker: u457
lines.text: He has paid off your uncle's mortgage.  He gave Dorothy a coach- and-six.  That coward of a fellow has been making of your uncle's family.  Faith, the business was well done.  Your cousins, Michael and Harry, never let him out of their sight, though he was for deserting to England, until the marriage was completed, and the happy couple off on their road to Dublin.  Are you in want of cash, my boy?  You may draw upon me, for I got a couple of hundred out of Master Best for my share and, while they last, you shall never want.

lines.speaker: u458
lines.text: Whom have I been harboring in my house?  Who are you, sirrah?

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Sirrah!  Sirrah, I am as good a gentleman as any in Ireland!

lines.speaker: u458
lines.text: You're an impostor, young man, a schemer, a deceiver!

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Repeat the words again, and I run you through the body.

lines.speaker: u458
lines.text: Tut, tut!  I can play at fencing as well as you, Mr. Roderick James. Ah!  You change color, do you?  Your secret is known, is it?  You come like a viper into the bosom of innocent families; you represent yourself as the heir to my friends the O'Higgins of Castle O'Higgins; I introduce you to the nobility and gentry of this methropolis; I take you to my tradesmen, who give you credit.  I accept your note for near two hundred pounds, and what do I find?  A fraud.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: It is distasteful to kill a scoundrel -- that should be work for a hangman.

lines.speaker: u459
lines.text: To risk one's life against such people is an imposition.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: I risk nothing, for I am certain to kill him.

lines.speaker: u459
lines.text: Certain?

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Perfectly certain, because I shall make him tremble.

lines.speaker: u460
lines.text: I entered here, monsieur, at a bad moment for you; it seems that you love this lady.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Certainly, monseigneur, does not Your Excellency consider her worthy of love?

lines.speaker: u460
lines.text: Perfectly so; and what is more, I will tell you that I love her, and that I am not of a humor to put up with rivals.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Very well!  Now that I know it, I will no longer love her.

lines.speaker: u460
lines.text: Then you yield to me.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: On the instant.  Everyone must yield to such a nobleman as you.

lines.speaker: u460
lines.text: Very well; but a man who yields takes to his legs.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: That is a trifle strong.

lines.speaker: u460
lines.text: Take to your legs, low Irish dog.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Lady Cosgrove, you are an old fool.

lines.speaker: u461
lines.text: Old fool!

lines.speaker: u462
lines.text: Monster!  Your father was a tailor, and you are always thinking of the shop.  But I'll have my revenge, I will!  Roddy, will you see me insulted?

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Indeed, Miss Dorothy, I intend to have his blood as sure as my name's Roderick.

lines.speaker: u464
lines.text: Last month, the Duke of Suffolk spent no more.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: All right, five hundred guineas.

lines.speaker: u465
lines.text: Have you done, Mr. Cosgrove?

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Yes!

lines.speaker: u465
lines.text: Well, Mr. Cosgrove, I'll answer you point by point.  The King is exceedingly averse to make peers, as you know.  Your claim, as you call them, have been laid before him, and His Majesty's gracious reply was, that you were the most impudent man in his dominions, and merited a halter, rather than a coronet.  As for withdrawing your support from us, you are perfectly welcome to carry yourself whithersoever you please.  And, now, as I have a great deal of occupation, perhaps you will do me the favor to retire, or tell me if there is anything else in the world in which I can oblige you.

lines.speaker: u467
lines.text: Then this must be done tomorrow.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: What is to be done?

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: How different was her lively rattle to the vulgar wenches at Kilwangan assemblies.  In every sentence, she mentioned a lord or a person of quality.  To the lady's question about my birth and parentage, I replied that I was a young gentleman of large fortune, that I was going to Dublin for my studies, and that my mother allowed me five hundred per annum.

lines.speaker: u468
lines.text: You must be very cautious with regard to the company you should meet in Dublin, where rogues and adventurers of all countries abound. I hope you will do me the honor of accepting lodgings in my own house, where Captain O'Reilly will welcome with delight, my gallant young preserver.

lines.speaker: u469
lines.text: I have good news for you, Mr. Cosgrove.  The firm of Bracegirdle and Chatwick, in the city of London, are prepared to lend you 20,000 pounds, pledged against your interest in the Edric mines.  They will redeem the encumbrances against the property, which amount to some 10,000 pounds, and take a twenty- year working lease on the mines. They will lend you the 20,000 pounds against the lease income, which they will apply to the loan as it comes in, and they will make a charge of 18% per annum interest on the outstanding loan balance.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Mr. Newcombe, I have made some difficult loans during the past few years, at very onerous terms, but 18% a year interest seems very stiff indeed.

lines.speaker: u469
lines.text: Considering your financial circumstances, Mr. Cosgrove, it has been impossible to find anyone at all prepared to do any business with you.  I think you may count yourself lucky to have this opportunity. But, obviously, if you would reject this offer, I shall keep trying to find a better one.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: I am prepared to accept the terms, Mr. Newcombe.

lines.speaker: u469
lines.text: There are a few other points we should discuss.  The loan agreement can only be executed by her ladyship's signature, and provided that Bracegirdle and Chatwick can be assured of her ladyship's freewill in giving her signature.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Provided that they can be assured of her ladyship's freewill?  Are you serious?

lines.speaker: u469
lines.text: May I be quite frank with you?

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Yes, of course.

lines.speaker: u469
lines.text: Mister Bracegirdle said to me that he had heard her ladyship lives in some fear of her life, and meditated a separation, in which case, she might later repudiate any documents signed by herself while in durance, and subject them, at any rate, to a doubtful and expensive litigation. They were quite insistent on this point, and said they must have absolute assurance of her ladyship's perfect freewill in the transaction before they would advance a shilling of their capital.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: I see.

lines.speaker: u469
lines.text: When I asked them in what form they would accept her ladyship's assurances, they said that they were only prepared to accept them if her ladyship confirms her written consent by word of mouth, in their presence, at their counting-house in Birchin Lane, London.  I requested they come here, and save her ladyship and yourself the inconvenience of the trip to London, but they declined, saying that they did not wish to incur the risk of a visit to Castle Hackton to negotiate, as they were aware of how other respectable parties, such as Messrs. Sharp and Salomon had been treated here.

lines.speaker: u473
lines.text: Your bother is in America fighting the rebels.

lines.speaker: u633
lines.text: So more men were slaughtered uselessly!

lines.speaker: u639
lines.text: He broke because of me. I saw it. He lost all will to fight.

lines.speaker: u633
lines.text: We must have alliance with England to prevail here. You achieved that! You saved your family, increased your lands! In time you will have all the power in Scotland!... Yet you grieve.

lines.speaker: u639
lines.text: In my heart I had begun to hope that he would never break.

lines.speaker: u633
lines.text: All men lose heart. All betray. It is exactly why we must make the choices we make.

lines.speaker: u638
lines.text: I have faced him. Have you?

lines.speaker: u634
lines.text: Let her speak.

lines.speaker: u638
lines.text: He will fight you forever. But what does he fight for? Freedom first, and peace. So grant them.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: Treason. Against whom?

lines.speaker: u635
lines.text: Against thy king, thou vile fool! Hast thou anything to say?

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: Never, in my whole life, did I swear allegiance to your king --

lines.speaker: u635
lines.text: It matters not, he is thy king!

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: -- while many who serve him have taken and broken his oath many times. I cannot commit treason, if I have never been his subject!

lines.speaker: u635
lines.text: Confess, and you may receive a quick death. Deny, and you must be purified by pain. Do you confess? ...DO YOU CONFESS?!

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: I do not confess.

lines.speaker: u635
lines.text: Then on the morrow, thou shalt receive they purification... And in the end, I promise you'll beg for the axe.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: I'm dreaming.

lines.speaker: u636
lines.text: Yes, you are. And you must wake.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: I don't want to wake. I want to stay with you.

lines.speaker: u636
lines.text: And I with you. But you must wake.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: I need you so much! I love you!

lines.speaker: u636
lines.text: Wake up, William. Wake up!

lines.speaker: u637
lines.text: Knowing his passion for his lost love, they next plotted to take him by desecrating the graves of his father and brother and setting an ambush at the grave of his wife. He fought his way through the trap and carried her body to a secret place! Now that is romance, Oui?

lines.speaker: u638
lines.text: ...I wouldn't know.

lines.speaker: u638
lines.text: Drink this! It will dull your pain.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: It will numb my wits, and I must have them all. If I'm senseless, or if I wail, then Longshanks will have broken me.

lines.speaker: u638
lines.text: I can't bear the thought of your torture. Take it!

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: War finds me willing. I know it won't bring back all I have lost. But it can bring what none of us have ever had -- a country of our own. For that we need a king. We need you.

lines.speaker: u639
lines.text: I am trying.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: Then tell me what a king is! Is he a man who believes only what others believe? Is he one who calculates the numbers for and against him but never weighs the strength in your own heart? There is strength in you. I see it. I know it.

lines.speaker: u639
lines.text: I must... consult with my father.

lines.speaker: u641
lines.text: And I will consult with mine.

lines.speaker: u640
lines.text: Come, it'll help you sleep.

lines.text: Aye. But it won't let me dream.

lines.speaker: u643
lines.text: Just. Like. Jason.

lines.text: Suppose that you bear five or six children with your characteristics. All in Siwash Cave. In a postcatastrophe world, your offspring would of necessity intermarry, forming in time a tribe. A tribe every member of which had giant thumbs. A tribe of Big Thumbs would relate to the environment in very special ways. It could not use weapons or produce sophisticated tools. It would have to rely on its wits and its senses. It would have to live with animals -- and plants! -- as virtual equals. It's extremely pleasant to me to think about a tribe of physical eccentrics living peacefully with animals and plants, learning their languages, perhaps, and paying them the respect they deserve.

lines.text: As I developed, however, I grew more concerned with subtleties and nuances of style. Time in terms of M.P.H. no longer interested me. I began to hitchhike in something akin to geological time: slow, ancient, vast. When I am really moving, stopping car after car after car, moving so freely, so clearly, so delicately that even the sex maniacs and the cops can only blink and let me pass, then I embody the rhythms of the universe. I am in a state of grace.

lines.speaker: u889
lines.text: Tell me. When you grew up in Brooklyn, how many astronauts did you know?  You went your own way then. You didn't listen to people. So why start now...?

lines.speaker: u890
lines.text: No more cracks about how I look.

lines.speaker: u893
lines.text: Hey, I'm Mr. Sensitivity now.  Clear the way, wide load coming through.

lines.speaker: u892
lines.text: But... this disease... is progressive... degenerative...

lines.speaker: u899
lines.text: That's terrible news...

lines.speaker: u897
lines.text: What are you doing --

lines.speaker: u893
lines.text: Sis. Let me take care of you for once.

lines.speaker: u897
lines.text: But Johnny... you can't fly.

lines.speaker: u899
lines.text: Make sure you find Ben, bring him back here. And keep it quiet. I don't need this to hit the press.

lines.speaker: u894
lines.text: Yes sir. You've got the Mayor at eight, then a nine-thirty interview with the Journal --

lines.speaker: u899
lines.text: Front page?

lines.speaker: u894
lines.text: Top left, like you asked.  Today Wall Street. Tomorrow, who knows... maybe Washington.

lines.speaker: u895
lines.text: But I'm not done with the machine --

lines.speaker: u899
lines.text: Which is precisely the point. Analysis is over. It's time for action. My men could have mass-produced this by now.

lines.speaker: u897
lines.text: Please don't make this personal --

lines.speaker: u899
lines.text: Oh, I think you already have.

lines.speaker: u897
lines.text: Victor, we can't do anything until the research is ready.

lines.speaker: u898
lines.text: Reed's gonna fix me up --

lines.speaker: u899
lines.text: For your sake I hope you're right. I'm sorry if that sounds a little skeptical.

lines.speaker: u898
lines.text: Skeptical...?

lines.speaker: u900
lines.text: Brad, I really fuckin' hate McDonald's, man. Ever since they started in with the chicken, everything went downhill.

lines.speaker: u901
lines.text: You want to work at Carl's?

lines.speaker: u900
lines.text: Oh, man, if you could swing something there, I'd do anything for you. I want to work with you guys.

lines.speaker: u901
lines.text: I can probably get you in there. Just let me talk to Dennis Taylor.

lines.speaker: u900
lines.text: All right!!

lines.speaker: u905
lines.text: Did you threaten this man or use profanity in any way?

lines.speaker: u901
lines.text: He insulted me first. He called me a moron.

lines.speaker: u905
lines.text: Did you threaten this customer or use profanity in any way?

lines.speaker: u901
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u905
lines.text: You're fired.

lines.speaker: u903
lines.text: Jeff you have company!

lines.speaker: u914
lines.text: Go away, Curtis. If you can't knock, I can't hear you.

lines.speaker: u916
lines.text: And... you can only tell it's the right girl if you're sensitive.

lines.speaker: u904
lines.text: Sensitive -- what is that?

lines.speaker: u916
lines.text: Sensitive is when you can tell how people feel without asking.

lines.speaker: u904
lines.text: So what makes you so sensitive?

lines.speaker: u916
lines.text: Well, for one, I read. I don't watch as much television as you. I'm trying to feel things more. I'm learning a lot about people.

lines.speaker: u904
lines.text: What do you read? What's the last book you read?

lines.speaker: u916
lines.text: Lust For Life. It's the story of Vincent Van Gough.

lines.speaker: u904
lines.text: Yeah, well, I saw the movie. That must mean I'm sensitive too.

lines.speaker: u916
lines.text: It's a way, Damone. It's a vibe. I put it out, and I have personally found that girls do respond.

lines.speaker: u910
lines.text: All right, what you want to do is go to the Free Clinic and tell the doctor that you have sex regularly -- several times a week -- and that you need Nornel One Plus Fifty's.

lines.speaker: u906
lines.text: And they don't call my parents?

lines.speaker: u910
lines.text: Not if you're over sixteen.

lines.speaker: u906
lines.text: Okay. Thanks a lot, Linda.

lines.speaker: u910
lines.text: And don't let them talk you into a diaphragm either.

lines.speaker: u907
lines.text: What's going through your mind right here, Jeff? The danger of it all?

lines.speaker: u914
lines.text: Merv, I'm thinking... I've only got about four good hours of surfing left before these little clowns from junior high start showing up with their boogie boards.

lines.speaker: u909
lines.text: That's him! He did it!

lines.text: Hey, mon, I don't know what your trip is, but...

lines.text: Where's Doug?

lines.text: He's not coming.

lines.speaker: u910

lines.speaker: u915

lines.speaker: u910
lines.text: Yeah, like maybe never.

lines.text: But what are you going to do?

lines.text: Well I might go to Dartmouth.

lines.text: I didn't tell anyone I applied cause I never thought I'd make it.

lines.speaker: u915
lines.text: I can't believe it! But what about Doug?

lines.text: There's a world of guys out there. I just wish I didn't have to date any of them.

lines.text: Yes.

lines.text: Well, I don't know, I may be doing some traveling this summer. I don't know how much I'll be around...  But I'll give you a call sometime.

lines.speaker: u915
lines.text: I'd like that.

lines.speaker: u917
lines.text: Are you sure there's nothing else I can bring you?

lines.speaker: u916
lines.text: I'll have one more Coke... Do you want another Coke, Stacy?

lines.text: The woman who left that message for you sounded very disturbed. I think she was crying...

lines.text: Crying? Why was she crying?

lines.speaker: u918
lines.text: Well, uh. She didn't say Mr. Duke. But since I know you're here with the Police Convention...

lines.speaker: u920
lines.text: Look, you want to be gentle with that woman if she ever calls again. We're watching her very carefully... this woman has been into laudanum. It's a controlled experiment, but I suspect we'll need your cooperation before this thing is over.

lines.speaker: u918
lines.text: Well, certainly... We're always happy to cooperate with the police...

lines.speaker: u920
lines.text: Don't worry. You're protected. Just treat this poor woman like you'd treat any other human being in trouble.

lines.speaker: u918
lines.text: What? Ah... yes, yes, I see what you mean... Yes... so, you'll be responsible then?

lines.speaker: u920
lines.text: Of course. And now I have to get back to the news. Send up some ice.

lines.speaker: u919
lines.text: Hell, I really hate to hear this. Because everything that happens in California seems to get down our way, sooner or later. Mostly Atlanta. But that was back when the goddamn bastards were peaceful. All we had to do was to keep 'em under surveillance. They didn't roam around much... But now Jesus, it seems nobody's safe.

lines.speaker: u921
lines.text: You're going to need to take the bull by the horns -- go to the mat with this scum.

lines.speaker: u919
lines.text: What do you mean by that?

lines.speaker: u921
lines.text: You know what I mean. We've done it before and we can damn well do it again!

lines.speaker: u922
lines.text: Okay. Here's how it is. What goes into my book, as of noon, is that I apprehended you... for driving too fast, and advised you to proceed no further than the next rest area... your stated destination, right? Where you plan to take a long nap. Do I make myself clear?

lines.speaker: u920
lines.text: How far is Baker? I was hoping to stop there for lunch.

lines.speaker: u922
lines.text: Not my jurisdiction. The city limits are two point two miles beyond the rest area. Can you make it that far?

lines.speaker: u920
lines.text: I'll try. I've been wanting to go to Baker for a long time. I've heard a lot about it.

lines.speaker: u921
lines.text: Oh, and don't bother to make up the room. That way we won't have to risk another of these little incidents, will we?

lines.speaker: u924
lines.text: Whatever you say, gentlemen. I can't tell you how sorry I am about what happened...

lines.speaker: u921
lines.text: Don't worry, it's all over now. Thank God for the decent people.

lines.speaker: u926
lines.text: Sorry, didn't mean to scare you.

lines.speaker: u935
lines.text: Where is everyone?

lines.speaker: u926
lines.text: I don't know, I just got here. Did you find your girl?

lines.speaker: u937
lines.text: That's an unwise thing to say, you know that?

lines.speaker: u927
lines.text: Just an observation.

lines.speaker: u937
lines.text: Well, why don't you keep your observations to yourself?

lines.speaker: u935
lines.text: It's imperative that you get that truck moving.

lines.speaker: u928
lines.text: Just cover me. It was built to move.

lines.speaker: u929
lines.text: What? Really?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Uh huh, now wiggle that sweet little ass over here and sit on Daddy's face, I wanna do some appraising.

lines.text: What's it for!?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Grass. I grow some pot down there. It's no big deal, just something I dabble in. The truck's for a quick get away, deliveries, whatever.

lines.speaker: u935
lines.text: Is it gassed up?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Fully.

lines.text: Four door?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Two.

lines.speaker: u935
lines.text: Open?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Covered.

lines.text: Max?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Seven.

lines.speaker: u935
lines.text: Nine?

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: Seven.

lines.speaker: u935
lines.text: Keys.

lines.speaker: u930
lines.text: What!? So you can just get the hell outta here and forget about all of us!? No way! That's my god damn truck!

lines.text: Let me make this clear; if we stay, we die!

lines.text: OH JESUS!

lines.text: I think --

lines.text: Come on, Frances. Louella Parsons is here. She wants to talk to you, help you out.

lines.text: You don't think I'm good enough?

lines.text: But... but wait a minute. We're supposed to be different, right? Clifford says... This theatre is supposed to be different! And this play... this play is all about what greed and money do to people!

lines.text: I know, but --

lines.text: Does Clifford even know?  You didn't tell him, did you?  I'm gonna tell him. Where is he?

lines.speaker: u947
lines.text: Get your clothes on.

lines.text: You have no right! You have no fucking right, you bastards! Get the hell out of here --

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: GET OUT!

lines.speaker: u947
lines.text: You're under arrest.

lines.text: ...Yes.

lines.speaker: u948
lines.text: Without me.

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: Showdown.

lines.text: You weren't going to tell me, were you? Just pack up and leave, is that it?

lines.text: Dick, we need some time apart --

lines.text: Hey, I'm not a complete fool, you know. I can see you're going sour on me, and when I try to do something about it, you turn your back and say it's nothing.

lines.text: Dick, I can't even breathe here...

lines.speaker: u948
lines.text: Dwayne! I'm Dwayne now! And you damn well better get used to it!

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: Dick...

lines.speaker: u948
lines.text: I don't suppose it occurred to you that I might want to leave too, that I might want to do theatre? No, 'cause you don't want me along, do you? And the reason has nothing to do with summer stock.

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: No?

lines.speaker: u948
lines.text: No. It's all about that night, isn't it?

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: What night?

lines.speaker: u948
lines.text: The premiere. I never pressed you about it but god damn it, you're gonna tell me right here and right now what happened and where the hell you were!

lines.text: You want his name?

lines.speaker: u949
lines.text: We're all square now, Harry. Right?

lines.speaker: u956
lines.text: All square, Doc.

lines.speaker: u949
lines.text: Good. 'Cause I don't want to see you again.

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: Harry? Oh Harry, I knew you'd come. I love you, Harry. I love... Take me home, Harry.

lines.text: We'll get you home, Frances.

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: Thank you, Harry.

lines.text: This is the answer: a subscription drive to "Voice of Action!" First prize is a trip to Moscow! You could visit the art theatre, maybe even meet Stanislavski!

lines.text: But I'll never win that.

lines.speaker: u951

lines.speaker: u955
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.text: Thank you, Ralph.

lines.text: Thank you, Frances. And after the show we're hosting a reception for you and your friends at Hollywood's own Roosevelt Hotel!

lines.text: Lillian... I'm more than willing to meet you halfway.

lines.text: But, Kurt, I...

lines.text: No, No arguments. Be my good girl and go. There's a forest, a burning forest, and you know what I have to do!

lines.text: Oh, Kurt!

lines.text: Oh Angela, my own... Angela!

lines.text: Symington says...

lines.text: And do you think it's radical for a man to have a job and feed a family?

lines.text: No!

lines.text: Is it radical for you to have a hand in shaping your future, and the future of your children?

lines.speaker: u968
lines.text: No!

lines.text: Is it radical for the wealth of this country to be turned back to the people who built the country?

lines.speaker: u968
lines.text: No! No!

lines.text: Good! Because, Brothers, that's you!

lines.text: I don't know why they even bother. She's had enough of this to knock sense into a bull elephant.

lines.text: Yeah?

lines.text: I checked the files. This one holds the record for shock treatments. Four hundred seventeen and no end in sight.

lines.speaker: u970
lines.text: You're kidding.

lines.text: Yeah, well, you know doctors. They sure hate to use that word.

lines.text: What?

lines.text: GET AWAY FROM HER! SHE'S MINE!

lines.text: Victor!

lines.text: Open this door for no-one!

lines.text: A warming wind.

lines.speaker: u975
lines.text: This ice will break yet.  How's our guest?

lines.speaker: u982
lines.text: He died. Raving about phantoms. He was mad, poor devil.  Gather a detail. Have the body removed from my cabin.

lines.text: Aye, Captain.

lines.speaker: u980
lines.text: All that I once loved lies in a shallow grave. By my hand.

lines.speaker: u976
lines.text: Let it go.

lines.text: I have always loved him.

lines.speaker: u979
lines.text: Is it also not true that you murdered his brother William in a misdirected crime of passion?

lines.speaker: u977
lines.text: Murder Willie? In my heart, he was our child. Victor's and mine. Such a thing could never have entered my mind.

lines.speaker: u979
lines.text: So you have claimed. Yet you have no explanation for this.  The locket last seen in the hands of the poor murdered child was found hidden in your dress the morning following the murder. The locket you so coveted.  How did it come to be in your possession?

lines.speaker: u977
lines.text: I have no knowledge of that.

lines.speaker: u978
lines.text: You seem to be adapting well to the approved curriculum.

lines.speaker: u980
lines.text: Despite the lack of challenge.

lines.speaker: u980
lines.text: We are kindred, you and I. Men of ambition. Let me tell you all that I have lost in such pursuits. I pray my story will come to mean for you all that is capricious and evil in man.

lines.speaker: u982
lines.text: Who are you?

lines.text: My name is Frankenstein...

lines.speaker: u983
lines.text: Sure.

lines.text: I'm gonna go lie down and catch some z's. Today wiped me out.  Thanks, Alice.

lines.text: You just had some lucky shots.

lines.speaker: u1006
lines.text: For the time being we are very confident we will apprehend the fugitives in the next forty-eight hours. The Bureau, local law enforcement and the Texas Rangers have all joined forces in forming a dragnet to snare Seth and Richard Gecko.

lines.speaker: u999
lines.text: Agent Chase, does it appear that they are heading for Mexico.

lines.speaker: u1006
lines.text: Yes, it does, Kelly. We have already alerted the Mexican authorities. They intend to cooperate every way possible in bringing these fugitives to justice.

lines.speaker: u999
lines.text: Are you optimistic about the safety of the hostage they took in Abilene, Gloria Hill?

lines.speaker: u1006
lines.text: We've received no news one way or the other. We can only hope for the best.

lines.speaker: u999
lines.text: What about the report from an eyewitness at the liquor store who said one of the brothers was shot?

lines.speaker: u1006
lines.text: This can't be confirmed at this time, but we do believe it to be true. We have reason to believe it was the youngest brother Richard, and he was shot in the vicinity of his neck and shoulders by the store's clerk.

lines.speaker: u999
lines.text: Is it safe to assume that because the death count involved and the loss of life of law enforcement officers, that the Bureau, the Rangers and the police force are taking this manhunt personally?

lines.speaker: u1006
lines.text: I would say that's a very safe assumption.

lines.speaker: u1000
lines.text: Yeah, and I'm gonna be right back at it tomorrow. So tonight I'm gonna sit in front of the box and just drink booze. How much is the bottle?

lines.speaker: u1001
lines.text: Six-fifty.

lines.speaker: u1001
lines.text: I never said help us!

lines.speaker: u1005
lines.text: Well that don't matter now, 'cause you got about two fuckin' seconds to live! Richie!

lines.speaker: u1002
lines.text: Best in Mexico.

lines.speaker: u1005
lines.text: I kinda doubt that. We're grabbin' a table, send over a waitress to take our order.

lines.speaker: u1003
lines.text: How are you?

lines.speaker: u1005
lines.text: Scarred for life, that's how I am!

lines.speaker: u1004
lines.text: He's right, Kate. Daddy's dead! He was too far away. If flinging that door and filling this room with those bat-things would save him, I'd fling it. The only thing it'll do is turn us into one of them.

lines.speaker: u1005
lines.text: He needs our help!

lines.speaker: u1004
lines.text: He's beyond our help. You saw him get bit. I saw him get bit. We all saw it. You can't help him. I've got no one left to lose but you. I can't be alone again. We're sticking together.

lines.speaker: u1007
lines.text: Wow...

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: What'd you find, Kathy?

lines.speaker: u1008
lines.text: Well, if you had to go over my head, lieutenant, that's the way to do it.  Christ, nothin' like a 0-200 call from the Commander and Chief to get the bowels movin'.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: Sir?  What did he say?

lines.speaker: u1008
lines.text: Basically -- he asked me if I could unring a bell.

lines.speaker: u1009
lines.text: What, we're gonna pry 'em out with paddles?

lines.speaker: u1018
lines.text: O'Neil.  Our air's gonna crap out as soon as we get down there.  You know that, don't you?

lines.speaker: u1010
lines.text: I once promised you a fast ticket, Jordan, and I always meant to make good on that.  Come work for me.  I can always use a hard-charger on my team.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: You promise Wickwire a fast ticket, too?

lines.speaker: u1010
lines.text: I've had no direct communication with him since this whole thing began.  And that's quite verifiable.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: I'm sure it is.

lines.speaker: u1010
lines.text: You'll think about my offer?

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: You know, I wonder what the SecNav would think about it.  If I spoke with him.

lines.speaker: u1010
lines.text: Well, I spoke with Mr. Hayes this morning myself -- and told him the deal was off.  No more test cases. He was only too happy to oblige.  Don't play politics with me, little darlin'.  You'd be up way past your bedtime.

lines.speaker: u1014
lines.text: What the hell is the President trying to do?  Steal DeHaven's thunder?

lines.speaker: u1012
lines.text: I think it's more important, sir, to decide what we're going to do -- since it's apparent this issue is not going away quietly.

lines.speaker: u1014
lines.text: "G.I. Jane."  And which one of you told me she wouldn't last a week? Huh?

lines.speaker: u1013
lines.text: Six o'clock!  Marking, marking!

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: Spotted you, Chief.  Pri One is to slip you some air, so we're coming down with a tank -- just something until the A-team shows.  Over.

lines.speaker: u1015
lines.text: O'Neil?

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: u1015
lines.text: You're wanted at the C.O.'s.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: The Navy Cross...

lines.speaker: u1016
lines.text: I believe he earned it for saving a man's life in Saudi Arabia.  He wanted you to have it.  He was very clear on that point.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: I was looking for him earlier, but...

lines.speaker: u1016
lines.text: The Chief was granted early retirement as of 17-hundred yesterday.  By 18-hundred he was gone.  Out of the Navy.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: Just a coincidence?

lines.speaker: u1016
lines.text: Maybe it's not my place to speculate on his private thoughts.  But I think the Chief knew that his way -- his world -- had come and gone.

lines.speaker: u1020
lines.text: Maybe we should call the Coast Guard.

lines.speaker: u1017
lines.text: Shut your hole, Slutnik.

lines.speaker: u1020
lines.text: This ain't workin' right!

lines.speaker: u1018
lines.text: What's our go-to-shit plan, O'Neil?

lines.speaker: u1020
lines.text: This ain't even workin' wrong!

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: The White House.  If Jordan wins, DeHaven wins in spades.  Why?  Well, it's been said that the only man the President fears -- ain't no man.

lines.speaker: u1019
lines.text: The first female President?

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: Don't for a second think she didn't leak this story.  "G.I. Jane" gives DeHaven a symbol that taps into the biggest constituency of them all.

lines.speaker: u1019
lines.text: Women.

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: If you were the President, wouldn't that put a little piss in your shoes?

lines.speaker: u1019
lines.text: I don't know.  Seems...

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: This ain't about some little soldier girl sloggin' her way through commando school.  The implications go way beyond.

lines.speaker: u1019
lines.text: Christ, I don't want to see her take a fall.  She thinks I do, but...

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: I take it this file is still open.

lines.speaker: u1019
lines.text: Even tough I don't talk to her every day -- I still talk to her every day.  Know what I mean?

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: Okay, so now work it from the other end.  Think about California -- and how things might be handled there.

lines.speaker: u1019
lines.text: I don't...  What, someone on base?  A "mole"?

lines.speaker: u1022
lines.text: This is what you get for brain- picking an old CIA spook.  but if I needed to control the outcome of this test case, that's how I'd do it.  A man-in-place.  Makes everything very controllable.

lines.speaker: u1024
lines.text: Audrey, did you take the tape out of the camera?

lines.speaker: u1025
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u1026
lines.text: We did it! We've got the exclusive! Way to go, Audrey!

lines.speaker: u1025
lines.text: We? I don't think so.

lines.speaker: u1026
lines.text: I want that story, Audrey. Remember you work for me.

lines.speaker: u1025
lines.text: Not anymore. Mr. Caiman, I quit.

lines.speaker: u1034
lines.text: Make sure they find that nest before it's too late.

lines.speaker: u1027
lines.text: I'll try.

lines.speaker: u1028
lines.text: We've secured the doors on both levels.

lines.text: Where's Luc and Pierre?

lines.speaker: u1028
lines.text: They didn't make it.

lines.speaker: u1035
lines.text: Nick, my men and I will hold them here. You will have to go and get help!

lines.speaker: u1030
lines.text: When we learned he could burrow his way through the tunnels we realized he could be out of the quarantined zone.

lines.speaker: u1032
lines.text: Christ. How many tunnels lead off the island?

lines.speaker: u1030
lines.text: Only five, Sir. We've checked them all. He hasn't used any of them.

lines.speaker: u1032
lines.text: Have them sealed off.

lines.speaker: u1030
lines.text: And how should we do that, Sir?

lines.speaker: u1032
lines.text: Fill them with cement, brick them up, put land mines in them, bombs, I don't know, just make sure that goddamned thing doesn't leave the island!

lines.speaker: u1032
lines.text: Organize a search party. I want a complete sweep of the entire city and subway system.

lines.speaker: u1033
lines.text: You don't have the authority to do that.

lines.speaker: u1034
lines.text: I understand.

lines.speaker: u1035
lines.text: I just wanted to say, au revoir and thank you for your help, my friend.

lines.speaker: u1034
lines.text: Wait.  Au revoir.

lines.speaker: u1041
lines.text: He always has to make the big entrance.

lines.speaker: u1036
lines.text: By Grabthar's Hammer, this is true. 159	NT. LIVING ROOM - SOMEWHERE - NIGHT	159

lines.text: These men were taken from their homes at night, tried by Reed's courts -- which Congress recognizes -- and, well, you can see.

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Cut those men down.  Congress is pushing ahead with your court-martial.  Benedict, trust me to handle this.

lines.text: Well, what have you thought?

lines.speaker: u1051
lines.text: Well, general, I think I ain't got no school learning, I ain't got no trade... and I'm a drunk.  So, I think there ain't much left to be set free.

lines.speaker: u1052
lines.text: Negroes?  Washington has black men in his army?  Are they good fighters?  What's that red ribbon on his arm, Colonel?

lines.speaker: u1060
lines.text: Because they have hardly any uniforms, they designate officers with colored ribbons.  My lord.

lines.speaker: u1052
lines.text: By red, what rank would you say this black, officer, soldier is, Colonel?

lines.speaker: u1060
lines.text: I, don't know what color is what officer, my lord...

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Who is that!?

lines.speaker: u1053
lines.text: That's Greene.  He's supporting our reconsolidation.

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Marquis!  Get these men reformed, send Steuben and Wayne out on the left...

lines.speaker: u1054
lines.text: That's why the people trust you George.  Without someone at the convention, who has the people behind him, everything will fail. Will you do it?

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: You're asking me to be president of a republic, not king?  Not a dictator over subjects?

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Horatio!  Horatio Gates, of course you know John Adams of the Massachusetts Delegation.

lines.speaker: u1055
lines.text: Good day, Mister Adams... George, what's the word from Boston?

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: The last I heard, a bunch of drunken militia have dug in on Breed's hill.  With one stroke the British could cut them off and apparently their leaders are too dumb to see it.

lines.speaker: u1055
lines.text: Who's in command out there?

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Who the hell knows?  Everyone's giving orders.  It's all very democratic.

lines.speaker: u1055
lines.text: George, we've got to get you out there before we lose our whole army.

lines.speaker: u1056
lines.text: Partially...

lines.speaker: u1063
lines.text: It's the political 'cost of doing business', George.

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Arnold is indispensable, do you understand?  I need Arnold to help me win this war!

lines.speaker: u1057
lines.text: Well, I shall deny him to you!  He is evil on earth!

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: Are you all going insane!? Benedict Arnold!  The man who stopped the British on Lake Champlain!  Who carried the day at Saratoga!  Goddamn-it, Joseph, you own two mansions, ride in an expensive, Tory coach!  You are all nothing but a pack of greedy pigs!

lines.speaker: u1058
lines.text: I feel the same, sir.

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: I will continue with our French allies, concentrating on New York.

lines.speaker: u1059
lines.text: Not today.

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: I want you to see our hospital.

lines.speaker: u1059
lines.text: I don't want to see your hospital.

lines.speaker: u1061
lines.text: If the constitution is ratified... we'll have a country.  They'll want to elect you president of the convention, which means president of the country.

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: You know, I came back to Mount Vernon to retire.  I don't need to be in government.

lines.speaker: u1062
lines.text: Remember, George, "It is dangerous to be right in matters on which the established authorities are wrong."

lines.speaker: u1066
lines.text: That's good... who?

lines.speaker: u1062
lines.text: Voltaire, of course...

lines.speaker: u1063
lines.text: Is that your test of patriotism, George; if a man will die for you?

lines.speaker: u1064
lines.text: God damn you, Sam Adams!  You wanted a revolutionary army and now that we've really got one it scares you more than it does the British!

lines.speaker: u1066
lines.text: William, we've been studying hard, I really know my stuff.

lines.speaker: u1065
lines.text: Don't be silly, you have whole worlds to fathom.

lines.speaker: u1067

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: I reserved a Cadillac.

lines.speaker: u1067
lines.text: Yeah, well, this one's the Cadillac of minivans.

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: You're kidding me, right?

lines.speaker: u1067
lines.text: Hey, you want La Tierra Rent-A-Car just over there, but I think all they got are Rabbit convertibles.

lines.speaker: u1068
lines.text: I think I pulled my quadriceps.

lines.text: So... how many movies you been in?

lines.speaker: u1068
lines.text: About sixty.

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: No shit? What're some of 'em?

lines.speaker: u1069
lines.text: You get to town, you go straight to the bank, raid the limo account.

lines.speaker: u1083
lines.text: I'm already in town, but it don't matter. We got dick in the bank. We dumped it all in Harry's movie.

lines.speaker: u1069
lines.text: What I'm sayin' is the man wants his money and he wants it now.

lines.speaker: u1070
lines.text: You a quick draw... 'bro?' You better be, your piece stuck way down in your belt like that.

lines.speaker: u1083
lines.text: Whatta you got there... some kinda pop nine, the fuckin' Fiat of guns, always jammin' at the wrong time.

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: I hate to say I told you, but I did. I told you don't start nothing with him that time.

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: You said don't say nothing and I didn't.

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: No, you just broke his fuckin' nose instead.

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: You gonna start that again? You're just like him, all you got room for in your brain is one fuckin' thing.

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: All I know is he came by the barber shop, all fuckin' undone, wanting to know where you were staying in Vegas. I told him I don't know. I still don't.

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: How'd he know I was in Vegas? You tell him?

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: He already knew it.

lines.speaker: u1071

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: Whatta you doing out there?

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: I'm going into the movie business.

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: What're you talking about? You wanna be a movie star?

lines.speaker: u1071
lines.text: I'm thinking about producing.

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: How you gonna do that? You don't know shit about making movies.

lines.speaker: u1071

lines.speaker: u1084
lines.text: Hey, Chil? I think you're fulla shit.

lines.text: So Mildred says to the cashier, 'I saw the new Streisand picture.'  'God, I just love it at the end when she brushed Robert Redford's hair off his forehead the way she did when they were together, and the way they gave each other this look that said they still loved each other, but knew they couldn't be together. That look was so... romantic.'

lines.speaker: u1074
lines.text: That's great, Harry. So what's the --

lines.speaker: u1077
lines.text: What she did not say was, 'I just loved the way the director moved the camera so much it made me fuckin' seasick.' All she cared about was that look. All she remembered was that look. And why do we remember things in movies? Because we can see them.

lines.speaker: u1077
lines.text: So this means you've reconsidered our deal on Mr. Lovejoy?

lines.speaker: u1075
lines.text: No. But now that you mention it, I did talk to a handsome executive at Paramount the other day... who just happened to get his hands on the script.

lines.speaker: u1077
lines.text: Yeah, what'd he have to say?

lines.speaker: u1075
lines.text: He said if Martin's interested, I could get a half a million for it easy. But don't worry, Harry, I'm still giving you until Friday.

lines.speaker: u1077
lines.text: How honorable of you.

lines.speaker: u1081
lines.text: I have to run. But what I hope to see, they begin to have misgivings about wanting the money. It becomes their moral dilemma and they try to rationalize keeping it, but in the end they can't. Can they?

lines.text: What money?

lines.speaker: u1081
lines.text: The three hundred large. What other money is there?  I should keep quiet, I know, till I've read the script, but I've got a feeling about this one. I'm that shylock.

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: It was only a matter of time before somebody killed somebody.  You saw it coming as well as I did. Dodge had his plans, starting with scuttling the boat. And Greer too, except he went nuts. Couldn't take it, I guess. Could've happened in the middle of downtown Anchorage. But did it make him any less dangerous? I don't think so.

lines.speaker: u1087
lines.text: So you killed them?

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: The way I figure it, it was them or me. I thought putting Dodge up on that pipe was a nice touch? Bought a little time. Made it look like whoever killed those Greeks was still around. But it's just us on this ship. Us and your... spirit friends.

lines.speaker: u1087
lines.text: And now you're gonna kill me, is that it?

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: I didn't want it to turn out this way.

lines.speaker: u1087
lines.text: Murphy, don't you see what's happening?

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: I think I see it pretty well.

lines.speaker: u1087
lines.text: It's the ship. The ship's making you think this way.

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: I know a little bit about human nature and what I've seen only confirms that.

lines.speaker: u1087
lines.text: It's a trap. There was no way we were gonna get away with that gold. Nobody ever does. It's just the bait. This ship sucks people in and it never lets them out.

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: I think maybe you been on this boat a little too long, with all that supernatural mumbo jumbo. There's nothing supernatural about greed. And that's what it comes down to, pure and simple.

lines.speaker: u1087
lines.text: I don't give a damn about the gold.

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: I wish I could believe that. Either way, you know what I've done. I've got no choice.

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: Nobody's going anywhere with that gold now. Anybody tries to board, we'll know about it.  You can do what you want, Greer. But neither of us is gonna risk saving your ass down here if it comes to that.

lines.speaker: u1088
lines.text: Fine with me.

lines.speaker: u1089
lines.text: You're kidding, right?

lines.text: You want fair pay, make hamburger for Mickey D. Otherwise, please to sign.

lines.speaker: u1094

lines.text: Let me tell ya somethin', Joe... Listen to me, Joe... you can't hit a home run without swinging the bat!

lines.speaker: u1097

lines.text: Yeah.
