lines.speaker: u1107
lines.text: I can see that... now what can you tell us about it? First of all, what kind of sculpture is this?

lines.speaker: u1103
lines.text: It's a "found object"... that's when an artist takes an ordinary object and places it in an artistic context and thus it becomes art.

lines.speaker: u1107
lines.text: Very good. Now, what can you tell us about it in regard to your artistic intent?

lines.speaker: u1103
lines.text: I guess I see the teacup as a symbol for womanhood, because of tea parties in the olden days, but instead of tea I was trying to kind of confront people with this... like...

lines.speaker: u1107
lines.text: This shocking image of repressed femininity!

lines.speaker: u1103
lines.text: Right, exactly!

lines.speaker: u1107
lines.text: I think it's really a wonderful piece, Margaret!

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Uh... hi. Uh... Enid's stepmother told me I'd find her here?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: She's not at home?

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: No... they said she was here...

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: What the fuck is she doing?! She was supposed to be here three hours ago!

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Uh, do you mind if I wait? I really need to talk to her.

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Are you sure she wasn't there?  Maybe she was just hiding from you.

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Why would she be hiding from me?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: I don't know... where is she, then?

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Maybe she's with Josh?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Josh!? Why would she be with Josh?

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Why? What did she tell you?

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: She just mentioned him a few times and said that they had been dating - I thought maybe she was...

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: What? Is she having some secret affair with Josh?

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: I have no idea - I just want to...

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Why wouldn't she tell me? There's no way! She could never keep that to herself... you're crazy.

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Really, I don't know enough about it to...

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: That slut!

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Why did you say she might be hiding from me? Did she say anything to you about me?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Yeah, she thinks you're a dork.

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Did she say that?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Look, what do you expect?  Considering how we met you.

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: On that pathetic fake blind date.

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: What are you talking about?

lines.speaker: u1106
lines.text: Didn't she ever tell you about that? God, she really is pathological...

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: What fake blind date? What are you talking about?

lines.speaker: u1109
lines.text: Seymour?

lines.speaker: u1108
lines.text: Yes?

lines.speaker: u1109
lines.text: Do you have a check for me?

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: Starting now, we attack them.

lines.speaker: u1111
lines.text: How; we don't know where they are?

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: We'll have to make them come to us, won't we? And since there are two of them, we're going to set two plans in motion.  First: we must move the entire hospital by tomorrow night.

lines.speaker: u1112
lines.text: Understand, I had help-

lines.speaker: u1116
lines.text: -not a time for modesty, Bob-

lines.speaker: u1113
lines.text: That's a terrible idea-

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: -is it, I'm sorry, but then, of course, you're the doctor, you should know.

lines.speaker: u1113
lines.text: Silliest thing I ever heard of- why in the world should we go through all that?

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: I suppose I could answer you. I suppose I could explain that the place is so inviting, what with the smell of blood and flesh, that they have to strike. It's even possible that I tell you I found some fresh paw marks around back which means they're already contemplating feasting here.  But I don't want to answer you because when you question me you are really saying that I don't have the least idea what I am doing, that I am nothing but an incompetent, that I am a fool.  Anyone who finds me a fool, please say so now.

lines.speaker: u1113
lines.text: I have been desperate for Patterson to let me move the hospital since the day he arrived.

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: Then we agree.

lines.speaker: u1114
lines.text: Go, now.  Such a gentleman.

lines.speaker: u1116
lines.text: I am desperate to see Africa- but I hate the leaving.

lines.speaker: u1116
lines.text: Not once?- you didn't hit it once?-

lines.speaker: u1115
lines.text: -I would never make excuses- but a fire broke out- the light was bad- he kept moving-

lines.speaker: u1116
lines.text: -well, of course he kept moving- but he couldn't have been more than ten feet away from the three of you- surely you must have wounded the thing-

lines.speaker: u1115
lines.text: I assure you we came close many times-

lines.speaker: u1118
lines.text: Afraid of lions.

lines.speaker: u1116
lines.text: It's all right, Samuel- we all get hit-

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: My life was shaped because someone invented gunpowder. Our lives have crossed because two lions went mad. But what if in the future the three of us do something grand for humanity? Was that worth all the lives? Too soon to tell.

lines.speaker: u1118
lines.text: Some mysteries should not have solutions.

lines.speaker: u1117
lines.text: Hold your son high.

lines.speaker: u1132
lines.text: Sorry!

lines.speaker: u1120
lines.text: Maybe we should discuss this somewhere else.

lines.speaker: u1121
lines.text: According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?

lines.speaker: u1121
lines.text: I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?

lines.speaker: u1121
lines.text: It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard.  Anyway, we're just about out of time.  Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets.  Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ...  ... Good night.

lines.speaker: u1123
lines.text: Look, I've had it with you.  Get your stuff together, get back in that clown car and get out of here.  This is a city matter and everything's under control.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Oh, you think so?  Well, I've got news for you.  You've got Dracula's brother-in-law in there and he's got my girlfriend and her kid.  Around about midnight tonight, when you're partying uptown, this guy's going to come to life and start doing amateur head transplants.  And that's just round one.

lines.speaker: u1124
lines.text: I'm not sure this is such a good idea?  Do they know you're doing this?

lines.speaker: u1127
lines.text: Oh, yeah, sure -- no.  But there's really not much to do here and they might need some back-up at the museum.

lines.speaker: u1124
lines.text: You're very brave, Louis.  Good luck.

lines.speaker: u1134
lines.text: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia --

lines.speaker: u1125
lines.text: Yes, the scourge --

lines.speaker: u1134
lines.text: -- the sorrow of Moldavia --

lines.speaker: u1125
lines.text: -- the sorrow --

lines.speaker: u1134
lines.text: I command you.

lines.speaker: u1125
lines.text: I await the word of Vigo.

lines.speaker: u1134
lines.text: The season of evil begins with the birth of the new year.  Bring me the child that I might live again.

lines.speaker: u1125
lines.text: Lord Vigo, the mother, Dana, is fine and strong.  I was wondering -- well, would it be possible -- if I bring the baby, could I have the woman?

lines.speaker: u1134
lines.text: So be it.  On this the day of darkness, she will be ours, wife to you and mother to me.

lines.speaker: u1126
lines.text: That's it?  That's all you have to say?

lines.speaker: u1127
lines.text: Did I forget something?

lines.speaker: u1127
lines.text: Hey!  Wait!  Okay, I'll meet you there.

lines.speaker: u1130
lines.text: I thought you were like the fifth Ghostbuster.

lines.speaker: u1127
lines.text: I let them handle all the little stuff.  I just come in on the big ones.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Hi, welcome back to the 'World of the Psychic,' I'm Peter Venkman and I'm chatting with my guest, author, lecturer and of course, psychic, Milton Anglund.  Milt, your new book is called The End of the World.  Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease.  Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it?

lines.speaker: u1128
lines.text: Well, I think it's important for people to know that the world is in danger.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Okay, so can you tell us when it's going to happen or do we have to buy the book?

lines.speaker: u1128
lines.text: I predict that the world will end at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: This year?  That's cutting it a little close, isn't it?  I mean, just from a sales point of view, the book just came out, right?  So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year.  And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe.

lines.speaker: u1128
lines.text: This is not just some money-making scheme!  I didn't just make up the date.  I have a strong psychic belief that the world will end on New Year's Eve.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Well, for your sake, I hope you're right.  But I think my other guest may disagree with you. Elaine, you had another date in mind?

lines.speaker: u1129
lines.text: I'll ask you again, Dr. Venkman.  Why were you digging the hole?  And please remember that you're under oath.

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: I had my fingers crossed when they swore me in, but I'm going to tell you the truth. There are things in this world that go way beyond human understanding, things that can't be explained and that most people don't want to know about anyway.  That's where we come in.

lines.speaker: u1129
lines.text: So what are you saying?  That the world of the supernatural is your special province?

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: No, I guess I'm just saying that shit happens and somebody has to deal with it.

lines.speaker: u1131
lines.text: Late Renaissance, I think.  Caravaggio or Brunelleschi.

lines.speaker: u1135
lines.text: There's something very familiar about this painting.

lines.speaker: u1135
lines.text: Ray -- Ray -- How do you feel, man?

lines.speaker: u1132
lines.text: Groovy.  I've never felt better in my life.

lines.speaker: u1135
lines.text: My people weren't taking any pictures from those slave ships, man.  And there wasn't any Statue in Charleston Harbor to welcome them, either.  What are you, Dana?

lines.speaker: u1133
lines.text: Miss Blue Blood?  Her family's been here since the year 12.

lines.speaker: u1136
lines.text: Hey, sweetheart, will you CUT THAT OUT!!!

lines.speaker: u1141
lines.text: Uuuuuuugh!!

lines.speaker: u1136
lines.text: What's the matter, dear?

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: Okay.  Just give me a second here.  I have to leave now but if you've got some time I'd like you to come back this evening and do some more work with me.

lines.speaker: u1137
lines.text: Eight o'clock?

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: I was just going to say "eight."  You're fantastic!

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: This is going to cost you, you know.  Our fees are ridiculously high.

lines.speaker: u1138
lines.text: Talk to my accountant.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: I trust you're moving us to a better space somewhere on campus.

lines.speaker: u1139
lines.text: No, we're moving you OFF CAMPUS.  The Board of Regents has decided to terminate your grant.  You are to vacate these premises immediately.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: This is preposterous!  I demand an explanation.

lines.speaker: u1139
lines.text: Fine.  This University will no longer continue any funding of any kind for your group's activities.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: But why?  The students love us!

lines.speaker: u1139
lines.text: Dr. Venkman, we believe that the purpose of science is to serve mankind.  You, however, seem to regard science as some kind of "dodge" or "hustle."  Your theories are the worst kind of popular tripe, your methods are sloppy and your conclusions are highly questionable.  You're a poor scientist, Dr. Venkman, and you have no place in this department or in this University.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: I see.

lines.speaker: u1140
lines.text: Well, that definitely looks like marshmallow to me.

lines.speaker: u1147
lines.text: Yeah, it's some kind of mallow-type substance - that's for sure.

lines.speaker: u1140
lines.text: You have to wonder why anybody would dump a marshmallow that size right in the middle of the street.

lines.speaker: u1147
lines.text: I wonder if there might not be a very large cup of hot chocolate somewhere in the area.

lines.speaker: u1140
lines.text: That would definitely explain it.

lines.speaker: u1142
lines.text: Did you see it?  What was it?

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: We'll get back to you.

lines.speaker: u1143
lines.text: And someone from the EPA is here to see you.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: The EPA?  What's he want?

lines.speaker: u1143
lines.text: I didn't ask him.  All I know is that I haven't had a break in two weeks and you promised you'd hire more help.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: Janine, I'm sure a woman with your qualifications would have no trouble finding a top flight job in the housekeeping or food service industry.

lines.speaker: u1143
lines.text: Oh, really?  Well, I've quit better jobs than this one, believe me.

lines.speaker: u1145
lines.text: Thank you for coming so quickly.  The guests are starting to ask questions and I'm running out of excuses.

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: Has this ever happened before?

lines.speaker: u1145
lines.text: Well, most of the original staff knows about the twelfth floor ... The disturbances, I mean ... But it's been quiet for years ... Up until two weeks ago ... It was never ever this bad, though.

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: Did you ever report it to anyone?

lines.speaker: u1145
lines.text: Heavens, no!  The owners don't like us to even talk about it.  I hoped we could take care of this quietly tonight.

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: Yes, sir.  Don't worry.  We handle this kind of thing all the time.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: Mr. Mayor, it's a pretty simple choice. You can believe Mr. Pecker here ...

lines.speaker: u1146
lines.text: That's "Peck!"

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: ... or you can accept the fact that this city is heading for a disaster of really Biblical proportions.

lines.speaker: u1148
lines.text: Hey!  I'm getting a little tired of this.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: You volunteered, didn't you?  Aren't we paying you for this?

lines.speaker: u1148
lines.text: Yeah, but I didn't know you were going to give me electric shocks.  What are you trying to prove?

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: I'm studying the effect of negative reinforcement on ESP ability.

lines.speaker: u1148
lines.text: I'll tell you the effect!  It pisses me off!

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: Then my theory was correct.

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: You mean if I stand here and concentrate on the image of Roberto Clemente, Gozer will appear as Roberto Clemente and wipe us out?

lines.speaker: u1149
lines.text: That appears to be the case.

lines.speaker: u1153
lines.text: What's he talking about?  Choose what?

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: What do you mean "choose?"  We don't understand.

lines.speaker: u1155
lines.text: Tribuus!  Go left here, I want to see my new statue at Via Claudia.

lines.speaker: u1168
lines.text: Yes, Caesar.

lines.speaker: u1155
lines.text: We need more statues -- perhaps I should open medical clinics.  For the poor.  Citizens only, though...

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: It's time for you to tell the Citizens that Commodus stole the money allocated for defending the German border.  It's time to tell the citizens everything.  Will you write it?

lines.speaker: u1156
lines.text: Yes, because I know they'll read it.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: The battle was won, today, and I prefer to believe it was a gift of Janus, the eldest God of Rome.  God of my ancestors.

lines.speaker: u1157
lines.text: God of passages and changes?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I believe we are arriving in an enlightened age; an age of peace that will bring Rome her greatest glory.  Thanks to Marcus Aurelius.

lines.speaker: u1157
lines.text: You know, general, there is a Gate of Janus in Rome which is only closed in time of peace.  Sadly, it has remained open for three hundred years.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I've read of it.

lines.speaker: u1157
lines.text: But have never been?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: My only visits to Rome, Senator, have been through books.  But the war's over, time to close the door of war once and for all.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: The Senate too?

lines.speaker: u1158
lines.text: The moment you returned from the battle your options were clear.  If you are a friend to neither side, legate, you must be an enemy to both.  We needed to know what you believed.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I hope you live to see what I believe...

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: Who are you?  Narcissus The Good?  I have heard of Narcissus Meridas. That's who I hear you are.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: You're hearing about somebody else.

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: How did you get condemned to the arena without a trial?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: When the Senate and the Emperor agree miracles can happen.

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: Would you support the Senate if they would give you a trial?  You'd have to give me your word.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I need to give you my word when yours is worth nothing?

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: You're a citizen and a soldier.  Not a gladiator.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: You don't know how wrong you are.

lines.speaker: u1160
lines.text: Is this Rome?  Are we just going to be executed?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: They can't... if this is Rome...

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Where are they?

lines.speaker: u1161
lines.text: Hidden.  Where my brother cannot place hands on them.  He didn't have the guts to watch them die so... I took care of it all.  The sooner he is put out of our misery, the sooner will they be safe.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: If I'd ever had a sign that you wanted to rule I would have... no, again, it's my own bullheadedness. Narcissus, I should have adopted you years ago.  And now the Gods are begging me to make you my son!

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Commodus is just a young man, he'll learn what you had to learn.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: It's not because he's young, it's because he's ignorant and arrogant. His sister is a better man.  That's why I have undertaken to begin sweeping changes in the relationship between the emperor and the Senate.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: So I understand.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: Everyone talking about it?  I wouldn't wonder.  All I seek is a genuine balance of power between the Emperor and the Senate.  Thus I have transferred legal power -- which was theirs to begin with -- back to the Senators.  This includes a shared right to taxation too but some bite in the plan.  It's a start, only a start.  If the Emperor and the Senate can share power then the people will be ready to take their share.  This means Commodus has to bend; does he strike you as that type?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: You're too hard on him.  He is a strong young man, with you as his guide...

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: A man should be upright, not be kept upright.  History shows us that a good general is quick to recognize opportunities -- even if it means making a complete about face at the last minute.  I want you to consider becoming my heir.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Marcus, you honor me, but I'm a soldier, politics scare the hell out of me.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: The Senators admire you.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: They fear me.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: They fear change.  The new Caesar must be honest enough to know when the emperorship is no longer feasible.  You could be the one, the Emperor, the man who oversees the rebirth of the Republic.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I'll do anything in my power to help you restore the Republic but I can't be that power.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Commodus must hate you.  Free your gladiators and come with us.

lines.speaker: u1164
lines.text: Are you mad?  With all this unrest the Colosseum will be open day and night!  Anyway, I'm not political, I'm in the entertainment business.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: Now look -- please --

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Ben, I think we're two civilized human beings. Do you think it's necessary to threaten each other?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: I am not threatening you.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Do you want to unclench your fists, please? Thank you. I can see in the dark, you know. I've been here quite a while.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: I am trying to tell you I have no personal feelings about you, Mr. Robinson. I am trying to tell you I do not resent you.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: You don't respect me terribly much either, do you?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: No, I don't.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Well, I don't think we have a whole lot to say to each other, Ben. I do think you should know the consequences of what you've done. I do think you should know that my wife and I are getting a divorce soon.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: But why?

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: It shouldn't make any difference what happened.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: That's quite a statement.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: Listen to me. We got -- we got into bed with each other. But it was nothing. It was nothing at all. We might -- we might just as well have been shaking hands.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Shaking hands. Well, that's not saying much for my wife, is it?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: You miss the point.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Don't shout at me, Ben.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: The point is -- I don't love your wife. I love your daughter, sir.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Well -- I'm sure you think you do, Ben, but after a few times in bed with Elaine I feel quite sure you'd get over that as quickly as you --

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: HUH?

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: I think I've talked about this enough. I don't know how far I can go, Ben. I don't know if I can prosecute or not, but I think maybe I can. In the light of what's happened I think maybe I can get you behind bars if you ever look at my daughter again. I have seen Elaine and I have spent the afternoon taking steps to insure...

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: -- before he does --  You're disappointing them, Ben. You're disappointing them.

lines.speaker: u1170
lines.text: Dad -- can you listen --

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: I'll give you ten seconds.  He is going to give us a practical demonstration of what I feel safe in saying is a pretty exciting birthday present -- and it better work or I'm out over two hundred bucks -- so let's hear it for --

lines.speaker: u1177
lines.text: What's happening?

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: Ben says he and Elaine are getting married.

lines.speaker: u1177
lines.text: I don't believe it.

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: That what he says. Right?

lines.speaker: u1183
lines.text: It's a short life and a gay one...

lines.speaker: u1191
lines.text: Every glass high to life -- the splendid, dangerous, mighty, brief -- brief life -- and the courage to live it.  Baron, you know -- I've only lived since last night -- but that little while seems longer than all the time before -- all the --

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Hello! Hello! --

lines.speaker: u1184
lines.text: Don't do that.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: And the child isn't coming?

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: Good heavens. What for?

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.

lines.speaker: u1407
lines.text: So anyway, that's the nightmare I've been having lately.

lines.speaker: u1411
lines.text: Do you suppose it has anything to do with Lila's unusually hairy body?

lines.speaker: u1407
lines.text: No, why?

lines.speaker: u1411
lines.text: Well, it seems that since Lila broached the subject of children, you've been on edge and I know you have an issue with the, uh, body hair.

lines.speaker: u1407
lines.text: Oh, I see. Yes, that's something to think about. That's very good. That's what you get the big bucks, right? Ha ha.

lines.speaker: u1411
lines.text: I just think it might be important to explore your feelings for Lila.

lines.speaker: u1407
lines.text: I love Lila. I mean, she's a wonderful person. And... she loves me! That's no small potatoes. I mean she really loves me. She's sacrificed so much to be in this relationship with me. And she's a good person. A truly good person. How rare is that in this world, eh? And how could I stop loving somebody because of a little physical imperfection, if it can even be called that. I mean, God knows I'm not perfect! What about my eyesight? It's lousy, that's what! Lila's not going to leave me because of my eyesight. What about my penis?

lines.speaker: u1411
lines.text: And how do you feel about Gabrielle?

lines.speaker: u1409
lines.text: It's a pleasure to meet you, mother. But I'm an ape like dad was...  And I have to go back into the woods now... forever.

lines.speaker: u1408
lines.text: Yes, I suppose so. I suppose I knew that was going to be what you would say. It's good to see you again though.

lines.speaker: u1409
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u1408
lines.text: I'm in the book, if you ever want to drop me a line or something.

lines.speaker: u1409
lines.text: I'm an ape, mom. I'm an ape. And apes don't drop lines.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: Huh?

lines.speaker: u1412
lines.text: It's open...  What'll you have?

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: So you figure you're still my manager, huh?

lines.speaker: u1413
lines.text: I'm a businessman, kid.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: Well, you got a lot of games lined up for me?

lines.speaker: u1413
lines.text: Yeah, we're gonna make a lotta money together, from now on.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: Fifty per cent?

lines.speaker: u1413
lines.text: No, it don't have to be fifty. It can be thirty... twenty-five.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: We really stuck the knife in her, didn't we, Bert?

lines.speaker: u1413
lines.text: Aaaahhhh!

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: Boy, we really gave it to her good.

lines.speaker: u1413
lines.text: If it didn't happen in Louisville, it'd happened someplace else. If it didn't happen now, it'd happen six months from now. That's the kinda dame she was.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: And we twisted it, didn't we, Bert? Course, maybe that doesn't stick in your throat cause you spit it out just like you spit out everything else. But it sticks in mine. I loved her, Bert. I traded her in on a pool game. But that wouldn't mean anything to you. Because who did you ever care about? Just win, win, you said, win, that's the important thing. You don't know what winnin' is, Bert. You're a loser. 'Cause you're dead inside, and you can't live unless you make everything else dead around ya.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: You got that wrong, mister. I am.

lines.speaker: u1414
lines.text: Okay, I told you what I wanted about Minnesota Fats. You just go ahead and play him, friend.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: Just tell me where I can find him, friend.

lines.speaker: u1414
lines.text: Comes right in this poolroom every night, eight o'clock on the nose. Just stay where you are. He'll find you.

lines.speaker: u1415
lines.text: Just like that?

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: Yeah. Just like that.

lines.speaker: u1416
lines.text: ...you shoot a great game of pool.

lines.speaker: u1417
lines.text: So do you, Fast Eddie.

lines.speaker: u1422
lines.text: You have to go.  He'll never stop. Leave this place.  Find another.

lines.speaker: u1424
lines.text: I'll go.  We'll both go.  Far away.

lines.speaker: u1423
lines.text: Good evening.  Did you have a pleasant day today?

lines.speaker: u1424
lines.text: Busy.  I went swimming and prepared a new vehicle.  A big vehicle.

lines.speaker: u1423
lines.text: That sounds charming.  Did you meet any interesting people today?

lines.speaker: u1424
lines.text: Yesterday.  They're back.  Haven't seen them for a few months.  I have to be careful.

lines.speaker: u1423
lines.text: Tell me about the interesting people you met, won't you?

lines.speaker: u1424
lines.text: They are... sinister.  They want to kill me.

lines.speaker: u1423
lines.text: That sounds charming.  What are you planning to do tomorrow?

lines.speaker: u1424
lines.text: Stay alive.

lines.speaker: u1424
lines.text: Bathroom?

lines.speaker: u1425
lines.text: Round back.

lines.speaker: u1427
lines.text: What did he talk to you about?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: He was upset with moving, I believe.

lines.speaker: u1427
lines.text: Is that all he said?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Why, yes.  Why?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Hello, this is Ms. Magnuson speaking.

lines.speaker: u1428
lines.text: I understand, Miss, that you have my son in your office.

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Yes, I do, Mr. Gardner.

lines.speaker: u1428
lines.text: May I ask why?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: We were having a little talk.

lines.speaker: u1428
lines.text: About what?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Children often have trouble adjusting to a new school.

lines.speaker: u1428
lines.text: I don't know what he's told you --  What <u>has</u> he told you?  Would you like to tell <u>me</u> -- ?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Mr. Gardner, I --

lines.speaker: u1428
lines.text: You people have a lot of nerve, taking it on yourselves to encourage young children to speak out of turn. I'm of a mind to pull him out of school if this is your idea of how to handle ... What sort of training do you have anyway?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Mr. Gardner, I don't think this is the place to discuss this matter.

lines.speaker: u1428
lines.text: I'm not particularly interested, <u>Ms.</u> Magnuson, in what you think is correct. My wife and I are going away on a business trip this afternoon and we want Jimmy with us.  Keep him in your office until we arrive.

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Of course.

lines.speaker: u1431
lines.text: It's all this moving from place to place.  We're never settled.  I'm having nightmares myself.

lines.speaker: u1429
lines.text: What kind, Mom?

lines.speaker: u1431
lines.text: Oh, I can't remember.  But people do have bad dreams when their routine is disturbed.

lines.speaker: u1432
lines.text: Ms. Magnuson, is Jimmy Gardner with you?

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: Why, yes.

lines.speaker: u1432
lines.text: Jimmy's father is on the phone.  I wonder if you'd take the call.

lines.speaker: u1430
lines.text: All right.  I'll be right back.

lines.speaker: u1433
lines.text: This could be our last night on Earth. I don't want to die a virgin.

lines.speaker: u1446
lines.text: If we do, we'll both die virgins. But at last we'll be together.

lines.speaker: u1434
lines.text: We're losing them.

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: Then get them out of there.

lines.speaker: u1450
lines.text: We're loose!

lines.speaker: u1435
lines.text: Doesn't matter. Game's over.

lines.speaker: u1450
lines.text: I don't hear no fat lady.

lines.speaker: u1436
lines.text: A meteor?

lines.speaker: u1449
lines.text: No Sir. Definitely not.

lines.speaker: u1436
lines.text: How do you know?

lines.speaker: u1449
lines.text: Well, er... it's slowing down.

lines.speaker: u1436
lines.text: It's doing what?

lines.speaker: u1449
lines.text: It's... slowing down, Sir.

lines.speaker: u1437
lines.text: Dylan, come here. I want you to meet the First Lady.

lines.speaker: u1439
lines.text: I thought you didn't recognize me.

lines.speaker: u1437
lines.text: Didn't want to say anything. I voted for the other guy.

lines.speaker: u1438
lines.text: Stevie... I can't...

lines.speaker: u1450
lines.text: Jimmy, stay with me.

lines.speaker: u1441
lines.text: How' he doing?

lines.speaker: u1448
lines.text: Just fell asleep. He's gonna be just fine. Join me in a little celebration?

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: Call them back.

lines.speaker: u1443
lines.text: The other bombers might have more luck. We shouldn't just give up...

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: I said call them back.

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: Can they be killed?

lines.speaker: u1444
lines.text: These three died in the crash. Their bodies are as frail as our own. You just have to get past their technology, which is, I'm sorry to say, far more advanced.

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: Why did you people come here?

lines.speaker: u1445
lines.text: Air... water... your "sun."

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: Where do your people come from?  Where is your home?

lines.speaker: u1445
lines.text: Here... now.

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: And before here?

lines.speaker: u1445
lines.text: Many worlds...

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: Can we negotiate a truce? Is there room for co-existance?  Can there be peace between us?

lines.speaker: u1445
lines.text: Peace? No peace.

lines.speaker: u1447
lines.text: What do you want us to do?

lines.speaker: u1445
lines.text: Die.

lines.speaker: u1454
lines.text: Well, Marcus, we are on the brink of the recovery of the greatest artifact in the history of mankind.

lines.speaker: u1452
lines.text: You're meddling with powers you cannot possibly comprehend.

lines.speaker: u1453
lines.text: Are you expected?

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: Don't take that tone with me, my good man. Now buttle off and tell Baron Brunwald that Lord Clarence MacDonald and his lovely assistant are here to view the tapestries.

lines.speaker: u1453
lines.text: Tapestries?

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: Dear me, the man is dense. This is a castle, isn't it? There are tapestries?

lines.speaker: u1453
lines.text: This is a castle. And we have many tapestries. But if you're a Scottish lord, then I am Mickey Mouse.

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: How dare he?!

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: I'm through!

lines.speaker: u1454
lines.text: We're through!

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: Elsa. Elsa don't. Elsa. Elsa. Give me your other hand, honey. I can't hold you.

lines.speaker: u1455
lines.text: I can reach it. I can reach it...

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: Uh-huh.

lines.speaker: u1456
lines.text: After you, Junior.

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: Yes, sir!  Haaa!

lines.speaker: u1458
lines.text: Ask yourself, why do you seek the Cup of Christ? Is it for His glory, or for yours?

lines.speaker: u1457
lines.text: I didn't come for the Cup of Christ. I came to find my father.

lines.speaker: u1458
lines.text: In that case, God be with you in your quest. Your father is being held in the Castle of Brunwald on the Austrian-German border.

lines.speaker: u1461
lines.text: Who?

lines.speaker: u1468
lines.text: It's some kind of cult! And they've got the sacred stones that Indy was searching for.

lines.speaker: u1462
lines.text: You understand what he tells us?

lines.speaker: u1463
lines.text: Kali Ma protects us now and for ever, and we must pledge our devotion by worshipping her with an offering of flesh and blood!

lines.speaker: u1463
lines.text: The last Sankara Stone.

lines.speaker: u1468
lines.text: And they don't even know what it really is.

lines.speaker: u1463
lines.text: Well, you didn't get your prince, and there goes your diamond.

lines.speaker: u1468
lines.text: You didn't do so well yourself. Finding that stone could've gotten you all the fortune and glory you were talking about.

lines.speaker: u1463
lines.text: It's still a long way to Delhi. Who knows what might happen.

lines.speaker: u1468
lines.text: I don't appreciate being cooked like a french fry!

lines.speaker: u1467
lines.text: Willie, come on!

lines.speaker: u1469
lines.text: I knew you were trouble.

lines.speaker: u1479
lines.text: Trouble...is, if we both get stuck here.

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: How about a deal?

lines.speaker: u1470
lines.text: We'll let you go. You leave the pods and the PEM.

lines.speaker: u1473
lines.text: What Job?

lines.speaker: u1471
lines.text: Doesn't matter. Then put him away.

lines.speaker: u1473
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: u1471
lines.text: Private clinic. Best of care. Total privacy. We'll pay all costs.

lines.speaker: u1473
lines.text: Bit expensive, sir.

lines.speaker: u1471
lines.text: It's the least we can do. After all, it's our responsibility.

lines.speaker: u1472
lines.text: And...you know Jan Gruner?

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: I think I've heard of you.

lines.speaker: u1473
lines.text: Sue who?

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: You...him...UST.

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: Don't do it!

lines.speaker: u1474
lines.text: Just give me the keys.

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: Whatever it is, don't do it.

lines.speaker: u1478
lines.text: Is there anything else?

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: A drink...

lines.speaker: u1478
lines.text: Water fountain's through that door, down the hall.

lines.speaker: u1475
lines.text: Thanks.

lines.speaker: u1476
lines.text: It'l be alright.

lines.speaker: u1481
lines.text: It will.

lines.speaker: u1476
lines.text: It doesn't hurt.

lines.speaker: u1481
lines.text: No?

lines.speaker: u1482
lines.text: It'l take months.

lines.speaker: u1481
lines.text: So we better get started.

lines.speaker: u1482
lines.text: What about Al...

lines.speaker: u1485
lines.text: He's into kind of little cars, that...

lines.speaker: u1497
lines.text: That remote control thing?

lines.speaker: u1485
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u1497
lines.text: Alright, we'll do that tomorrow.

lines.speaker: u1485
lines.text: Mom.

lines.speaker: u1497
lines.text: Yes, baby?

lines.speaker: u1485
lines.text: There's Dad, on TV.

lines.speaker: u1486
lines.text: We'll give you a heads up before we launch.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: How long?

lines.speaker: u1486
lines.text: Three hours.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: You got a deal.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: These are their leads, their sources. I want you to have your reporters...

lines.speaker: u1487
lines.text: Suein Hwang and Milo Geyelin.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Have them make their own calls. They'll find that these sources have a different story than the one that's in the dossier...  Push the deadline, Charlie...

lines.speaker: u1488
lines.text: Yeah. Yeah, sure. I'll see if I can find him. Hold on...  Yeah, Don's looking for you...

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Good.

lines.speaker: u1488
lines.text: The sub-heading is, "Brown & Williamson Has a 500-Page Dossier Attacking Chief Critic." It quotes Richard Scruggs calling it "the worst kind of an organized smear campaign against a whistle-blower."

lines.speaker: u1489
lines.text: What are you cooking?

lines.speaker: u1497
lines.text: I'm cooking pasta primavera.

lines.speaker: u1489
lines.text: Oh, I love that stuff.

lines.speaker: u1490
lines.text: The New York Times ran a blow by blow of what we talked about behind closed doors! You fucked us!

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: No, you fucked you! Don't invert stuff! Big Tobacco tried to smear Wigand; you bought it. The Wall Street Journal, here, not exactly a bastion of anti-capitalist sentiment, refutes Big Tobacco's smear campaign as the lowest form of character assassination! And now, even now, when every word of what Wigand has said on our show is printed, the entire deposition of his testimony in a court of law in the State of Mississippi, the cat totally out of the bag, you're still standing here debating! Don, what the hell else... do you need?

lines.speaker: u1491
lines.text: And what are you implying?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: I'm not implying. I'm quoting. More vested interests...  "Persons Who Will Profit From This Merger...  Ms. Helen Caperelli, General Counsel of CBS News, 3.9 million. Mr. Eric Kluster, President of CBS News, 1.4 million..."

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: That computer has everything...

lines.speaker: u1492
lines.text: You alright, Mr. Wigand?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Oh, Bill... Main Justice is investigating a major New York bank. Laundering narco dollars out of their Mexico City branch. You want it for the Evening News?

lines.speaker: u1493
lines.text: What about you, you got a crew already?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: I'm gonna do a follow-up.

lines.speaker: u1493
lines.text: Okay.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Catch ya' later.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Is CBS corporate telling CBS News do not go to air with this story?

lines.speaker: u1494
lines.text: You're getting ahead of yourself. We're all in this together. We're all CBS. We'll find out soon. Thank you, gentlemen.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: How prominent? What kind of placement?

lines.speaker: u1495
lines.text: Oh, c'mon, Lowell. This is The New York Times. I don't know...

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Well, until you do, all I can tell you is what you already know... they will not air an interview.

lines.speaker: u1495
lines.text: Call me back in ten.

lines.speaker: u1496
lines.text: Lowell?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Did I tell you you were wrong?

lines.speaker: u1496
lines.text: No.  I'm assuming the cave-in begins with the threat of litigation from Big Tobacco. Are we talking... are we talking Brown & Williamson, here?

lines.speaker: u1497
lines.text: I don't think I can do this... I want to stand by my husband... I really do, Jeffrey. But I don't think I can do this anymore. I am so sorry...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: Can we talk about this when I get back?

lines.speaker: u1497
lines.text: Yes... Jeffrey.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Thank you, Bob.

lines.speaker: u1498
lines.text: Who's calling?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: My name's Lowell Bergman... I'm --

lines.speaker: u1498
lines.text: Did you say Berman?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: No, Bergman... B.E.R.G.M.A.N.... I'm a producer with "60 Minutes"...

lines.speaker: u1498
lines.text: "60 Minutes"?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u1498
lines.text: "60 Minutes," the television show?

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: What's happening?!

lines.speaker: u1506
lines.text: He doesn't seem to be listening...

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: Alright, now listen to me. I want you -- I want you to tell him, in these words: get on the fucking phone...!

lines.speaker: u1506
lines.text: I can't say that!

lines.speaker: u1499
lines.text: No, you can.  Tell him to get on the fucking phone!

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: And, so, I moved out... I see the girls a couple of days a week...

lines.speaker: u1500
lines.text: Where you staying now?

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: Our favorite hotel, honey... I checked into Room 930. Odd choice? Huh?

lines.speaker: u1504
lines.text: Jeff Wigand, Michael Moore.

lines.speaker: u1501
lines.text: Good to meet you, Dr. Wigand.

lines.speaker: u1504
lines.text: Mike's our Attorney General down here.  I was just explaining to Jeff, they got a Kentucky court to issue a gag order to stop his deposition today.

lines.speaker: u1501
lines.text: Right.

lines.speaker: u1504
lines.text: Now, they tried to get the Mississippi Court to honor it, but the judge threw it out...  However, for you, there is a more perilous effect to the Kentucky gag order...

lines.speaker: u1501
lines.text: Dr. Wigand, you do understand what could happen, don't you?

lines.speaker: u1502
lines.text: "You wish you hadn't blown the whistle?"

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: "There are times... I wish I hadn't done it. But there are times that I feel compelled to do it..." "I've -- if you asked me if I would do it again or if it's -- do I think it's worth it. Yeah. I think it's worth it."

lines.speaker: u1509
lines.text: Object to the form of the question!

lines.speaker: u1503
lines.text: It acts as a drug on the body?

lines.speaker: u1509
lines.text: Object to the form!

lines.speaker: u1503
lines.text: It acts as a...

lines.speaker: u1509
lines.text: Object!

lines.speaker: u1503
lines.text: There an echo in here? Your objection's been recorded. She typed it into her little machine over there. It's on the record. So now I'll proceed with my deposition of my witness. Does it act as a drug?

lines.speaker: u1509
lines.text: Dr. Wigand. I am instructing you...  ...not to answer that question in accordance to the terms of the contractual obligations undertaken by you not to disclose any information about your work at the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company. And in accordance with the force and effect of the temporary restraining order that has been entered against you to by the court in the State of Kentucky! That means you don't talk!  Mr. Motley, we have rights, here...

lines.speaker: u1503
lines.text: Oh, you got rights and lefts! Ups and downs and middles! So what?! You don't get to instruct anything around here! This is not North Carolina, not South Carolina nor Kentucky. This is the sovereign State of Mississippi's proceeding. Wipe that smirk off your face! Dr. Wigand's deposition will be part of this record. And I'm going to take my witness' testimony! Whether the hell you like it or not!  Answer the question, Dr...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: Jail?

lines.speaker: u1504
lines.text: Possibly, yes. That is one of the possible consequences of your testifying here today. That's right...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: How does one... "go... to... jail?" What does my family do? Go on welfare? If my wife has to work? Who's going to look after the kids? Put food on the table? My children need me. If I'm not teaching... there's no medical... no medical... even on co- pay, that's like... Tuition...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: Is that a threat?

lines.speaker: u1508
lines.text: ...we worked together for, what was it, three years...? Now, the work we did here is confidential, not for public scrutiny... any more than are one's family matters...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: You threatening my family, now, too?

lines.speaker: u1508
lines.text: Now, don't be paranoid, Jeff.  About the direction of research here, we may have had our differences of opinion...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: "Research..."  You declare, as a badge of honor, you don't even know what makes water boil...

lines.speaker: u1508
lines.text: That's why we hire scientists...

lines.speaker: u1510
lines.text: Okay.  I don't believe you can maintain corporate integrity without confidentiality agreements. I was paid well for my work. The health and welfare benefits are good. The severance package is fair. I have no intention of violating my confidentiality agreement and disclosing that which I said I wouldn't.

lines.speaker: u1508
lines.text: I appreciate all that, Jeff. But, upon reflection... we've decided to expand our zone of comfort with you.

lines.speaker: u1520
lines.text: Yes. Your husband did show remarkable foresight in taking those pictures. And, yes, absent a swimming pool, the presence of the pool man would appear to be suspicious. But Bonnie, who is the real victim here? Let me suggest the following. Your husband, who on a prior occasion slapped you -- beat you --

lines.speaker: u1512
lines.text: Well, I wouldn't say --

lines.speaker: u1520
lines.text: Your husband, who has beaten you -- repeatedly --

lines.speaker: u1512
lines.text: He --

lines.speaker: u1520
lines.text: Please -- was at the time brandishing your firearm, trying in his rage to shoot an acquaintance -- friend of long standing --

lines.speaker: u1512
lines.text: They hate each other --

lines.speaker: u1520
lines.text: So he says now! But if not for your cool headed intervention, his tantrum might have ended this schmoe's life and ruined his own... As for the sexual indiscretion which he imagined had taken place, wasn't it in fact he who had been sleeping with the pool man?

lines.speaker: u1520

lines.speaker: u2100
lines.text: They told me you wanted to talk about this Shane business.

lines.speaker: u2101
lines.text: You havin' any luck findin' out who did him?

lines.speaker: u2100
lines.text: Shane was a friend of yours?

lines.speaker: u2101
lines.text: He was around...

lines.speaker: u2100
lines.text: Lad, I'm a busy man. July's always a big month for murder. Fella named Barone turned up just this mornin', throat cut ear to ear.  Black Hand.

lines.speaker: u2101
lines.text: When you're investigatin', how long ya keep at it?

lines.speaker: u2100
lines.text: It consoles the bereaved family ta see the perpetrator take his load of juice. We try to oblige.

lines.speaker: u2101
lines.text: But if ya can't catch the guys...

lines.speaker: u2101
lines.text: I'm sorry, but I sleep better when I know I'm with the winning side.

lines.speaker: u2104
lines.text: We're gonna be the winning side. It's like Rothstein said about that guy in Austria. We're gonna use Maranzano and Masseria. Let 'em knock each other bloody. And then, when everybody's screamin' for peace, we step in to make it. What they're fight in' over, everybody will beg us to take.

lines.speaker: u2101
lines.text: I thought we just wanted to be left alone to run our business.

lines.speaker: u2102
lines.text: I'm gonna lose you, Charlie.

lines.speaker: u2105
lines.text: It'll all be over tomorrow. No more wars. No more killin'. Just livin' normal like everybody else.  You'll be stuck with me for good.

lines.speaker: u2103
lines.text: Julius Caesar never took no vote.

lines.speaker: u2105
lines.text: And maybe that's why he ended up dead in the streets of Rome.

lines.speaker: u2104
lines.text: We're gonna change it, Bugs. Once we get rid of the Dons, the Commission's gonna rule. No more wars. No more vendettas. No more Boss of All the Bosses.

lines.speaker: u2112
lines.text: Yeah. And no more Tommy Reina.

lines.speaker: u2112
lines.text: I'm a hard guy. I done more jobs than alla you combined. And I never said no. Not once. But dammit I don't understand why the hell we gotta kill our friends!

lines.speaker: u2105
lines.text: Because the world ain't big enough for the Dons. So we gotta choose between our friends and ourselves. It ain't the way I'd make the world, but that's the way it is.

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: What a cozy little scene.

lines.speaker: u2108
lines.text: Kill them! Kill them!

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: What's it worth to ya, Boss?

lines.speaker: u2108
lines.text: Anything!

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: Anything ain't a very hard number.

lines.speaker: u2108
lines.text: One hundred thousand. No... three hundred thousand.

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: Now that's a hard number.

lines.speaker: u2110
lines.text: You're fuckin' crazy.

lines.speaker: u2112
lines.text: But only on purpose, Tommy.

lines.speaker: u2110
lines.text: This is nice. I mean it.

lines.speaker: u2120
lines.text: "4/17: Subject, when unaware of observation, prefers to hold eating utensils...with feet. Successfully carves turkey roll holding eating utensils...with feet."

lines.speaker: u2113
lines.text: They had a case like that at Johns Hopkins. Wires got crossed between hands and feet.

lines.speaker: u2114
lines.text: Hey, Stu, why so glum? Everybody loves a good humiliation nightmare.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Three months, Bull. Three months tonight. Three months since the accident - and I'm no closer to going home than I was then.

lines.speaker: u2114
lines.text: Aw, buck up. Have another 'tini.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: I'm sick of martinis. I'm sick of the waiting, and the carnival rides, and watching people's <u>nightmares</u>. And of course, I need not <u>add</u> -

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Hey. Where's Monkeybone?

lines.speaker: u2115
lines.text: Back in your head, where he belongs. No offense, Stu, but on your own you're kinda vanilla. I didn't want to send you back without him.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Back? You're sending me back?

lines.speaker: u2115
lines.text: It's irregular, but...I just love that strip of yours. I figure I'll take the "Family Circus" guy instead.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Death! Thank you!

lines.speaker: u2115
lines.text: Thank me next time you see me.

lines.speaker: u2116
lines.text: Three months. There's always some brain damage. But at three months...the chances of coming back shrink dramatically with every day.

lines.speaker: u2121
lines.text: I want him to have every chance, Doctor. We can certainly give it...three months.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: So here's my idea. We do a giveaway at the zoo benefit. We get a big piata. We fill it with Monkeybone dolls - <u>hundreds</u> of 'em.

lines.speaker: u2117
lines.text: A piata. That's a <u>great</u> idea!

lines.speaker: u2118
lines.text: The Nightmare Juice! It's gone! Somebody switched it for a beaker of grape Kool-Aid!!

lines.speaker: u2120
lines.text: Kool-Aid!? But who'd would want to -

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: Easy, pal! I was coming to congratulate you. It ain't easy snatching one of those E-tickets. Steve here was the last guy to pull it off, and that musta been, what, 25 years ago...?

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Why'd you do it? What'd I ever do to you?!?

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: It's simple, Stu. We need nightmares - lots of 'em. So whenever we can swing it, we send a guy up to stimulate the flow...a <u>nightmare maker</u>! Like Steve here. Poe. Rasputin...we've been doing this all the way back to Atilla and Genghis Khan!

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: But <u>why me</u>? Why'd you pick on <u>me</u>??

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: The monkey, of course. It was his idea.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Monkeybone...!?

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: Nobody wants to be a sidekick, Stu. So one day he comes to us - he's got a proposition. We help him get your body...in return he gives us all the nightmares we want.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: You're nuts! I'm a comic strip artist! What's he gonna do - draw <u>really scary cartoons</u>??

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: Oh, no, no, no. Y'see, Stu, as it happens, that girlfriend of yours figured out the chemical basis of bad dreams. And she just whipped up a big old batch of nightmare juice!

lines.speaker: u2120
lines.text: Kimmy! What's the matter?

lines.speaker: u2121
lines.text: This is hard for me, Julie...very hard...but it's been three months now, and... I gave the order.

lines.speaker: u2122
lines.text: Go. Just <u>go</u>.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Thanks, Kitty, I'll never forget you for th--

lines.speaker: u2123
lines.text: Awwww. Worried about my feelings, are you? Well, there's a new twist.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Don't joke around, little buddy. I mean it. I really do love y--

lines.speaker: u2126
lines.text: Is there something else I can do for you?

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: Well, I'd love to see inside your club.

lines.speaker: u2126
lines.text: You want to come inside?

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: Well, if you're not holding a meeting or anything.

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: I see.  How much?

lines.speaker: u2129
lines.text: Forty-five all total.

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: Forty-five?  I thought it was only supposed to be thirty?

lines.speaker: u2129
lines.text: Thirty is base price.  Tolls, tax, tip ... it all adds up.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Here you are, Senator. Not a bad desk, either. Daniel Webster used to use it.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Daniel Webster? Sat here? Say--that man was a great orator.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Give you something to shoot at, Senator--if you figure on doing any talking.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Not me, sonny. I'm just going to sit around and listen.  What's this?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Calendar for the day. You'll find the Senate Manual in the drawer. Anything else you want, just snap for a page.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Where's the Majority Leader?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: The Majority Leader? Right over there. And that's [           ] the Minority Leader. They're both pretty good in the clinches.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Uh-huh. And where's the Press Galery?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Right up there over the Vice- President's chair--the four in the front row represent the four big news services. You've met the press bunch, haven't you?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Oh, yes--they're fine people--regular people.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Look out for those fellows--they tell the truth about you--sometimes. That corner over there is reserved for guides and sightseers who come in for five minutes to rest their feet. That section over there is reserved for Senator's friends. The front row--the empty one--is for the President and White House guests-- see that old couple over there-- they've attended every session for the last twenty years. Over the clock back here is the Diplomatic section. They and the page boys are the only real class we have in this place. The rest are mostly people who come here like they go to the zoo--

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Those busts up there--all around the wall--who are they, sonny?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: All the ex-vice-Presidents. You can get ten-to-one around here if you think you can remember their names. The Vice-President presides over the Senate--you know that. It's how he earns his pay. Oh--over there, Senator-- on the east side of the Chair we still have the old snuff boxes with real snuff in them if you like snuff.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Thanks very much, sonny--

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: I'll take your hat into the cloak room.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Here--let me give you a Boy Ranger button.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Swell. Thanks very much.  Good luck, Senator. Keep your left up.

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: And you say you never signed this contract with Mr. Allen?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: I did not--

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: You've never *seen* this contract.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Never.

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: But you did *talk* to Mr. Allen about that and--?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: I--I discussed it with him--yes-- because I--you see, I've always had this camp in mind--but I made no contract with him!

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: Then--this is *not* you signature, Senator?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Looks like it, but--

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: But it *isn't*?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: It couldn't be.

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: You are saying, in effect, that this is a forgery?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: I'm saying I didn't sign it!

lines.speaker: u2141
lines.text: And while you're at it, get me a bed!

lines.speaker: u2133
lines.text: Let's send out a pigeon!

lines.speaker: u2141
lines.text: Blow a bugle!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Diz!

lines.speaker: u2134
lines.text: Kid--he thinks he's talking to that mob at home, but not a line we've written--not a word he's said from that floor has gotten into that home State.

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: What!

lines.speaker: u2134
lines.text: Not a word! Taylor's sewed up every paper. They're tossing out everything that comes in over the wires!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Freedom of the press! Mr. James Taylor blindfolding a whole State--  Wait a minute! If that's how he wants to play *I'll* get through to that bunch--I'll get plenty of words into that, State--!  Come on, Diz, get that stuff you've written--let me have it--

lines.speaker: u2137
lines.text: Emma! I'm a man at the end of his rope.

lines.speaker: u2135
lines.text: No wonder--without your dinner.

lines.speaker: u2137
lines.text: Emma, which is it--Horace Miller or Henry Hill?

lines.speaker: u2135
lines.text: Well, your children are very bright-- and *they* say Jefferson Smith.

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Are you ready for him, Bill?

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: All set. Foley's rooms in the Senate office building--nice, big clean desk--lot of Senator stationery to write his little boys on--and Foley's secretary, Saunders, to make it look like the real thing--

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Good. Are the newspaper men at the hotel?

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: Yup--Sweeney, Flood, Farrell--waiting for you--

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Fine. The first thing to do is-- present Mr. Smith to the press--in the *right* way. Hurry him along, Bill.

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: How do you feel, champ?

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: All right, why?

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: Your name's spreading like wild-fire out here--you are the winterbook favorite to get on the National ticket.

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Oh! Go away.

lines.speaker: u2139
lines.text: When Jeff gets through with Taylor, Pop--

lines.speaker: u2137
lines.text: When Jeff gets through with Taylor--  Quiet! What do you mean by breaking in here--? Get out! Get *out* of here!

lines.speaker: u2142
lines.text: Yeah! How about it? You're a nature lover. Do you handle any of that sign language?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Well--I can *manage*--

lines.speaker: u2141
lines.text: Your Ranger's on the garbage pile, Happy! He's done for!

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Shut up! You've *got* the man pilloried! Do you have to dance around him like a cannibal--!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Look, Nosey--your pals would like to get in on this, wouldn't they?

lines.speaker: u2142
lines.text: Hey--I wanna *scoop*!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Well, that's out. Either it's *lots* of reporters and *lots* of tickets or--. Now will you go and call 'em before I change my mind about the whole thing!

lines.speaker: u2142
lines.text: Okay. See you here.

lines.speaker: u2146
lines.text: Is there objection?  You may proceed, Senator.

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Page boys!

lines.speaker: u2153
lines.text: Put that away, slug!  At your service!

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: I got a trunk in that room. Will you get it out for me?

lines.speaker: u2153
lines.text: Certainly.

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: We'd like to get in touch with him. It's very important.

lines.speaker: u2154
lines.text: Who's that?

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: Deeds! Who do you think I'm talking about?

lines.speaker: u2154
lines.text: Oh, yes - Deeds. Fine fellow. Very democratic. You won't have no trouble at all. Talk to anybody.

lines.speaker: u2171
lines.text: He's still pixilated.

lines.speaker: u2155
lines.text: He sure is.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Are you married?

lines.speaker: u2156
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Any children?

lines.speaker: u2156
lines.text: No, no children.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: All right, Mr. Dodsworth. I think you'll qualify.  Take this to that desk over there for further instructions.

lines.speaker: u2156
lines.text: Thank you very much.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Next, please.

lines.speaker: u2176
lines.text: It's for you. In a couple weeks you'll get the itch so bad, you'll be working for nothing.

lines.speaker: u2157
lines.text: Hello . . .

lines.speaker: u2168
lines.text: Ow! My foot's asleep!

lines.speaker: u2158
lines.text: Come on - let's go!

lines.speaker: u2159
lines.text: don't want to be critical, John, but here it is

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: Yes, I know. A week's gone by and we haven't got the Power of Attorney yet!

lines.speaker: u2159
lines.text: Yes, but you said

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: I don't care what I said. I can't strangle him, can I!

lines.speaker: u2160
lines.text: How is this, sir?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Perfect! Perfect!

lines.speaker: u2160
lines.text: I wish you luck, sir.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Thank you. Now don't touch a thing. Leave everything as it is.

lines.speaker: u2161
lines.text: You can't come up here!

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: Let me go! I wanna see him!

lines.speaker: u2161
lines.text: He's not home, I tell you!

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: I wanna see that guy!

lines.speaker: u2161
lines.text: We'll send for the police!

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: Let me go!

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: Come in, please. Come in. Can I get you a cup of tea?

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: No, thanks.

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: Sit down. Sure I couldn't get you a glass of lemonade or something?

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: That's very kind of you. Are you related to him?

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: No, I'm his housekeeper.

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: Well, we'd like to find out something about him. What does he do for a living?

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: He and Jim Mason own the Tallow Works. But that's not where he makes his money. He makes most of it from his poetry.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Cobb! Get lunch for the rest of them.

lines.speaker: u2163
lines.text: What? There must be 2000 of them out there.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Well, that doesn't make 'em any less hungry.

lines.speaker: u2163
lines.text: Okay, Santa Claus. 2000 lunches.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Now, where were we?

lines.speaker: u2164
lines.text: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not conducted like any ordinary business.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Why not?

lines.speaker: u2164
lines.text: Because it just isn't a business, that's all!

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Well, maybe it isn't to you, but it certainly is a business to me, if I have to make up a loss of $180,000. If it's losing that much money, there must be something wrong. Maybe you charge too much. Maybe you're selling bad merchandise. Maybe lots of things. I don't know. You see, I expect to do a lot of good with that money. And I can't afford to put it into anything that I don't look into. That's my decision for the time being, gentlemen. Goodbye, and thank you for making me Chairman.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: You remember, Dr. Fosdick, in my last book there are some very fine examples.

lines.speaker: u2165
lines.text: Uh-huh.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: Especially, the one of the young nobleman, you remember?

lines.speaker: u2165
lines.text: Oh, yes. Yes, of course Dr. Von Holler. Very interesting.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: It reminds me very much of this one. Nicht wahr?

lines.speaker: u2165
lines.text: Ja.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: It takes so long to detect them  because their mood changes so often and so quickly. Now, Your Honor, may I show you? May I use the chart?

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: my wife wanted me to tell you she  she prays for you every night.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Well, thanks, I - uh  How do you do? What is your name?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: There's one nice thing about being rich - you ring a bell and things happen. When the servant comes in, Mr. Hallor, I'm going to ask him to show you to the door. Many people don't know where it is.

lines.speaker: u2169
lines.text: No use in getting tough. That'll get you nowhere, Mr. Deeds.  You know, we've got letters.

lines.speaker: u2170
lines.text: Look, he's temperamental.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Yeah, what if I am? What about it?

lines.speaker: u2172
lines.text: Anything else, Mr. Deeds?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: No.  Yes. There's just one more thing I'd like to get off my chest before I finish.

lines.speaker: u2172
lines.text: Proceed.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

lines.speaker: u2183
lines.text: Shall I call the police, sir?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: No!  What do you want!!

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: You can go out there if you like...

lines.speaker: u2184
lines.text: "There's no shame in getting a little therapy", right, Doc?

lines.speaker: u2185
lines.text: Her friend from the city came and took her out to dinner. First time in a long time she's been willing.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: A friend?

lines.speaker: u2186
lines.text: Better make yourself comfortable. We got a three hour drive here.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I'm fine.

lines.speaker: u2186
lines.text: You're the shrink, aren't you?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: No, not really.

lines.speaker: u2186
lines.text: But you do therapy?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Not any more.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I see.

lines.speaker: u2187
lines.text: And please, for whatever small way I may have encouraged this, accept my apologies.  There is good news, though.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: u2187
lines.text: Phyllis has decided to leave town and pursue her practice in the city. Which leaves you the only psychologist in town.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Dr. Sheeler is leaving Mumford? I'm sorry to hear that.

lines.speaker: u2187
lines.text: As you can imagine, my own feelings about this are mixed... Unlike, I must say, those of my wife.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I feel like we're making real progress here.

lines.speaker: u2188
lines.text: Me too, Doc. And I can't tell you what that package meant to me --

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: What brought this on?

lines.speaker: u2189
lines.text: I'm not at liberty to say. Sometimes it's just routine, sometimes there's been a complaint. We'll be in touch.

lines.speaker: u2190
lines.text: You're the doctor, what do you think?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: She seems very unhappy.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: Mr. White, I am frustrated that the criminal code in this state allows a maximum sentence of only six months and a maximum fine of only $2000.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I'm sorry, your honor.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I'm sorry you're frustrated.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: Are you disrespecting this court, Mr. White?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: No, sir. I was empathizing. Sorry.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: Maybe you can empathize with this -- Maximum fine. Three months in jail, three months house arrest. Sentence to begin immediately at the Orchard Valley Correctional Facility. Case closed. This court is adjourned.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: What it might take is... doing time.

lines.speaker: u2192
lines.text: Too bad. That's tough, I mean it. I'm not unsympathetic. But Skip says you're in love.

lines.speaker: u2193
lines.text: It's a country club. Don't worry about it.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Thanks for your help, Lionel.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: How are you?

lines.speaker: u2194
lines.text: Insane! Didn't ja hear? My family got five hundred times better.  Let's go, Vanessa.

lines.speaker: u2195
lines.text: Sofie. It's so obvious... you're after my daughter.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Well, I gotta say, Mrs. Cook, you're right about that.

lines.speaker: u2198
lines.text: Yes... your particular approach.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I don't have one really. Most of the time I'm faking it. See, I think there's not much that can be done about most problems... they're too complicated, too deep-rooted by the time I hear about them. The most I can do, usually, is look and listen real closely, try to catch some glimpse of the secret life everybody's got. If I can get a sense of that, well then, maybe... just maybe, I can help them out a little.

lines.speaker: u2201
lines.text: If he arrives before us, it will be too late.

lines.speaker: u2208
lines.text: Did you say 'kill' my sister?

lines.speaker: u2202
lines.text: ...and how do you say? Those slimy things, in your stomach?

lines.speaker: u2205
lines.text: Intestines.

lines.speaker: u2202
lines.text: Yeah! Them.

lines.speaker: u2203
lines.text: Which would be located not far to the east of the Anubis statue.

lines.speaker: u2209
lines.text: Don't tell me we gotta go back out there?

lines.speaker: u2203
lines.text: If we want to kill the creature, yes.

lines.speaker: u2204
lines.text: The hell with this. I'm goin, downstairs to get me a drink. You want somethin'?

lines.speaker: u2206
lines.text: Yeah, get me a glass of bourbon, a shot of bourbon and a bourbon chaser.

lines.speaker: u2205
lines.text: Ah! Ah! Ahmenophus!

lines.speaker: u2208
lines.text: Yes,... I see.

lines.speaker: u2209
lines.text: Do something, Jonathan! Kill it!

lines.speaker: u2208
lines.text: You have got to be joking?

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: And I know the terrible revenge that you plan to inflict on this city.

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: I guess you know just about everything, don't you, Lance?

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: Um-hmm.

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: Except for one little thing.

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: And what's that?

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: That I've hot wired the city's entire power supply through that catwalk.

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: What --?

lines.speaker: u2212
lines.text: You two timing psychotic bastard.

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: Darling, you've got the wrong idea.

lines.speaker: u2212
lines.text: Do I?

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: I was only strangling her... I've killed hundreds of women. It doesn't mean a thing.  Pootchkie, you're over-reacting. This is our night. It's what we've lied for... cheated for... murdered for. She's just a plaything, a trifle... You're the only woman who's ever meant anything to me. I adore you. I worship you. I want to make you my bride.

lines.speaker: u2216
lines.text: He'll never make it.

lines.speaker: u2213
lines.text: Think positive.

lines.speaker: u2218
lines.text: Stay away!

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: Or you'll what? CAN ME?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: He's turned into a completely normal person!

lines.speaker: u2215
lines.text: Normal. What's normal? Does normal exist? And if it did, how would we know it?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Yes, Obie-wan.

lines.speaker: u2217
lines.text: Hey... he's gone.

lines.speaker: u2218
lines.text: Here you go.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Ow.

lines.speaker: u2218
lines.text: Maybe you guys ought to forget this Superhero stuff and join Kiwanis or something.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Oh, Mother, I'm sorry. I know how much you wanted me to be a doctor or a lawyer with a family -- but it's just not who I am!

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: But... the silverware?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: I use it... to fight evil.

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: Jeffrey... this is wonderful.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: It is?

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: I always knew that you were special.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: You did?

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: Ever since you were a little boy...  Come with me.

lines.speaker: u2221
lines.text: Where am I going?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Through there!

lines.speaker: u2221
lines.text: Right.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You can always tell at a glance whether retreating infantry are being pursed by cavalry, because they hurry along and keep turning around and looking back.  When they are retreating before infantry, they merely trudge along, head down.

lines.speaker: u2224
lines.text: Fascinating!  Tell me, leaving aside the question of grand strategy, for the moment, what would you say is the single most difficult tactical skill to master?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Without a doubt, to estimate the enemy's strength on the battlefield. This is something that is only acquired by experience and instinct. At Jena, there were as many opinions about strength of the enemy as there were generals present.  Murat said there were 50,000, preparing to attack.  Berthier said there were no more than 25,000, about to withdraw. "Berthier sees only what is in the open," Murat said.  "But don't forget there is a second force hidden in the forest."  And so it would always go, each of them would judge things according to his own ability, character and state of mind, at the moment.

lines.speaker: u2224
lines.text: Ah, my dear Napoleon, sometimes I feel that I am not really an Emperor as you are.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: u2224
lines.text: I know absolutely nothing of war -- and I am still totally dependent upon my generals.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: I don't have to tell you of our latest difficulties.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Things are quite serious, I should say.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: We expect an attack on the Convention tomorrow morning, at daybreak, and I have been placed in charge of its defense.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What do you have in mind?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: To be perfectly honest, I haven't the vaguest idea.

lines.speaker: u2244
