lines.text: Are you serious?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: I don't even know whether a defense is possible.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What forces do you have at your disposal?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: About 5,000 troops.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Cavalry?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: The 21st Dragoons, about two or three-hundred troopers.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Any cannon?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: There are none here.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Where are they?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Well, I believe there are at least 30 guns at Sablons.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You could have them here by daybreak.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Is this enough to oppose 40,000 men?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Properly arranged, yes.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: These are odds of 8 to 1.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: The numbers are not particularly relevant.  You are not up against soldiers -- this is a mob, and they will run as soon as things become sufficiently unpleasant.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Would you be prepared to handle this for me?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Are you proposing to transfer command to me?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: In every practical sense, yes, but, officially, of course, I would have to retain command.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Fair enough.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: I must be honest with you.  I first approached three generals more senior than yourself, and they all very prudently sent excuses.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I'm not insulted.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: You realize what is at stake?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Our lives, the revolution, my career?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Look, let me be completely open with you, I have a carriage and an escort waiting for me, and I have a great deal of money outside of France. Unless we stand a very good chance of carrying this off, I am prepared to call it quits right now.

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: But, sire, Your Majesty would lay Paris open to being sacked.  The enemy is outside the gates with more than 120,000 men.  Besides this, I left the city under the terms of a treaty and I am forbidden to reenter Paris.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: A treaty?  Don't be ridiculous. What treaty is this?  Who made it? Who has been giving orders?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I don't know the details of the treaty, sire, Marshal Mortier sent me word of its having been agreed to, and he said that I was to take the army and make for Fontainebleau.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: But who made this treaty?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I believe it was arranged by Marshals Mortier and Marmont.  I must explain to you that we have had no orders all day.  Each marshal has been keeping his own position.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Who sent my wife and son out of Paris?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I don't know, sire.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: And where is Joseph?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I don't know what has happened to Prince Joseph.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What cowardice!  What treason! Joseph has ruined everything.  How could they all lose their heads. They knew I was coming up fast. Victory was just within grasp. Come, come, turn your troops around, General Belliard.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Who is there?

lines.speaker: u2227
lines.text: Bertrand, sire.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I have just had the most vivid... dream... about Josephine.

lines.speaker: u2227
lines.text: Yes, sire?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: She was sitting there... and it was as if I had last seen her only the night before... She hadn't changed -- she was still the same -- still completely devoted to me... and she told me we were going to see each other again and, never again, leave each other... She has promised me. Did you see her?

lines.speaker: u2227
lines.text: No, sire... I was asleep.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I wanted to kiss her, but she didn't want to kiss me... She slipped away, the moment I wanted to take her in my arms.

lines.speaker: u2228
lines.text: This dispatch has just arrived from Aboukir, marked highest priority, for General Bonaparte's eyes only.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Let me see it.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Then, you have my thanks, Captain Charles, for safely escorting Madame Bonaparte to Milan, and you may consider your assignment completed.

lines.speaker: u2230
lines.text: Thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You will return to Paris tomorrow and you will carry my compliments and thanks to General Le Clerc for assigning such an excellent officer to carry out a responsibility which has meant so much to myself and to Madame Bonaparte.

lines.speaker: u2230
lines.text: Thank you, sir.  I will do that.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You may go, Captain Charles.

lines.speaker: u2231
lines.text: Just a minute, General.  Listen, don't let them fool you with all their grand la-de-da.  They've all made their money from the war -- mostly from crooked war contracts. They say Citizen Barras has put away millions.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I see...

lines.speaker: u2232
lines.text: Hello there, Picart.

lines.speaker: u2247
lines.text: Ah, Didier -- you are alive.

lines.speaker: u2232
lines.text: Why are you carrying the dog?

lines.speaker: u2247
lines.text: His paws are frozen and he cannot walk.

lines.speaker: u2232
lines.text: When you eat him, may I have some?

lines.speaker: u2247
lines.text: My God -- don't you recognize Mouton -- our regimental dog?  I would rather eat Cossack.

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: The Emperor has decided to marry your Archduchess, Marie-Louise.

lines.speaker: u2249
lines.text: What is that?

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: Earlier this afternoon, the Emperor refused the hand of the Grand Duchess Anna, of Russia, and, as I'm sure you can appreciate, he is quite able to change his mind again.  For the Emperor, to choose a wife, is only a matter of minutes.

lines.speaker: u2249
lines.text: But this is not a matter which can be settled tonight, surely?

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: No one can say how the Emperor's thoughts work, Ambassador, and unless we move quickly, he might change his mind again.

lines.speaker: u2249
lines.text: But, my dear Duroc, how can I act without guidance from Vienna?  I haven't the slightest idea of how the Emperor Francis might feel about this.

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: May I suggest that we can prepare and sign the agreement, between ourselves, subject to the approval of the two Emperors.  Believe me, my dear friend, your Archduchess, Marie-Louis, may very well hold, in her hands, the future of our two countries.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Good morning, Citizen de Beauharnais.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: Good morning, sir.  Are you General Bonaparte?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I am, Citizen.  Is your mother Madame Josephine de Beauharnais?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: Yes, sir.  Are you acquainted with her?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I have met her.  What is your business with me?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: I believe you issued an order that all citizens of Paris must hand over any weapons that they have in their possession.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: That is correct.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: This morning, a Lieutenant and three soldiers came to our house and asked if we had weapons.  I explained we had only my late father's sword, which, in fact, was not a weapon but only a keepsake of memory.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: A sword is a weapon whatever else you might wish to use it for.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: I told the Lieutenant my late father was General Alexander de Beauharnais, and asked if there was any consideration that might be given to his memory.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: And he sent you to me?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: He said no one had the authority to rescind the order except you.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Does your mother know you have come?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: No, sir.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Well, then, you have a lot of initiative, my young friend.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: My father's sword means more to me than any other possession I have.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You realize, of course, that thousands of swords have been collected.  How do you expect me to find yours?

lines.speaker: u2235
lines.text: No -- not as a rule.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Ah, well, that is the first rule of warfare.  You must wear long-sleeved and long-legged underwear.  You can never conjure up brilliancies with a cold bottom.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What's your name?

lines.speaker: u2237
lines.text: Lisette.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Only Lisette?

lines.speaker: u2237
lines.text: Lisette La Croix.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: That's a very nice name.  Where are you from?

lines.speaker: u2237
lines.text: Please, sir, come into bed or I shall die of a chill.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Oh, yes... of course.

lines.speaker: u2238
lines.text: Will you use the troops?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Only as a last resort.  What are the Councils doing now?

lines.speaker: u2239
lines.text: Oh -- I didn't tell you... I've seen Dr. Corvisart, and he was very reassuring and encouraging.  He has had excellent results with the waters of Plombiers, and he thinks it would be a good idea for me to spend a few weeks there. Apparently, he sent Madame Le Floch there last year, and she gave birth to twins.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Indeed -- well, you may tell Dr. Corvisart, I should be entirely satisfied with half her success.

lines.speaker: u2240
lines.text: I wanted to kill him but Joseph convinced me it would be a mistake. He said people would say you hadn't the courage to deal with it yourself.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: And was it so widely known that Joseph had reason for such concern?

lines.speaker: u2240
lines.text: I believe so.  I believe Madame Bonaparte was not discreet, in Paris.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: Good day, monsieur.  Do you think it is possible for you to tell your driver to stop ringing that bell?

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: My regrets, my dear Major, but I believe you have been blocking the road.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: Are you trying to provoke me, monsieur?

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: No, Major, I merely wish to state that your vehicle appears to be somewhat slower and heavier than mine, and point out that, if you would be kind enough to pull over to one side of the road, I could pass you and be on my way.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: May I inform you, monsieur, that I am Major Fidon, official courier to the court of the Emperor Napoleon, on my way to our Embassy at St. Petersburg and, in accordance with the rules of the road, no one may overtake or pass me.

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: Before you quote the rules of the road to me, Major, may I point out to you that you are not in France now, but that you are a guest in Russia.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: If I have given you any cause to be insulted, monsieur, may I offer you immediate satisfaction?

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: If you wish to put things on that basis, then I will say good day to you, monsieur.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Do you know the joke about the two Swiss boys who go to a bordello for the first time?

lines.speaker: u2242
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Well, two nice little Swiss boys, who are virgins, decide they will save up their money and go to a bordello.

lines.speaker: u2245
lines.text: On January 1st, 1814, France itself was invaded.  Now, with a small army of raw recruits, Napoleon would have to face the powerful combination of England, Russia, Prussia and Austria, operating against him together, for the first time.  The balance of numbers had tilted irretrievably against him.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: A year ago, the whole of Europe was marching alongside of us.  Today, the whole of Europe is marching against us.

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Okay, I know what I want this time.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: Anything you need.

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Yo' cousin, Craig.  Hook us up.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: That's it?

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Just tell him to come over here and talk to me.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: And I can go free?

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Go, fo' I change my mind.

lines.speaker: u2262
lines.text: Why for?  Them boys are real player haters.

lines.speaker: u2253
lines.text: It's a long story.  Right now we gotta do somethin'.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: I can't give you your damn money back on this.

lines.speaker: u2254
lines.text: Bullshit!  I'll go postal in this mothafucka!

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: Well, you gonna have to go postal then.

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Tape his mouth shut.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: Joker, a man like yourself can do a lot for this community.  By letting us go, you can improve black and brown relations.

lines.speaker: u2257
lines.text: Hey, how you get out of here.

lines.speaker: u2259
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u2261
lines.text: Hey, what's going on?

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Nothing.  What you want?

lines.speaker: u2261
lines.text: Are you going to take me to see Mom?

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Take your car.

lines.speaker: u2261
lines.text: 'Take your car?'

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Yeah, and hurry up.

lines.speaker: u2263
lines.text: Well, we better hit the road, too. Craig, get your stuff.

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: Well, Craig, you're welcome anytime.

lines.speaker: u2266
lines.text: Elroy, what happen?

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: I threw my back, again.

lines.speaker: u2266
lines.text: Aw, no lovin' tonight?

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: Naw, baby, no lovin' tonight.

lines.speaker: u2266
lines.text: Come on, baby, let's go in the house.

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: For what?  We ain't gonna have no house after the auction tomorrow!

lines.speaker: u2268
lines.text: Aw, gee. I sent her on an errand.

lines.speaker: u2270
lines.text: You sent my assistant on an errand.

lines.speaker: u2268
lines.text: I've been a bad boy.

lines.speaker: u2271
lines.text: Look...I've... I've got a problem. A big problem...

lines.speaker: u2269
lines.text: Oh, yeah?

lines.speaker: u2270
lines.text: Good luck.

lines.speaker: u2271
lines.text: Same to you.

lines.speaker: u2271
lines.text: Thanks for the shine.

lines.speaker: u2272
lines.text: Thanks for the tip.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Goddamnit, you fuckin' bum, come here!

lines.speaker: u2272
lines.text: Gimme a dollar.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Fuck you!

lines.speaker: u2277
lines.text: Well, is it real? Do we know anything about it?

lines.speaker: u2273
lines.text: It looks real. I don't know anything about guns.

lines.speaker: u2277
lines.text: Could I see it?

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Close your eyes.

lines.speaker: u2274
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: I've got something for you.

lines.speaker: u2274
lines.text: A surprise?

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: You ask too many questions. You want the surprise or not?

lines.speaker: u2275
lines.text: Come Back.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u2275
lines.text: Put her on.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: What gives?

lines.speaker: u2275
lines.text: Just put her on.

lines.speaker: u2285
lines.text: He never told about the money.

lines.speaker: u2279
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2285
lines.text: What do you figure he done with it?

lines.speaker: u2279
lines.text: He took the secret with him when I dropped him.

lines.speaker: u2280
lines.text: You got common sense. She ain't. When you grow up that money'll be yours. Now swear. "I will guard Pearl with my life..."

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: I will guard Pearl with my life...

lines.speaker: u2280
lines.text: ..."and I won't never tell about the money."

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: And I won't never tell about the money.

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: Uncle Birdie!

lines.speaker: u2281
lines.text: Don't!

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: Hide us Uncle Birdie! He's a-comin' with his knife!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Where's Ruby?

lines.speaker: u2282
lines.text: She went.

lines.speaker: u2293
lines.text: And the Lord told that man --

lines.speaker: u2283
lines.text: Yes! Yes!

lines.speaker: u2293
lines.text: The Lord said, Take that money and throw it in the River!

lines.speaker: u2283
lines.text: Yes! Yes! Hallelujah!

lines.speaker: u2293
lines.text: Throw that money in the River! In THE RIVER!

lines.speaker: u2283
lines.text: IN THE RIIV-ER!

lines.speaker: u2284
lines.text: See ye got two more peeps to your brood.

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Yeah, and ornerier than the rest.

lines.speaker: u2284
lines.text: How's your own boy, Miz Cooper?

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Ain't heard from Ralph since last Christmas. Don't matter -- I've got a new crop.  I'm a strong tree with branches for many birds. I'm good for something in this old world and I know it, too! We know that she will rout the Devil.

lines.speaker: u2284
lines.text: Got a good buy in soap, Miz Cooper.

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Don't need no soap. I'm boilin' down the fat from my hog.

lines.speaker: u2286
lines.text: Just look at you! Dust and filth from top to toe!

lines.speaker: u2286
lines.text: Want me to take 'em up and wash 'em good?

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Thank you, no. Thank you, dear Icey. I'll tend to them. Thank you.

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: Nothin'.

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Come to me, boy!

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Just tell me now; where's the money hid?

lines.speaker: u2288
lines.text: But I swore. I promised John I wouldn't tell.

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: JOHN -- DOESN'T -- MATTER! Can't I get that through your head, you poor, silly, disgusting little wretch!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: What do you want?

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Them kids!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: What are you after them for?

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: None of your business, Madam.

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: I'm givin' you to the count of three to get out that screen door; then I'm a-comin' across this kitchen shootin'!

lines.speaker: u2291
lines.text: Miz Cooper!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u2291
lines.text: The man! The man!

lines.speaker: u2297
lines.text: Oh my god, oh my god...

lines.speaker: u2294
lines.text: Get the kit!

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: Bring him out of what?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: My dream.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: How you plan to do that?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Just like I did the hat. Have a hold of the sucker when you wake me up.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: Me?  Wait a minute, you can't bring someone out of a dream!

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: If I can't, then you all can relax, because it'll just be a simple case of me being nuts.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: I can save you the trouble. You're nutty as a fruitcake. I love you anyway.

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Good, then you won't mind cold-cocking this guy when I bring him out.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: What!?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: You heard me. I grab him in the dream -- you see me struggling so you wake me up. We both come out, you cold cock the fucker, and we got him. Clever, huh?

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: You crazy? Hit him with what?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: You're a jock. You must have a baseball bat or something. Come to my window at midnight. And meanwhile...

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: Meanwhile...?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Meanwhile whatever you do don't fall asleep. Midnight.

lines.speaker: u2298
lines.text: Maybe god's punishing us all...

lines.speaker: u2296
lines.text: Keep your head -- this is a fucking flesh and blood killer we're talking about.

lines.speaker: u2298
lines.text: Like Rod Lane?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Feeling better?

lines.speaker: u2297
lines.text: They say you've bottomed out when you can't remember the night before.  No more drinking, Baby, suddenly I just don't feel like it any more.

lines.speaker: u2302
lines.text: What you dream?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: I dreamed about this guy in a dirty red and yellow sweater; I dream in color, y'know; he walked into the room I was in, right, right through the wall, like it was smoke or something, and just stared at me. Sort of... obscenely. Then he walked out through the wall on the other side. Like he'd just come to check me out...

lines.speaker: u2302
lines.text: When did you have a nightmare?

lines.speaker: u2301
lines.text: Guys can have nightmares too, y'know. You ain't got a corner on the fucking market or something.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: From Leon.

lines.speaker: u2303
lines.text: From Leon!... How is he?... Come, tell us... open it... tell us... how is he?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: No, I left everything in Paris. I just happened to be wearing this.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Tell me... what else did you have?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Well, a hat...

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: What was it like?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: It was very silly.... I would be ashamed to wear it here.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: As beautiful as that? What else? Come, tell me.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: An evening gown.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Evening gown?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: A dress you wear in the evening.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: What do you wear in the morning?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: When you get up you put on a negligee, and then you change to a morning frock.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: You mean to tell me you wear a different dress for different times of the day?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Now, Ninotchka, you're exaggerating.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: No, my dear, it is true. That's how they live in the other world. Here we dress to have our bodies covered... to keep warm....

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: And there?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Well, sometimes they're not completely covered but... they don't freeze.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: They must have wonderful materials to make a thing like this so soft... something you don't even see.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: You feel it, though.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Ninotchka, I wouldn't bring this up if we weren't such good friends.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: What is it, Anna?

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: You know I told you that Pavlov and I are going to get married when he comes back from the maneuvers. Would it be asking too much...

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: You want this?

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Just for the honeymoon.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: You can have it for good. It is my wedding present.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Boys, boys... don't forget Russia is your mother country. Three sons walking out all at once... that's too much for any mother.

lines.speaker: u2305
lines.text: Well, if your mother turns against you, you have to look for someone to adopt you.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: What time have you, Gaston?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Eight forty-two, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: I guess it is eight forty-two.

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: I am, Gaston.

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: If you will forgive me, ever since you met that Bolshevik lady I've noticed a distinct change in you, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Have you?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly amazed when I came from the market and found that you had made your bed, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: And Gaston, I was happier all day long. I felt I'd contributed something.

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Well, sir, if you should do it again, which I hope you won't, please remember the order. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Ah, there's something poetic about the simple processes of labor. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet... it should be set to music!

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: May I add, sir, that it was with great amazement that I found a copy of Karl Marx's Capital on your night table. That is a socialistic volume which I refuse to so much as dust, sir. I view with alarm, sir, the influence over you of this Bolshevik lady.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it about time that you realized the unfairness of your position? You being my servant? Wouldn't you like to stand on an equal footing with me?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: No, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Isn't there any revolt in you? Sometimes when I order you around don't you feel like kicking me in the pants?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: No, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you look forward to the day when you can come in here and stand square on your two feet and say, "Hey, you, d'Algout! from now on it's going to be share and share alike"?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Emphatically not, sir. The prospect terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand me, sir, I don't resent your not paying me for the past two months, but the thought that I should split my bank account with you... that you should take half of my life's savings... that is really too much for me.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: General, would you mind making my excuses at our table? I'll be back in a few moments.

lines.speaker: u2307
lines.text: Certainly.

lines.speaker: u2308
lines.text: Is this satisfactory?

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Thank you, Louis.

lines.speaker: u2309
lines.text: A Special Envoy is coming from Moscow. He'll occupy the Royal Suite. Move our things to the smallest room you've got.

lines.speaker: u2313
lines.text: Yes, monsieur.

lines.speaker: u2309
lines.text: Right away... instantly!

lines.speaker: u2310
lines.text: ...and Kopalski.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Don't make it difficult for me. This is no more a pleasure trip for me than it is for you.

lines.speaker: u2311
lines.text: We'll leave these papers here for your further consideration. Au revoir, madame.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Au revoir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Now, please, Swana.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Count d'Algout was for several years my personal representative and if it is necessary to sign any affidavit for him I'll be delighted.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: That does it, Swana.  Now you mustn't miss your appointment with your hair-dresser.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Just in case they don't give you your visa to Russia I want you to know that I have signed a contract for my memoirs and rented a lovely little chteau in the Touraine, and if you feel the need of a change...

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Thank you, Swana. You are very gracious.

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: Where to, madame?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Can you recommend a restaurant?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: Well, there's Pruniers if you care for seafood. If you want to lunch in the Bois, there's...

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Where do you eat?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: At Pre Mathieu's.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Where is that?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: It's just a place for workmen.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Where is it?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: Eight blocks down in the Rue de Poivrel.

lines.speaker: u2318
lines.text: I am sorry... I have to leave.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Thank you so much, my friend. I will get in touch with you.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: For Christ's sake, it soils my mother's memory.  Do you think I want the whole goddamn world to see my mother like this?  Raising a dirty mouth!

lines.speaker: u2322
lines.text: But sir, we'll have to start over from the beginning.  We don't have the staff to ...

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: How's the job coming, Bob?

lines.speaker: u2323
lines.text: Frankly, sir, it stinks.  I have no access.  I'm lucky Helms lets me have a staff.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: We'll see about that ...

lines.speaker: u2323
lines.text: He's nervous, sir.  He's heard you're looking for a new director.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Well, he certainly isn't acting like it.

lines.speaker: u2323
lines.text: That's Helms.  He's "sang froid," a world-class poker player.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Yeah?  Well, I own the fucking casino.

lines.speaker: u2324
lines.text: How the hell do you have the temerity to blackmail the President of the United States?

lines.speaker: u2332
lines.text: That's not the question, John.  The question is: Why is he paying?

lines.speaker: u2324
lines.text: To protect his people.

lines.speaker: u2332
lines.text: I'm one of his people.  The Cubans are his people.  And we're going to jail for him.

lines.speaker: u2324
lines.text: Howard, you'll serve no more than two years, then he'll pardon you.

lines.speaker: u2332
lines.text: John, sooner or later -- sooner, I think -- you are going to learn the lesson that has been learned by everyone who has ever gotten close to Richard Nixon.  That he's the darkness reaching out for the darkness.  And eventually, it's either you or him. Look at the landscape of his life and you'll see a boneyard.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: I don't know, I don't know ... I just know we've made too many enemies.

lines.speaker: u2325
lines.text: Sir, Bob and I are gonna have to testify before Earvin's committee.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: No, you're not!  You're going to claim executive privilege and you're going to stonewall it all the way -- plead the Fifth Amendment.  I don't give a shit.  They can't force the President's people to testify.

lines.speaker: u2325
lines.text: Executive privilege will make it look like we're covering up.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: We are covering up!  For some petty, stupid shit.  There are things I can say -- when other people say them, they'd be lies. But when I say them nobody believes me anyway ...

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: ... they smelled the blood on me this time, Al.  I got soft.  You know ... that rusty, metallic smell ...

lines.speaker: u2326
lines.text: I know it well, sir.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: It came over from Vietnam, you know.

lines.speaker: u2326
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: That smell.  I mean, everybody suffered so much, their sons killed. They need to sacrifice something, y'know, appease the gods of war -- Mars, Jupiter.  I am that blood, General.  I am that sacrifice, in the highest place of all ... All leaders must finally be sacrificed.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: ... There can be no whitewash at the White House ... two wrongs do not make a right.  I love America.  God bless America and God bless each and every one of you.

lines.speaker: u2327
lines.text: Sir ... six bodies.

lines.speaker: u2328
lines.text: It's a gift, Richard.  This law school is a gift from your brother.

lines.speaker: u2342
lines.text: Did he have to die for me to get it?!

lines.speaker: u2328
lines.text: It's meant to make us stronger.  Thou art stronger than Harold ... stronger than Arthur.  God has chosen thee to survive ...

lines.speaker: u2342
lines.text: What about happiness, Mother?

lines.speaker: u2328
lines.text: Thou must find thy peace at the center, Richard.  Strength in this life.  Happiness in the next.

lines.speaker: u2329
lines.text: Relax, Dick, it's just me ... The desert's so beautiful, isn't it?  I want to go home, Dick.  Time to go home.

lines.speaker: u2342
lines.text: You're not gonna quit on me, are you, Harold?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: I never thought Jack was ready for the presidency.  But I would never, never consider ...  His death was awful, an awful thing for this country.  Do you ever think of death, Mr. Helms?

lines.speaker: u2330
lines.text: Flowers are continual reminders of our mortality.  Do you appreciate flowers?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: No.  They make me sick.  They smell like death ... I had two brothers die young.  But let me tell you, there are worse things than death.  There is such a thing as evil.

lines.speaker: u2330
lines.text: You must be familiar with my favorite poem by Yeats?  "The Second Coming"?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2330
lines.text: Black Irishman.  Very moving. "Turning and turning in the widening gyre / The falcon cannot hear the falconer / Things fall apart, the center cannot hold / Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world / And everywhere the ceremony of innocence is drowned / The best lack all conviction, while the worst are full of passionate intensity" ... But it ends so beautifully ominous -- "What rough beast, its hours come round at last / Slouches toward Bethlehem to be born?" ... Yes, this country stands at such a juncture.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: This damned tie ... Will you help me, Edgar?  Churchill used to say to me, "If you want your own history written properly, you must write it yourself."  All right, Edgar, but just don't let it come back to haunt me.

lines.speaker: u2331
lines.text: It won't.  As long as I'm here.

lines.speaker: u2332
lines.text: Let's get the fuck out of here, shall we, ladies?

lines.speaker: u2335
lines.text: Anything goes wrong, head for your homes, just sit tight -- you'll hear from me or Howard.

lines.speaker: u2332
lines.text: Personally, I'll be calling the President of the United States.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Because if you're uncomfortable with the EPA up your ass, try the IRS ...

lines.speaker: u2333
lines.text: Well, goddamn.  Are you threatening me, Dick?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Presidents don't threaten.  They don't have to.  Good day, gentlemen.

lines.speaker: u2334
lines.text: You know, Mr. Chairman, at Harvard I used your writings in my class.

lines.speaker: u2337
lines.text: What a waste of time.  My writings mean absolutely nothing.

lines.speaker: u2334
lines.text: But your writings have changed the world, Mr. Chairman.

lines.speaker: u2337
lines.text: Fung pi!   I've only managed to change a few things around the city of Beijing.  I want to know your secret.

lines.speaker: u2334
lines.text: Secret, Mr. Chairman?

lines.speaker: u2337
lines.text: How a fat man gets so many girls.

lines.speaker: u2336
lines.text: He was a politician.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Did you cry when he died?

lines.speaker: u2336
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u2336
lines.text: I don't know.  He made me see the stars ...

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: How did he do that?  All those kids ... Why do they hate me so much?

lines.speaker: u2337
lines.text: You're too modest, Nixon.  You're as evil as I am.  We're both from poor families.  But others pay to feed the hunger in us.  In my case, millions of reactionaries.  In your case, millions of Vietnamese.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Civil war is always the cruelest kind of war.

lines.speaker: u2337
lines.text: The real war is in us.  History is a symptom of our disease.

lines.speaker: u2338
lines.text: What are you going to do about this Allende fellow nationalizing our businesses in Chile?  You gonna send Kissinger down there?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: We're gonna get rid of him -- Allende, I mean -- just as fast as we can. He's on the top of the list.

lines.speaker: u2338
lines.text: How about Kissinger along with him?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Kissinger's misunderstood.  He pretends to be a liberal for his Establishment friends, but he's even tougher than I am ...

lines.speaker: u2339
lines.text: Get off that.  That leads nowhere. You should offer condolences to the families of those kids.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: Sure, I'd like to offer condolences.

lines.speaker: u2343
lines.text: Hey, you know Henry Kissinger -- he's down from Harvard.  On my staff, foreign policy whiz ...

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: No, but I liked your book on nuclear weapons.  We have similar views on the balance of power ...

lines.speaker: u2343
lines.text: Well, that's wonderful.  So get me this "crisis" thing, Dick; I'll be glad to take a look at it.

lines.speaker: u2356
lines.text: ...How'd you sleep?

lines.speaker: u2350
lines.text: I don't know. Had dreams.

lines.speaker: u2356
lines.text: Well you got time for 'em now. Anything interesting?

lines.speaker: u2350
lines.text: Well they always is to the party concerned.

lines.speaker: u2356
lines.text: Ed Tom, I'll be polite.

lines.speaker: u2350
lines.text: Okay. Two of 'em. Both had my father. It's peculiar. I'm older now'n he ever was by twenty years. So in a sense he's the younger man. Anyway, first one I don't remember so well but it was about meetin' him in town somewheres and he give me some money and I think I lost it. The second one, it was like we was both back in older times and I was on horseback goin' through the mountains of a night.

lines.speaker: u2351
lines.text: Llewelyn, I ain't gonna leave you in the lurch.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: No. This works better. With you gone and I don't have the money, he can't touch me. But I can sure touch him. After I find him I'll come and join you.

lines.speaker: u2351
lines.text: Find who? What am I supposed to do with Mother?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: She'll be all right.

lines.speaker: u2351
lines.text: She'll be all right?

lines.speaker: u2352
lines.text: ...Don't put it in your pocket.

lines.speaker: u2363
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: u2352
lines.text: Don't put it in your pocket. It's your lucky quarter.

lines.speaker: u2363
lines.text: ...Where you want me to put it?

lines.speaker: u2352
lines.text: Anywhere not in your pocket. Or it'll get mixed in with the others and become just a coin. Which it is.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: Good. I need everything else.

lines.speaker: u2353
lines.text: Okay.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: You get a lot of people come in here with no clothes on?

lines.speaker: u2353
lines.text: No sir, it's unusual.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: ...Keep going. Don't stop.

lines.speaker: u2354
lines.text: I don't want to get in some kind of a jackpot here, buddy.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: It's all right.

lines.speaker: u2354
lines.text: Why don't I set you down here and we won't argue about it.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: I want you to take me to another motel.

lines.speaker: u2354
lines.text: Let's just call it square.

lines.speaker: u2357
lines.text: ...An attempt at humor, I suppose.

lines.speaker: u2365
lines.text: I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u2357
lines.text: Goodbye, Mr. Wells.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Who do you think gets through this gate into the United States of America?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: I don't know. American citizens.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Some American citizens. Who do you think decides?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: You do, I reckon.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: That is correct. And how do I decide?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: I ask questions. If I get sensible answers then they get to go to America. If I don't get sensible answers they don't. Is there anything about that that you don't understand?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: No sir.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Then I ask you again how you come to be out here with no clothes.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: I got an overcoat on.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Are you jackin' with me?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: No sir.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Don't jack with me.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: Yes sir.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Are you in the service?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: No sir. I'm a veteran.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: Nam?

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: Yes sir. Two tours.

lines.speaker: u2362
lines.text: What outfit.

lines.speaker: u2360
lines.text: Twelfth Infantry Batallion. August seventh nineteen and sixty-six to July second nineteen and sixty-eight.

lines.speaker: u2387
lines.text: You wanna see if he has more shells, go ahead. I say we wait...

lines.speaker: u2368
lines.text: No, no, no... you don't know shit about procedure! You don't send your best...

lines.speaker: u2387
lines.text: I've got the working gun, Elden, me! You wasted all your bullets so you crawl out there.

lines.speaker: u2386
lines.text: These guys are here to help you, Betty.

lines.speaker: u2369
lines.text: I don't think so.  Rosa, I didn't kill Del... they did.

lines.speaker: u2383
lines.text: Blake, I can handle that transplant!

lines.speaker: u2370
lines.text: We need someone with the right kind of experience, Lonnie.

lines.speaker: u2383
lines.text: Even if he's falling asleep on his feet?

lines.speaker: u2370
lines.text: Lonnie, it's a complex procedure. Why don't you observe?

lines.speaker: u2383
lines.text: I'm not some snot-nosed resident fresh out of medical school, Blake.

lines.speaker: u2370
lines.text: No, you're not. You're a good doctor, Lonnie, but you're not David Ravell. I've made my decision. Now, if you'll excuse me...

lines.speaker: u2371
lines.text: ...and how long did she work here?

lines.speaker: u2373
lines.text: Oh, five years, give or take.

lines.speaker: u2371
lines.text: Hmm... you two in high school together?

lines.speaker: u2373
lines.text: Aren't you a sweetheart... no, not quite. Anyway, she's been with us awhile.

lines.speaker: u2371
lines.text: But she wanted more out of life, right?

lines.speaker: u2373
lines.text: No... she just wanted something outta life. Anything. And with Del, she wasn't getting nothing. That's her husband, Del. I'm sorry about what happened and all, but that's the way I feel about all of this...

lines.speaker: u2371
lines.text: I see.  May I?

lines.speaker: u2373
lines.text: If it helps bring her back, be my guest...

lines.speaker: u2371
lines.text: Thank you for your cooperation.  Just one more thing... did she ever talk about getting rich?

lines.speaker: u2373
lines.text: ...who doesn't?

lines.speaker: u2374
lines.text: Jesus Christ!

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: He's waiting...

lines.speaker: u2374
lines.text: Okay, uh... the, umm, Injuns're stupid.

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: "Injuns?"

lines.speaker: u2379
lines.text: Jesus, don't do that! If it gets around that you fired me, I'll never land a pilot.

lines.speaker: u2384
lines.text: Then do as you're told. Get her back.

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: Hey, can you sneak me on the lot?

lines.speaker: u2380
lines.text: Sure.

lines.speaker: u2381
lines.text: You've got to be missing a piece of your soul to kill someone. That's not our Betty...

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: ...why do you think you have to be missing a piece of your soul to kill somebody?

lines.speaker: u2381
lines.text: Because it ain't natural, young man.

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: What are you talking about? Killing's totally natural. It's dying that isn't natural...

lines.speaker: u2382
lines.text: What did you say?

lines.speaker: u2387
lines.text: The driver was killed. I think there's a connection --

lines.speaker: u2382
lines.text: No, about... Are you talking about Duane Cooley?

lines.speaker: u2387
lines.text: Yeah. Why, you know him?

lines.speaker: u2382
lines.text: Know him? We were gonna get married! He was gonna leave his wife for me! Fuck!!...

lines.speaker: u2385
lines.text: Hey... Is Betty still trying to find that soap opera guy?

lines.speaker: u2386
lines.text: Oh, yeah... Man, I'd love to find that actor just to see the look on her face, watch her bubble burst in mid-air.

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: You lie, motherfucker...

lines.speaker: u2387
lines.text: I swear to God!

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: Yeah?

lines.speaker: u2388
lines.text: Mr. Campbell?

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: Huh?

lines.speaker: u2388
lines.text: Is this Neighborly Life Insurance?

lines.speaker: u2389
lines.text: Oh, umm, yes, this is Dwight Campbell.

lines.speaker: u2388
lines.text: It's Sue Ann Rogers, Betty Sizemore's friend? I heard from her.

lines.speaker: u2394
lines.text: I like to think that I'm a pretty astute observer of the human scene.

lines.speaker: u2390
lines.text: No doubt, brother - I figured as much back there in the restaurant. That's why I invited you out here for this advanced tutorial.

lines.speaker: u2394
lines.text: It ain't the law!

lines.speaker: u2391
lines.text: The law. Well the law is a human institution.

lines.speaker: u2392
lines.text: A miracle! It was a miracle!

lines.speaker: u2394
lines.text: Aw, don't be ignorant, Delmar. I told you they was gonna flood this valley.

lines.speaker: u2392
lines.text: That ain't it!

lines.speaker: u2393
lines.text: Pappy O'Daniel be laughing' then.

lines.speaker: u2403
lines.text: Not out the other side his face, though.

lines.speaker: u2393
lines.text: Oh no, no, just the reg'la side -

lines.speaker: u2394
lines.text: Hot damn, boy, I almost believe you did sell your soul to the devil!

lines.speaker: u2397
lines.text: Boys, that was some mighty fine pickin' and singin'. You just sign these papers and I'll give you ten dollars apiece.

lines.speaker: u2394
lines.text: Okay sir, but Mert and Aloysius'll have to scratch Xes - only four of us can write.

lines.speaker: u2397
lines.text: Now what can I do you for, Mister French?

lines.speaker: u2395
lines.text: How can I lay hold a the Soggy Bottom Boys?

lines.speaker: u2397
lines.text: Soggy Bottom Boys - I don't precisely recollect, uh -

lines.speaker: u2395
lines.text: They cut a record in here, few days ago, old-timey harmony thing with a guitar Accump-accump-uh-

lines.speaker: u2397
lines.text: Oh I remember 'em, colored fellas I believe, swell bunch a boys, sung into yon can and skedaddled.

lines.speaker: u2395
lines.text: Well that record has just gone through the goddamn roof! They're playin' it as far away as Mobile! The whole damn state's goin' ape!

lines.speaker: u2397
lines.text: It was a powerful air.

lines.speaker: u2395
lines.text: Hot damn, we gotta find those boys! Sign 'em to a big fat contract! Hell's bells, Mr. Lunn, if we don't the goddamn competition will!

lines.speaker: u2397
lines.text: Oh mercy, yes. You gotta beat that competition.

lines.speaker: u2399
lines.text: Holy-moly. These boys're a hit!

lines.speaker: u2396
lines.text: But Pappy, they's inter-grated.

lines.speaker: u2399
lines.text: Well I guess folks don't mind they's integrated.

lines.speaker: u2398
lines.text: She's at the five and dime.

lines.speaker: u2404
lines.text: Buyin' nipples!

lines.speaker: u2405
lines.text: I knew you'd make it!  Where's your girl? Didn't she come?

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: Naw. That's over with.

lines.speaker: u2406
lines.text: Go on, Zack! Go for the record!

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: Fuck the record. Now you listen to me and do exactly what I tell you.  Start back ten yards and take off from here. Not here... or there... but right here!  No excuses, Seeger! You are going to plant those legs here and then you're going to yank yourself over that wall because you have to! You want jets? Then do it, goddamnit!

lines.speaker: u2407
lines.text: He doesn't mean anything by it, Zack. Do you, Joe?

lines.speaker: u2410
lines.text: I don't mean anything by it.

lines.speaker: u2408
lines.text: I know why most of you are here. We're not stupid. But before you get to sell what we teach you over at United Airlines, you gotta give the Navy six years of your life, Sweet Pea. Lot of things can happen in six year. Another war could come up in six years. If you're too peaceful a person to dump napalm on an enemy village where there might be women and children, I'm gonna find that out. Understand?

lines.speaker: u2409
lines.text: Yes, sir!

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: Don't you dare ask me that question. I'm an adult and you got no right to push your nose into my affairs like that!

lines.speaker: u2410
lines.text: Well, as long as you live in this house, young lady, you live by my rules! You should be dating local boys.

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: Uh-uh! Not a chance! There's nobody in this town doing anything with his life, except what his father did, which is nothing. If I can't have more out of life than that, I'd rather be dead!

lines.speaker: u2410
lines.text: Do you honestly think you'll find a boy in that... that officer's school who's serious about marriage?

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: Yes I do!

lines.speaker: u2410
lines.text: Then you're dumber than I thought! All you'll get from their kind is pregnant!

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: You little bitch! How could you? Was there ever a baby, Lynette? That's all I want to know! Did you make up that baby, Lynette? Did you??

lines.speaker: u2411
lines.text: Of course there was a baby. I'd never lie about something like that. Would I, Paula?

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: Please stop it. None of that's true. Goddamnit, I love you. I loved you ever since I met you.

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: Come on, Paula! You were looking for a ticket out of here and you didn't care who it was, any more than you cared with the last class of candidates you and Lynette fucked your way through, looking for a husband! Or the class before that!

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: Yeah. You got the whole story just right.

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: Beware of the Puget Debs -- and we all laughed, especially him.

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: I'm not a Puget Deb. I hate that goddamn term!

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: I bet you do!

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: However you got it figured, I didn't kill Sid and Lynette didn't kill him! He killed himself!

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: That's brilliant.

lines.speaker: u2412
lines.text: Maybe not, but it is the truth. And Zack, you didn't kill him either.

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: How about that prick! He told me he wasn't officer material because he grew up poor like me.

lines.speaker: u2413
lines.text: He said he grew up poor?

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: The kid on the windy side of the baker's window. That's how he put it.

lines.speaker: u2413
lines.text: Foley's not poor. Buddy of mine in oh-four told me he's the son of a rich doctor down in Louisiana.

lines.speaker: u2414
lines.text: Please, Zack -- go back to the barracks!

lines.speaker: u2415
lines.text: I don't get it! He's the best candidate in our class! Ask anyone! The best student! The best leader! The best friend to everybody! Couldn't you bend your goddamn standards just a little?

lines.speaker: u2414
lines.text: Zack, it wasn't him! He didn't ask me to D.O.R. I came to him on my own.  I'm glad it's over, Zack. I really mean that. He was right. I wasn't doing this for me.

lines.speaker: u2416
lines.text: You walk out that door and you lose your share of the money.

lines.speaker: u2419
lines.text: Yeah, whatever.

lines.speaker: u2416
lines.text: I mean it!

lines.speaker: u2419
lines.text: Adios.

lines.speaker: u2417
lines.text: May I ask what the rest of that sentence was going to be?

lines.speaker: u2421
lines.text: Huh?

lines.speaker: u2417
lines.text: The sentence that started "There are three."  What was the rest?

lines.speaker: u2418
lines.text: Push that button for me, will you?

lines.speaker: u2421
lines.text: Don't!

lines.speaker: u2419
lines.text: Suit yourself.

lines.speaker: u2422
lines.text: Nobody leaves.

lines.speaker: u2419
lines.text: Observe.

lines.speaker: u2420
lines.text: Old Bernie didn't miss a trick with this room, did he?

lines.speaker: u2421
lines.text: Open the door.

lines.speaker: u2420
lines.text: And with kids like he's got, no wonder he wanted a place to hide.

lines.speaker: u2423
lines.text: Where is the Glucogen?

lines.speaker: u2421
lines.text: Oh, you know, it's uh... it's in the little fridge in your room.

lines.speaker: u2423
lines.text: I'm sorry, Mom.

lines.speaker: u2421
lines.text: Hey, quit apologizing, you're starting to sound like Grandma. You're not gonna have an attack. Okay?

lines.speaker: u2423
lines.text: Okay.

lines.speaker: u2424
lines.text: No...

lines.speaker: u2442
lines.text: You gotta. You gotta stay alive. You know what they were trying to do here. You got the pigs dead to rights. It's like Huey said, you're more important than any of us.

lines.speaker: u2425
lines.text: For the last time Boy!!! What do those guns mean??!!

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: They mean, Pig!, that the Black Panther Party declares that if you try to brutalize our community or take our weapons.  We are going to shoot you!!!

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: You got to sit on Eldridge...

lines.speaker: u2426
lines.text: Man, El-Rage is El-Rage. You know him.

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: Yeah, I do, but he's gotta cool it...

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: ...The police report says he was shot three times but the coroner's report says quite clearly that Denzil Dowell was shot six times. And two of those shots were in his armpits. Brothers and Sisters you know why that is?  Because Denzil had his hands up!!

lines.speaker: u2427
lines.text: No more police brutality! WHAT DO WE WANT?

lines.speaker: u2428
lines.text: Go! Run! Go on! Get the fuck out of here!!

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: What? So you can shoot me? Call it resisting arrest?

lines.speaker: u2428
lines.text: I ain't gonna shoot you Judge. Look... it's over. Just run away. Get out. Stay away from Oakland. Cause it's gone... it's gone.

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Brimmer you're fucked up...

lines.speaker: u2428
lines.text: Yeah... I'm fucked up. You're fucked up. Government's fucked up. Whole country's fucked up. You got no idea what's going on here. This is bigger than you and me. We're just little tiny soldiers getting moved around on some big asshole's desk. The Panthers... fuck you're history... they killed you and you don't even know it.

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Who's they?

lines.speaker: u2428
lines.text: Drugs Judge, they're gonna flood West Oakland with dope. Jack you up and string you out like a two dollar whore. And while the community's shuffling for a fix, they're gonna snuff every Panther they can find.

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Who? I mean besides the FBI?

lines.speaker: u2428
lines.text: I don't know. Except, it's one of you. Maybe not a Panther, but it's someone from the neighborhood. Judge. Look, just go. Get away. It's over. You lost.  We all lost.

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Cy... Cy... Oh shit man... who did this to you. Was it the pigs?

lines.speaker: u2438
lines.text: I don't think that will be any problem...

lines.speaker: u2430
lines.text: You talk as if this thing's already been decided.

lines.speaker: u2431
lines.text: But lots of our people don't read, man. They need strong imagery to help them out.

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: Yeah... then shouldn't this be all of us together.

lines.speaker: u2431
lines.text: Trust me Huey, this picture will be worth a thousand words. Now have you given any thought to that Peace and Freedom Party thing. They really want to hook up with us. Do a rally together. Hell it'd broaden our base of visibility.

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: Yeah, but aligning with white organizations. I'm not sure now's the time.

lines.speaker: u2431
lines.text: The time, my friend, is what Sartre called, "the moment the match is being put to the fuse." Question is, is the hand holding that match gonna be black or white.

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: ...no full fledge alliance. But I think we should do a rally with them. Show that there's some common ground between Black and White. You all with that?  All right then Eldridge, set it up.

lines.speaker: u2432
lines.text: Did you shoot the officers in question?

lines.speaker: u2433
lines.text: Again I'll take the fifth amendment on that question.

lines.speaker: u2434
lines.text: Well, then we're going to take that power away from those bastards.

lines.speaker: u2438
lines.text: You mean...

lines.speaker: u2434
lines.text: Yes, that's exactly what I mean. And Agent Rodgers?... This conversation never occurred.

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: I don't know man. I don't know. That reminds me.  Another little donation from the police.

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: If the pigs only knew they were subsidizing The Panthers...

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Yeah well, they want a lot for their money. They want a felony, preferably with "violent intent." We've got to give them something. They'll kill me if I don't. And the Panthers are going to kill me if I do. I'm scared.

lines.speaker: u2435
lines.text: Me too. That's why I fight so hard.

lines.speaker: u2437
lines.text: You meet those friends of yours in jail too?

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Yes... No... Mom it's not like you think. They're alright. There out there trying to do something.

lines.speaker: u2437
lines.text: I hear them boys, those Black Panthers, they're communists. They don't even believe in God.

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: Mom, black folks been praying to God for four hundred years. Maybe it's time we tried something else...

lines.speaker: u2437
lines.text: You believe that?

lines.speaker: u2436
lines.text: I don't know. I really don't.

lines.speaker: u2443
lines.text: Next time we'll bring more blankets.

lines.speaker: u2448
lines.text: That would be nice.

lines.speaker: u2443
lines.text: Maybe we'll be lucky this winter and have just rain, no snow.

lines.speaker: u2448
lines.text: That would be nice, too.

lines.speaker: u2444
lines.text: You got salt last week.

lines.speaker: u2448
lines.text: Oh, right.  Baking powder, we need baking powder.

lines.speaker: u2444
lines.text: We've got plenty of baking powder. You went to Pembroke and got five pounds two weeks ago.

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: Two pounds, fourteen ounces.

lines.speaker: u2445
lines.text: Lovely.

lines.speaker: u2446
lines.text: We did.

lines.speaker: u2457
lines.text: With a lace table cloth?

lines.speaker: u2447
lines.text: Do you see that, Colonel?

lines.speaker: u2457
lines.text: Unless I'm dreaming, I think I see irregulars at their center.

lines.speaker: u2448
lines.text: There are some letters here from him.  Some are just to you.

lines.speaker: u2456
lines.text: I don't care.  I hate him.

lines.speaker: u2448
lines.text: You don't hate him.

lines.speaker: u2456
lines.text: Yes, I do.  I hate him and I hope he never comes back.

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: Your son, what did you name him?

lines.speaker: u2449
lines.text: Robert.  Robert E. Lee.

lines.speaker: u2450
lines.text: Lord Cornwallis will be with you presently.

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: u2450
lines.text: You may, of course, keep your weapons, but I must warn you that...

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: I'm familiar with appropriate behavior at a military parley.

lines.speaker: u2450
lines.text: Yes, quite, but you should know that...

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: That will be all, Major.  I'll wait for Lord Cornwallis.

lines.speaker: u2450
lines.text: Yes... you will wait.

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: Margaret, take William and Susan to the river shed.  Hide there.  If we're not back by dawn, go up the river to the Richardson's house. They'll take you to your Aunt Charlotte's farm.  Nathan, Samuel, and I are going to get Gabriel.

lines.speaker: u2451
lines.text: But what about Thomas?

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: Leave him.  Take care of William and Susan.

lines.speaker: u2453
lines.text: Father... I killed those men...

lines.speaker: u2452
lines.text: Don't blame yourself, you did what I told you to do.

lines.speaker: u2453
lines.text: I'm glad I killed them... I'm glad...

lines.speaker: u2460
lines.text: Do you swear?

lines.speaker: u2462
lines.text: I swear.

lines.speaker: u2462
lines.text: I'll bite--what's the bottom of the truth, Jud?

lines.speaker: u2461
lines.text: Why...that sometimes dead is better. That's all. Sometimes dead is better.

lines.speaker: u2462
lines.text: You better get going, hon.

lines.speaker: u2464
lines.text: Oh Louis, I just don't know about this--

lines.speaker: u2462
lines.text: I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy.

lines.speaker: u2464
lines.text: Louis, are you sure?

lines.speaker: u2462
lines.text: I'm sure.

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: AnaMaria, trim the mainsail!

lines.speaker: u2465
lines.text: Aye, aye, sir!

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: Mr. Gibbs, organize a cleaning detail -- you and Cotton.  I want every inch of the Pearl spic-and- span and ship-shape!

lines.speaker: u2466
lines.text: Agreed.  You have my word, as a gentleman of fortune --

lines.speaker: u2467
lines.text: Will -- you can't trust him.

lines.speaker: u2467
lines.text: You didn't tell Commodore Norrington everything.

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: Nor did you, I noticed.

lines.speaker: u2467
lines.text: He might delay the rescue ... and that would be too late.

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: Exactly.

lines.speaker: u2467
lines.text: These men will be facing an enemy that seemingly cannot be killed.

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: I have a plan.  If it succeeds, then any battle will be decidedly brief ... and one-sided.

lines.speaker: u2467
lines.text: What's your plan?

lines.speaker: u2476
lines.text: We can at least fight -- we might be able to kill a few--

lines.speaker: u2468
lines.text: Will -- it'll go worse for us -- for Elizabeth, especially -- if we fight.

lines.speaker: u2469
lines.text: Sir, I'll not see any of my men killed or wounded in this foolish enterprise.

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: Fine by me.  We brought you a nice little boat, so you can all get back to shore, safe and sound.

lines.speaker: u2469
lines.text: Agreed.  You have the momentary advantage, sir.  But I will see you smile from the yard arm, sir.

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: As likely as not.  Will, short up the anchor, we've got ourselves a ship!

lines.speaker: u2476
lines.text: Well, you're the worst pirate I've ever heard of.  You're a man who can be trusted, who can be counted on, and who can't betray his friends.  What kind of pirate is that?

lines.speaker: u2470
lines.text: The worst.  On the other hand, maybe I'm a man who can't pass up a chance for revenge against the black-hearted bastard who stole my ship and left me to die in the middle of the ocean -- twice! -- and who knows how to get what he wants.  Now that's a great pirate.

lines.speaker: u2472
lines.text: That Jack Sparrow ... he talked about the Black Pearl.

lines.speaker: u2471
lines.text: Mentioned it, is more what he did.

lines.speaker: u2472
lines.text: Still --

lines.speaker: u2475
lines.text: Commodore --

lines.speaker: u2473
lines.text: A moment.

lines.speaker: u2475
lines.text: But --

lines.speaker: u2473
lines.text: Please.

lines.speaker: u2475
lines.text: Dammit, man, it appears someone is stealing your ship!

lines.speaker: u2477
lines.text: It'll be better for us if he simply disappears.  The gardener will know what to do.

lines.speaker: u2480
lines.text: Wait, wait, can I at least have his body?

lines.speaker: u2477
lines.text: Donated to science.  Perfect.

lines.speaker: u2481
lines.text: Here, kid, this is great stuff.  Why don't you give it a try?

lines.speaker: u2478
lines.text: I want Trix!  Mommy!

lines.speaker: u2481
lines.text: What is it with you litterbugs?  Is it a territorial thing, marking your turf with your garbage?

lines.speaker: u2479
lines.text: You better quit pushing me, pal.

lines.speaker: u2481
lines.text: I just want to know what goes on in the mind of a litterbug.  What chemical is secreted by your smooth brain that tells you, 'It's okay, just chuck it'?

lines.speaker: u2479
lines.text: Look, asshole, I don't got time for this.  If you got a problem, you better take care of it yourself.

lines.speaker: u2481
lines.text: Oh no, no, no.  No can do.  You enjoyed a tasty beverage and thus this receptacle becomes your responsibility and I don't care if it's a Styrofoam cup or the Exxon Valdez!  You've got to learn to take responsibility!

lines.speaker: u2479
lines.text: What are you going to do?  Make me throw it out?

lines.speaker: u2481
lines.text: I'll do whatever I have to do.

lines.speaker: u2480
lines.text: Susan!

lines.speaker: u2483
lines.text: Wellie well, Dr. Bright.  You're just in time.

lines.speaker: u2483
lines.text: Maybe you're ready to find out if that hide of yours is bulletproof?

lines.speaker: u2481
lines.text: The question is, are you?

lines.speaker: u2484
lines.text: Okay, Barbie, let's get this over with.

lines.speaker: u2482
lines.text: Don't worry, four eyes.

lines.speaker: u2484
lines.text: What in the hell?

lines.speaker: u2483
lines.text: Pipe down, brain lady!  And you...

lines.speaker: u2485
lines.text: Why doesn't Dexter show some decency? And you might show some too, Mother. What do you expect a man to do when he's called such names?  I'm glad you hit that reporter, Stewart. He deserved it.

lines.speaker: u2493
lines.text: All right, all right! It's your funeral, Anne Schuyler!

lines.speaker: u2486
lines.text: Well, Stew, that's all thrashed out. By golly, I'm surely glad to see that you're not really sore. You know our racket - after all, news is news.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: Sure, sure. That's all right. That was a great story, Bingy. A great story - wish I'd printed it.

lines.speaker: u2486
lines.text: I gave you the breaks, didn't I? That hairy chest story!

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: You've raised it up to the chin, I see.  Go on in the other room and get yourself a drink.

lines.speaker: u2487
lines.text: Well, I'm sorry to see a good reporter go blooey  Let me know when you're quitting.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: I'm not quitting!

lines.speaker: u2487
lines.text: No?

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: No!

lines.speaker: u2487
lines.text: 'For he's only a bird in a gilded cage, a beautiful sight to see'  Tweet, tweet - ha, ha

lines.speaker: u2488
lines.text: That's a canary, sir.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: That's a canary! Who brought that in here? Canary, huh? Go on, get that out of here. Get that out of here!

lines.speaker: u2488
lines.text: Yes, sir. Very good, sir.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: A bird! A bird in a gilded cage! Get that thing out of here!

lines.speaker: u2488
lines.text: Yes sir!

lines.speaker: u2489
lines.text: What other girl?

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: The little O'Brien girl, of course - the one you suggested in the story.

lines.speaker: u2489
lines.text: But that's ridiculous! You can't make a sudden change like that.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: Gallagher, what are you going to do - tell me how to write a play?

lines.speaker: u2489
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: There's nothing sudden about that  He's always loved the girl, but he was such a sap he didn't have sense enough to tell her. Well, that's all right - we can fix that. He will go to the little O'Brien girl, and - here, I'll show you.

lines.speaker: u2490
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: And now for that twentieth crack

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: I'm sorry nobody could come.

lines.speaker: u2491
lines.text: The rest of the gang had to get out the morning edition - but they'll be down later.

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: Now Hank, are you sure they're coming?  It will be lonesome without them.  Smythe, take this crowd in there and give them a drink. And find out what the boys in the back room want!

lines.speaker: u2493
lines.text: What's going on here? Who is this woman?

lines.speaker: u2495
lines.text: Joan of Arc! What's it to you?

lines.speaker: u2493
lines.text: Heavens! The man's insane!
