lines.speaker: u6176
lines.text: What happened?

lines.speaker: u6180
lines.text: _Krueger_...

lines.speaker: u6176
lines.text: Who?

lines.speaker: u6180
lines.text: Come on.

lines.speaker: u6180
lines.text: And this hand... it... it slashed Doctor Layton's throat... and the Deputy. Then it grabbed Danny by the head...  And it pulled his head right down into his chest... I couldn't... Hayes lays a hand his shoulder.

lines.speaker: u6177
lines.text: Take it easy, Ruby...	it's all right.  Now, try to think clearly... don't you mean _Jason's_ hand... don't you mean he grabbed a scalpel and slashed Doctor Layton's throat?

lines.speaker: u6180
lines.text: Did you find a scalpel? Did you find a murder weapon?

lines.speaker: u6180
lines.text: "Zombie Sluts From Beyond the Grave."

lines.speaker: u6179
lines.text: A seminal film. First ever depiction of a fully nude triple impalement.

lines.speaker: u6181
lines.text: What happened? Where's Jason?

lines.speaker: u6180
lines.text: My client... is dead.  But I think he's a free man.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: It's only majestic from here. When you get closer you see it for what it really is.

lines.speaker: u6182
lines.text: What is it really?

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: A glorified office block.  They keep all the old records there -- the final resting place for facts and figures that have ceased to matter in the world of the living.

lines.speaker: u6182
lines.text: Well, as long as I admire it from afar it shouldn't worry me if it's hollow.

lines.speaker: u6183
lines.text: Fine -- terrible.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: What was the matter with it?

lines.speaker: u6195
lines.text: Yours is a very powerful and important firm -- it has a lot at stake.

lines.speaker: u6184
lines.text: Perhaps Eduard was closer than he knew to discovering it and so had to be silenced.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: -- You appreciate my writing.

lines.speaker: u6185
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: Will you do me a favor then?

lines.speaker: u6185
lines.text: Another one?

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: If I don't see you later -- go to my house and find my notebooks -- and destroy them.  All my manuscripts -- just burn them. Please.

lines.speaker: u6185
lines.text: What an extraordinary request!

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: It's my last and final one.

lines.speaker: u6185
lines.text: Then its authority is in doubt.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: A true friend would do it.

lines.speaker: u6185
lines.text: Not necessarily.  A <u>wife</u> would.

lines.speaker: u6186
lines.text: Good morning --  Or should I say good afternoon?

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: Say what you like -- no one pays the least attention.

lines.speaker: u6186
lines.text: Oh, don't they?  I think you underestimate my station in this office and overrate your own.

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: Not today, Burgel.  Send one of your memos, write up one of your communiques, but for God's sake don't bother me today.

lines.speaker: u6186
lines.text: It's my place to offer advice, not yours -- and by advising the Chief Clerk of your unpunctuality it's certainly not my situation that's compromised, if that's what you're implying.

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: You're just doing your job.

lines.speaker: u6186
lines.text: It's what I'm paid to do.

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: You're detestable.

lines.speaker: u6186
lines.text: And you're late!

lines.speaker: u6187
lines.text: Was there something else?

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: No -- I just -- I feel a sense of obligation.  He was my friend -- if I can be of any help -- closing his affairs.

lines.speaker: u6187
lines.text: No, there's only one report to complete.  I'll be doing it myself and submitting it to the Castle today or tomorrow.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: I see -- it's just the Erlanger claim then.

lines.speaker: u6187
lines.text: The <u>Orlac</u> claim.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: Sorry, yes -- well -- thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: I think you've just escaped for the moment.  Just as I did.  As Eduard did.  As they let us do. But only for the moment.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: No -- not this time.

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: I know better than you what people will say when they have to.  When they brought me in for questioning I informed on my friends the very first day.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: -- Listen to me --

lines.speaker: u6188
lines.text: I do.  Always.  You understand the world better than any of us, Kafka.  And what it's becoming.  I've always held you in the highest regard.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: Maybe it's true then what she said.

lines.speaker: u6189
lines.text: What did she say?

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: That the police may have allegiance to something other than truth.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: All these in the last year?

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: You must have read about it in the papers -- there was a terrible cave-in.  It wouldn't have been so bad, but even the Medical Officer for the district was killed!

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: I did read that.  They gave him a posthumous medal.

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: Dr. Murnau was the bravest of men. He spent an entire career in those backwaters with no regard for personal gain.  A great loss.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: This is the cross-reference of clerks who've worked on Orlac claims?

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: Is your friend's name among them?  Then he only worked on the one case.  Your Chief will send me the final summation when he's finished with it.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: Once a file's been sent to the Caste, is it possible to recall it for review?

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: Of course not.  Only by a Director of the firm.  Who'd want to let in all kinds of riff-raff off the streets?

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: What good are records if they're not open for public inspection?

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: These laws have been with us for centuries -- how can you doubt them?

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: What if I petitioned one of the Directors?

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: You do not summon them -- they summon you -- and this, of course, hardly ever happens, if at all. The Directors are an eccentric lot and by nature cautious.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: Where do our records go to in the Castle?

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: We're a medical firm, aren't we? They go to the Medical Records Section.

lines.speaker: u6190
lines.text: I could always apply there.

lines.speaker: u6191
lines.text: It so happens, my dear simple sir, that the Head of Medical Records at the Castle <u>is</u> one of the Directors of this firm.

lines.speaker: u6194
lines.text: Then that's the place for us!

lines.speaker: u6192
lines.text: Amerika for us!

lines.speaker: u6194
lines.text: Amerika!

lines.speaker: u6199
lines.text: Ann ... Ann!

lines.speaker: u6196
lines.text: It' s alright Jack ... it' s alright.

lines.speaker: u6197
lines.text: It must have been terrifying?

lines.speaker: u6199
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u6200
lines.text: Are you gonna start it up?

lines.speaker: u6199
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u6200
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u6199
lines.text: Coz of something I lost.

lines.speaker: u6200
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: u6199
lines.text: Compassion.

lines.speaker: u6200
lines.text: What's compassion, mister.

lines.speaker: u6204
lines.text: Honey, a couple of years ago, with Jane and Frankie? -- Jane sent me a Dumper --

lines.speaker: u6203
lines.text: Please, if he sees you, he won't come!

lines.speaker: u6204
lines.text: Arlyn, just tell me, did Jane have a dumper, one of her regular Johns?

lines.speaker: u6203
lines.text: What about him? Yes.

lines.speaker: u6204
lines.text: Did he come around often?

lines.speaker: u6204
lines.text: Can I carry something for you, to the car?  Will you kiss me?

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: No. I'm sore.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: Well --

lines.speaker: u6205
lines.text: Tomorrow. See you tomorrow night.

lines.speaker: u6206
lines.text: I'm sure the FBI and the Police explored that possibility.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: No. They never did, really. But that's what I'm going to recommend. The next step. Unless something --

lines.speaker: u6206
lines.text: Have you discussed this with them?

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: It's in the report.

lines.speaker: u6206
lines.text: Do they have the report? Have you discussed it with them?

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: I wanted to give it to you first.

lines.speaker: u6206
lines.text: All right. All right --  John, just sit tight will you? I'll read your report, I'll discuss it with the others. I'll be back next Thursday, we'll talk the whole thing over then. Nothing til Thursday, all right?

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: All right.

lines.speaker: u6206
lines.text: Thank you. Goodbye, John.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: Goodbye, Pete.

lines.speaker: u6207
lines.text: OK, a family matter. Between the girls. I had two other cows --  -- two other girls besides Bree.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: She told me.

lines.speaker: u6207
lines.text: OK and one of them  Jane McKenna -- she blows a little jealous of Bree - you know? -- Bree comes first? And evidently she knew the freak --- that he was a dumper -- she conned me into passing him to Bree, you know, so Bree'd get hurt. I didn't know. Till afterwards.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: Why didn't you tell Bree, afterwards?

lines.speaker: u6207
lines.text: You don't tell them. That one of their own in-laws laid a dumper on them?  Peace in the family.  Beyond that, I don't know. All she wrote.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: I'd like to talk with Jane McKenna.

lines.speaker: u6207
lines.text: Would I be telling you all this? She copped out long ago. She committed suicide Baxter.

lines.speaker: u6214
lines.text: It's damn lucky you didn't have the dossier on Cable here.

lines.speaker: u6208
lines.text: Nobody's seen that.

lines.speaker: u6214
lines.text: If we get anything from the lab, we'll have it by noon. And just think -- all he really had to do was write us a letter.

lines.speaker: u6213
lines.text: Klute knew Tom. He has a great many ideas about the case --

lines.speaker: u6211
lines.text: Yes sir, we know he --

lines.speaker: u6213
lines.text: We'd expect him to work in cooperation with you. He'd report to each of you and to our Company's New York office, to Pete -- Pete goes there on a regular schedule back and forth, and --

lines.speaker: u6211
lines.text: Mr. Streiger, speaking frankly -- we've appreciated the Sergeant's interest you know, all along. Here, locally. But New York, that's - well --

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: He hits me on the planet Kriptarium, when I steal the buried treasure from the famous peanut butter factory.

lines.speaker: u6216
lines.text: In real life when does he hit you?

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: My daddy doesn't hit me, silly. Why would my daddy hit me?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Billy, sometimes when a mother and a father are divorced, there's a discussion about who the child should live with, the mother or the father.  Now there is a man who is very wise.  He's called a judge.  And a judge has a lot of experience with divorces and he decides who it would be best for the child to live with.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Why does he decide?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Because...Well, that's what he does.  He's a very powerful man.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Like a principal?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Bigger than a principal.  The judge sits in robes in a big chair.. The judge has thought a lot about us, about you and me and your mom, and he has decided...  ...he has decided that it would be best for you to live with your mom Joanna in her apartment.  And I'm very lucky.  Because even though you'll live with your mom Joanna I'll get to see you once a week for dinner and a couple of weekends a month.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: I don't understand, daddy.

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: What don't you understand, pal?

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Where will my bed be, where will I sleep?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: At your mom's.  She'll have a bed for you in your own room.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Where will my toys be?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: I'll send your toys there and I'm sure you'll get some new ones.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Who will read me my stories?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Your mom.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Daddy, what if The Face comes when I'm at mommy's?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Your mom knows all about The Face, okay?  Don't worry, she'll tell The Face to beat it.

lines.speaker: u6217
lines.text: Will you come and say good-night to me every night?

lines.speaker: u6222
lines.text: Ted was a good worker.  But, ah... ... after his wife left him and he was taking care of the kid on his own, things started to change. Look, I know he had problems, I understand that.  I've got problems, everybody's got problems.  But I've got a shop to run, I can't let that kind of thing get in the way...  I guess I felt that Ted was letting his duties at home interfere with his responsibilities in the office.

lines.speaker: u6218
lines.text: Thank you.  I have no further questions.

lines.speaker: u6219
lines.text: There might be something at J. Walter Thompson.  But...  ...I don't think they're really serious.  The position's been open for two months and...  They may just be on a fishing expedition.  I'm sure you'll be much happier if you wait until after the first--

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Call up the people at J. Walter Thompson.  Set up an appointment at four.

lines.speaker: u6219
lines.text: Mis-ter Kramer, it's...  ...almost four now.  It's the Friday before Christmas.  Nobody is going to want to--

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Either you call and set up the appointment, or I'll call.  And if I call, you lose the commission.

lines.speaker: u6219
lines.text: My, we are a hot shot aren't we?

lines.speaker: u6220
lines.text: Okay...I think I'll go talk to my son now.  How do I look?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Beautiful.

lines.speaker: u6222
lines.text: Disappointing.  It only pulled a fourteen share and they were hoping for a twenty-five minimum, and...ah...they're not very happy and...Well, the guys have decided they want to...ah, re-think the entire concept and...Look, I don't like having to do this, okay?... But...I mean, what I mean is...ah, I'm going to have to...ah, let you go--

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Are you firing me, Jim?

lines.speaker: u6223
lines.text: It's a very good job--too good to pass up.  I'll be handling funding for the whole...  Look, I...  ..."like" you a lot.  And you...  ..."like" me, okay?  Maybe if it was a year from now, maybe things would be different...

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: But it's not a year from now, is it?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u6224
lines.text: Walk him over to Bethesda Fountain, buy him an ice.  It'll kill twenty minutes.

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: I've got a lot more than twenty minutes to kill.

lines.speaker: u6224
lines.text: Tough...  ...I get off duty at five-thirty.  How long you been divorced?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Three months.  How can you tell?

lines.speaker: u6224
lines.text: You've got that look.  My lady and I split two years ago in August and I'm an old pro at this shit.  First thing, stay away from the Children's Zoo.  It's pure hell--if I never see another chicken, I'll be happy.  I'm here, darling.  Don't worry...

lines.speaker: u6225
lines.text: Mr. O'Connor called.  There's a meeting with the Revlon people in the board room and you're fifteen minutes late.

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: I know....I know.

lines.speaker: u6225
lines.text: Mr. Schmidt can't have the figures on the television buy until Monday.

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: No.  Uh, uh.  Tell him I asked for it Friday.  I want it Friday. Period.

lines.speaker: u6225
lines.text: Mr. Lombardo from packaging wants to meet on Friday.

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Fine.

lines.speaker: u6226
lines.text: Mrs. Phillips, how long have you known Ted Kramer?

lines.speaker: u6231
lines.text: Six years.  Ever since Ted and Joanna moved into the building.

lines.speaker: u6226
lines.text: How often do you see Mr. Kramer and his son?

lines.speaker: u6231
lines.text: Charley, my husband, and I are ...divorced and Kim, that's our daughter is about Billy's age and the children play together a lot.  So, I guess we see each three or four times a week.

lines.speaker: u6226
lines.text: Can you describe the relationship between Mr. Kramer and his son?

lines.speaker: u6231
lines.text: It's beautiful.  It's just beautiful. They have a beautiful relationship.

lines.speaker: u6227
lines.text: You ever see her talk to the walls?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: No, but--

lines.speaker: u6227
lines.text: Then you don't have a choice. Have Billy at the Seventy- Fifth Street entrance to Central Park, Saturday at ten.

lines.speaker: u6228
lines.text: Now, I'd advise you to wait outside.  It'll be eas--

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u6228
lines.text: Mr. Kramer, there's--

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Fuck you.  He's my son.  I'm staying with him.

lines.speaker: u6232
lines.text: Huh.. .Hello?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: All right, Thelma...That's it. I've had it.  You can call your good friend Joanna Kramer and tell her enough is enough, okay?  I mean, I don't know what I did, but you can tell her she's made her point.

lines.speaker: u6232
lines.text: Ted, what are you talking about?!

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Don't play innocent with me, Thelma.  You know perfectly well what's going on.

lines.speaker: u6232
lines.text: Ted, I don't understand a word you're saying.  Where's Joanna?

lines.speaker: u6230
lines.text: Ha!  You tell me.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: I worry about them.

lines.speaker: u6233
lines.text: Do not worry, Holiness. They fight for you. They are under your protection.

lines.speaker: u6253
lines.text: And that day, your father got better. He named you Lhamo. "The Protector."

lines.speaker: u6234
lines.text: I know.

lines.speaker: u6235
lines.text: Goodbye, Kundun.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: No!

lines.speaker: u6236
lines.text: Plans for absorbing the Tibetan army into the People's Army will soon be finalized.

lines.speaker: u6243
lines.text: I will not approve it.

lines.speaker: u6236
lines.text: Then, we will begin with replacing the Tibetan flag with the flag of the Motherland.

lines.speaker: u6243
lines.text: And we will begin with tearing it down.

lines.speaker: u6237
lines.text: Do you have plans to return soon, Dalai Lama?

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Soon.

lines.speaker: u6237
lines.text: Good. Our first request is that you allow us to build a road. You have no roads in Tibet. We can discuss the plans in Lhasa. When you return.

lines.speaker: u6238
lines.text: Your Prime Ministers, support the proposal that you return to Lhasa. On the opposite hand, some officials urge you not to return. They believe you should leave now, for India.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: If I were to go into exile, could we expect any serious assistance, from India, suppose?

lines.speaker: u6239
lines.text: Who am I?

lines.speaker: u6246
lines.text: We do not know.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: I need to squeeze this brain.

lines.speaker: u6240
lines.text: Answer.

lines.speaker: u6241
lines.text: You can't do anything real until you are Dalai Lama.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: I am him.

lines.speaker: u6241
lines.text: Not until you are eighteen.

lines.speaker: u6242
lines.text: We are now accused of aiding the rebels. The Chinese said we can expect drastic measures to be taken to crush this revolt.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Arrange for me to speak to the people's leaders.

lines.speaker: u6246
lines.text: Good day.

lines.speaker: u6244
lines.text: Good day.

lines.speaker: u6246
lines.text: Please, come in, so cold.

lines.speaker: u6244
lines.text: We are traveling to Lhasa. May we...?

lines.speaker: u6246
lines.text: Of course, please, this way. Your servant may use the kitchen.

lines.speaker: u6244
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: I have been greatly impressed by your accomplishments. Industrial progress. Great efficiency. Your people are capable and courteous.

lines.speaker: u6245
lines.text: You have a lot to learn about organization. How to draw out people's opinions. How to make key decisions. Train your young Tibetans. When I make contact with you, I want to reach you through a Tibetan.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Always.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Do you think I must?

lines.speaker: u6246
lines.text: You decide.

lines.speaker: u6247
lines.text: What does the butter spot feel like?

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Soft. Nice. I have a good friend back in Lhasa.

lines.speaker: u6248
lines.text: You must study very hard, do not neglect the holy things during this time.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: I will miss you.

lines.speaker: u6248
lines.text: We have had fun, you and I. Fun for a little boy in an old palace.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: We have.

lines.speaker: u6248
lines.text: You have grown up very good.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: And you have grown older and your chin has grown balder.

lines.speaker: u6249
lines.text: You are in great danger. The Dalai Lama cannot fall into Chinese hands. You must flee.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: How could I ever leave?

lines.speaker: u6249
lines.text: It may not be your decision to make.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: What should I do about my doubt, Teacher?

lines.speaker: u6250
lines.text: It is a difficult situation.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: I mean, my doubt. Why me? Am I Him?

lines.speaker: u6250
lines.text: Doubt is an affliction. Reliquish it. Accept.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u6252
lines.text: Too young?

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Much too young.

lines.speaker: u6252
lines.text: Look for a strong woman, not too occupied with her beauty. Look for a woman who keeps her hands busy. Look for a kind heart.

lines.speaker: u6251
lines.text: Like my mother.

lines.speaker: u6252
lines.text: I see that.

lines.speaker: u6254
lines.text: I'll sue you.

lines.speaker: u6259
lines.text: Go ahead.

lines.speaker: u6255
lines.text: Go!!!

lines.speaker: u6256
lines.text: <u>I'm</u> <u>trying</u>!!!

lines.speaker: u6256
lines.text: He's gonna live?

lines.speaker: u6258
lines.text: Yeah.  Thanks to you.

lines.speaker: u6256
lines.text: And Hank.  I know you weren't really trying to hit him.

lines.speaker: u6259
lines.text: Thanks for your help.

lines.speaker: u6257
lines.text: You too.

lines.speaker: u6258
lines.text: You don't know what to say, lucky for you action speaks louder than words.

lines.speaker: u6261
lines.text: Kelly--

lines.speaker: u6258
lines.text: I'm not upset, Myra, okay.  I just never thought of you as a y'know...

lines.speaker: u6261
lines.text: Backstabber?

lines.speaker: u6258
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u6261
lines.text: Liar?

lines.speaker: u6258
lines.text: Myra.

lines.speaker: u6261
lines.text: Shitbutt?

lines.speaker: u6258
lines.text: I really... I should get back.

lines.speaker: u6262
lines.text: Agent Starling! Telephone!

lines.speaker: u6266
lines.text: Agent Mapp! Thank you!

lines.speaker: u6263
lines.text: Wear it, don't ever leave it in your purse. Dry fire it whenever you get the chance. And do your exercises.

lines.speaker: u6266
lines.text: I will... I promise.

lines.speaker: u6263
lines.text: Listen, I hope you never need a thing I've taught you. But you've got something... Jack sees it, I do too. If you ever need to, you can shoot.

lines.speaker: u6266
lines.text: FBI, Catherine, you're safe.

lines.speaker: u6264
lines.text: Safe, SHIT, he's got a gun! Getmeout. GET ME OUT!

lines.speaker: u6265
lines.text: He's my patient! I have rights!  I'm not just some turnkey, Miss Starling. I shouldn't even be here this afternoon. I had a ticket to Holiday on Ice.

lines.speaker: u6269
lines.text: Your lambs are still for now, Clarice, but not forever... You'll have to earn it again and again, this blessed silence. Because it's the plight that drives you, and the plight will never end.

lines.speaker: u6266

lines.speaker: u6269
lines.text: I have no plans to call on you, Clarice, the world being more interesting with you in it. Be sure you extend me the same courtesy.

lines.text: You know I can't make that promise.

lines.speaker: u6269
lines.text: Goodbye, Clarice...  You looked - so very lovely today, in your blue suit.

lines.speaker: u6267
lines.text: Look... search your own records, if you prefer. You can do it a lot faster than us, anyway. If we find Buffalo Bill through your information, I'll suppress it. Nobody has to know this hospital cooperated.

lines.speaker: u6268
lines.text: I doubt very much that the FBI or any other government agency can keep a secret, Mr. Crawford. Truth will out... And then what? Will you give Johns Hopkins a new identity? Put a big pair of sunglasses on this building, and a funny nose?

lines.speaker: u6267
lines.text: Oh, that's clever, Dr. Danielson. Very humorous. You like the truth? Try this.  He kidnaps young women and kills them and rips their skin off. We don't want him to do that anymore. If you don't help me, just as fast as you can, then the Justice Department is going to ask publicly for a court order, We'll ask twice a day, just in time for the morning and evening news. And each one of our press conferences will focus on Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins, and how we're still hoping for his cooperation. And every time there's any news on the case - when Catherine Martin floats, when the next one floats, and the next one - why, we'll just issue another press release about good ol' Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins - complete with all his humorous fucking remarks.

lines.speaker: u6268
lines.text: It may be that - I could confer with my colleagues on this. And get back to you.

lines.speaker: u6267

lines.text: Magua slept hard in the English wigwams.  And the sticks left their mark...  Magua's village and lodges were burnt. Magua's children were killed by the English.  Magua was taken as a slave by the Mohawks who fought for the Grey Hair. Magua's wife believed he was dead and became the wife of another. The Grey Hair was the father of all this.  In time Magua became blood-brother to Mohawk to become free. In his heart he always was Huron.  And his heart will be whole again on the day when the Grey Hair and all his seed are dead!

lines.speaker: u6351

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Wasn't legal to sell liquor in a glass back then unless you was a club, see. Roderick used to say, "Buy yourself a drink, you get a free membership." But Sheriff Wade, he could shut you down anytime.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: And my father?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Sheriff Buddy was a different story. Long as Roderick throw his weight the right way on election day, make sure all the colored get out to vote- we was called colored back then, if you was polite--maybe throw a barbecue for the right people now and then, things was peaceful. That Sheriff Wade, though, he took an awful big bite.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: People didn't complain?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Not if they was colored or Meskin. Not if they wanted to keep breathin'.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Do you remember the last time you saw him?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I don't think you can take it personally--

lines.speaker: u6343
lines.text: I'd like to see them spend a day pulling 14-year-olds off of each other--I should get combat pay--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I have new respect for some of my kids, meeting the parents they've been dealt--

lines.speaker: u6344
lines.text: I'm not open. We were just talking.

lines.speaker: u6344

lines.text: Can I get this?

lines.text: Out in the fresh air, nice gringo lady making you pies--who's gonna sit back in a little jail cell all day? Sheriff Buddy, man. Como el no hay dos. And after that cabron Charley Wade--

lines.text: This isn't Houston, my friend. We pretty much running things now. Our good day has come.

lines.text: What's this I see? Is that whiskey in them glasses on the Bar? Roderick, I'm gonna have to cite you for a violation of state law--

lines.text: If he hadn't found that Deputy job, I believe Buddy might've gone down the other path, got into some serious trouble. Settled him right down. That and your mother. 'Course he had that other one later.

lines.text: Your mother wasn't one to get chased off her patch. Half the damn county knew and nobody thought the worse of her for seein' it through.

lines.speaker: u6354
lines.text: The other one? Hell, at my age, every time you learn a new name you got to forget an old one. Your head's all crowded up--here it is--

lines.speaker: u6954

lines.text: Yeah, I'm kidding, I'm kidding. You don't think I should turn him in... .

lines.speaker: u6967
lines.text: But I ain't out. I'm in. I'm in. Who's lying to who?

lines.speaker: u6959
lines.text: You ought to go home and take care of that

lines.speaker: u6967

lines.speaker: u6960
lines.text: Well I got to watch myself these days. Know what I mean?

lines.speaker: u6967
lines.text: I'll bring him up to your loft.

lines.speaker: u6960
lines.text: I'll see you on the roof.

lines.speaker: u6967
lines.text: You want to know something? Take the heater away and you're nothin' take the good goods away, and the kickback and the shakedown cabbage away and the pistoleros  away and you're a great big hunk of nothing  Your guts is all in your wallet and your trigger finger!

lines.speaker: u6961
lines.text: Go on talkin'. You're talkin' yourself right into the river. Go on, go on... .

lines.speaker: u6967
lines.text: I'm glad what I done today, see? You give it to Joey, you give it to Nolan, you give it to Charley who was one of your own. You thought you was God Almighty instead of a cheap connivinggood-for-nothing bum! So I'm glad what I done you hear me? glad what I done!

lines.speaker: u6961
lines.text: You ratted on us, Terry.

lines.speaker: u6967
lines.text: From where you stand, maybe. But I'm standing over here now. I was rattin' on myself all them years and didn't know it, helpin' punks like you against people like Pop and Nolan an'... .

lines.text: Jack --

lines.text: Call and tell you.

lines.speaker: u6976
lines.text: And you let them come up.  You don't try to make the bust yourself.  You understand?

lines.speaker: u6977
lines.text: You see what they doing, those posts out there?  Putting up another fence, five metres on the other side of the one that's there.  We wait until Super Bowl Sunday, they could have the second fence built and we have to dig another nine, ten days.  So we going soon as it's dark.  You want -- I mean it -- you can still come.

lines.speaker: u6980
lines.text: I appreciate the offer.  And it's tempting.

lines.speaker: u6979
lines.text: Karen, I told you not to--

lines.text: Wait, I know him --okay?

lines.text: Islamic.

lines.text: What's it mean, "No Hair"?

lines.text: The Hejira was the flight of Mohammed from Mecca in 622.

lines.text: The flight?

lines.speaker: u6982

lines.text: Meaning?

lines.text: Meaning time came, I left.

lines.speaker: u6982
lines.text: That time?

lines.speaker: u6982

It sounds like you're saying it's okay as long as her husband doesn't find out about it.  Like the guy who cheats on his wife, saying what she doesn't know won't hurt her.

lines.text: If you're patching up bullet holes right here on the runway, maybe we should skip the housekeeping and get right to the planes.

lines.text: That was a nice little stunt you pulled, buzzing the base.

lines.text: You liked that?

lines.speaker: u7000
lines.text: Sir?

lines.text: I don't buy that hot dog shit.  So you and your buddies are gonna transfer your planes up to Haleiwa.

lines.speaker: u6998

lines.speaker: u7000
lines.text: Sir, I --

lines.speaker: u6998
lines.text: Too late for apologies, Walker.

lines.speaker: u6999
lines.text: Shit, he's puking on my feet!

lines.text: Hang on.

lines.text: Listen you guys.  I'm the first plane -- then McCawley, Walker, the rest of you. I'll have the shortest run.  If I don't make it, you don't go.

lines.text: It was.  I couldn't have you go away, wherever it is...to war...without knowing something.  You think I made a choice, of Danny over you.  I didn't.  I didn't have a choice.  I'm pregnant.

lines.text: If we launch the third wave and annihilate their fuel depots, we destroy their ability to operate in the Pacific for at least a year!

lines.speaker: u7013
lines.text: And if we fail, and lose our carriers, we destroy our ability to fight them at all.  As soon as the second wave returns, we will withdraw.

lines.speaker: u7006
lines.text: We have bombed Tokyo, Mr. President. Radio Tokyo interrupted it's own broadcast to make the announcement.

lines.speaker: u7012
lines.text: Have the planes made it to China?

lines.speaker: u7006
lines.text: There've been some complications, Sir. The Chinese didn't receive our request for homing beacons until is was too late to get them set.  And the planes had to take off so early they may lack fuel to make the mainland anyway.

lines.speaker: u7012
lines.text: So those brave men are flying blind and running out of fuel.

lines.speaker: u7006
lines.text: The Chinese are sending out search parties to try to find the crews before the Jap patrols do, if any of the planes make it.

lines.speaker: u7012
lines.text: God help them.

lines.text: I have'na been able ta --

lines.speaker: u7010

lines.text: You have something to say, Yamamoto?

lines.speaker: u7013
lines.text: The Council knows I have opposed fighting the Americans.  No matter how great our resolve, they have resources beyond ours. If we must go to war, there is only one way -- deal them a blow from which it will take them years to recover.  In that time we can conquer all of the Pacific, and they will have no choice but to ask for peace.

lines.speaker: u7009
lines.text: You see us as capable of such a blow?

lines.speaker: u7013
lines.text: The Americans themselves have made it possible.  We will annihilate them in a single attack -- at Pearl Harbor.

lines.speaker: u7026

lines.text: Vision? I'm a walking anachronism! I've upset my parents. I miss my kids. I could be trapped here forever! And poor Charlie...I got pregnant on my 18th birthday and we had to get married. Tomorrow's my birthday! I've got to get out of here now.

lines.text: Did you break up with Charlie?

lines.speaker: u7025

lines.speaker: u7025
lines.text: No! No! No! Peggy Sue got married! Case closed. I don't want to marry anybody. Goodbye Richard.
