lines.text: Startin' to acclimate, anyhow. Take it.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: We'd better get started. If the mounted police pick up our trail, they'll come this far at least.

lines.speaker: u7063
lines.text: Right.  Let's put the water and provisions in the wagon.

lines.speaker: u7072
lines.text: Well, at least they haven't tried to bite us.

lines.speaker: u7064
lines.text: Blessed are the vegetarians.

lines.speaker: u7065
lines.text: But the quota system's been abolished! You made it. Why can't I?

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: What do you mean, made it? I'm an animal psychologist, that's all. We don't have any authority.

lines.speaker: u7065
lines.text: You do pretty well when it comes to getting space and equipment.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: That's because Dr. Zaius realizes our work has value.

lines.speaker: u7065
lines.text: Hmph.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: The foundations of scientific brain surgery are being laid right here - in studies of cerebral function in these animals.

lines.speaker: u7065
lines.text: They're still dirty. And their bite is septic. Look at that ...

lines.speaker: u7066
lines.text: Tell the court, Bright Eyes -- what is the second Article of Faith?

lines.speaker: u7072
lines.text: I admit, I know nothing of your culture.

lines.speaker: u7066
lines.text: Of course he doesn't know our culture - because he cannot think.  Tell us why all apes are created equal.

lines.speaker: u7072
lines.text: Some apes, it seems, are more equal than others.

lines.speaker: u7066
lines.text: Ridiculous. That answer is a contradiction in terms. Tell us, Bright Eyes, why do men have no souls? What is the proof that a divine spark exists in the simian brain?

lines.speaker: u7072
lines.text: Show this to the President.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: Get me a collar and leash. I'm taking him to the infirmary.

lines.speaker: u7067
lines.text: He's vicious, Doctor. Besides, it's against the rules.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: Do as I say.

lines.speaker: u7068
lines.text: We got off at the wrong stop.

lines.speaker: u7072
lines.text: You're our optimist Look at the bright side. If that's the best there is around here, in six months we'll be running this planet.

lines.speaker: u7069
lines.text: Who put them up?

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: The Hunt Club.

lines.speaker: u7069
lines.text: To scare off humans?

lines.speaker: u7070
lines.text: You asked for the opportunity to present your case. Surely you must know why you're here.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: My own purpose is to save this exceptional creature from mutilation.

lines.speaker: u7070
lines.text: And our purpose is to settle custodial and jurisdictional questions concerning this beast, and determine what's to be done with him.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: At the very least, this man has the right to know whether there's a charge against him.

lines.speaker: u7071
lines.text: Sustained.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: Sustain all objections, but face the truth!

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: Go with God, Taylor.  That's an old expression. it comes from both ape and man.

lines.speaker: u7072
lines.text: God bless you.

lines.speaker: u7074
lines.text: But the proof? The doll?

lines.speaker: u7073
lines.text: In a few minutes there will be no doll. There can't be.  I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u7085
lines.text: Uh... Bob. Like to speak to you. Take a minute.

lines.speaker: u7075
lines.text: Yeah, what is it?

lines.speaker: u7085
lines.text: Bob, I got Elias' R&R... It's coming up in 3 days. Going to Hawaii. See Patsy.  I never asked you for a break, I was hoping you... you'd send me in on the chopper with King... what do you say Chief?

lines.speaker: u7075
lines.text: I can't do that for you, Red... We need every swinging dick in the field. Sorry bout that...

lines.speaker: u7085
lines.text: Hey Bob, come on! Talk to me hunh, it's your friend Red, I'm only asking you for three days chief...

lines.speaker: u7075
lines.text: I'm talking to you Red and I'm telling you no. Get back to your position.

lines.speaker: u7085
lines.text: Bob, I gotta bad feeling about this, I... I'm telling you I got a bad feeling, man, I don't think I'm gonna make it... y'know what I mean?

lines.speaker: u7075
lines.text: ...everybody gotta die sometime Red... Get back to your foxhole.

lines.speaker: u7082
lines.text: Don babytalk him man. Cocksucker fell asleep. They walked right up on us, he don do shit.

lines.speaker: u7076
lines.text: Shaddup bitch.

lines.speaker: u7077
lines.text: Come on you can do better than that!

lines.speaker: u7082
lines.text: Fuck this shit! I ain't dyin' in no white man's war! Ise didi-ing this motherfuckah!

lines.speaker: u7078
lines.text: Hey that's great King, that's great... you take it on home for me, you tell 'em King... got your address right? You know where you can reach men, man. Anytime!

lines.speaker: u7083
lines.text: I gotta didi man. Don't wanna miss that chopper. I'll send you a postcard. After I get me some. I'll send you some tapes too man. This new guy Jimi Hendrix man, whew... you okay Taylor? Just 'member take it easy now, don't think too much, don't be a fool, no such thing as a coward cause it don't mean nuthin. Jes keep on keepin' on. Okay my man...

lines.speaker: u7083
lines.text: What we got here a crusader?

lines.speaker: u7079
lines.text: Sounds like it.

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: Sounds pretty far out to me 'Lias.

lines.speaker: u7080
lines.text: Maybe but I seen it happen at Ia Drang in '66, First Cavalry and they cut us to fuckin' pieces!  Give me three men, if I'm wrong, I can still roll up that flank.

lines.speaker: u7083
lines.text: Right on.

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: I remember first time you came in here Taylor you telling me how much you admired that bastard.

lines.speaker: u7084
lines.text: I was home on leave y'know and everybody's just worried 'bout making money, everybody's out for themselves, they don't even want to talk about it man, it's like the fucking Twilight Zone back there - you wouldn't even KNOW there's a war on here. My sister says to me why you have to go there like I started this...

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: Baaaa! Fuck it, they sold us out - so what! What'd you'all expect? Civilian life is phoney BULLSHIT man. They're ROBOTS man - watchin' dopey television and drivin' dopey cars, and they fuck up, nobody dies. That's all right, you keep fuckin' up, politicians keep lyin'. Cause it don't really matter. Don't mean shit. So what! Whatcha want - a parade! Fuck that too! No war time no grunt never got no respect. Till he was dead - and even THEN! You're fighting for YOURSELF man! You're fighting for your SOUL, dat's all. Remember dat. And it's some goddamn battle too - if you'se a man, wrestle with that angel...  ...Love and Hate - the whole shitbang show, that's the story then and now and it ain't hardly gonna change...

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: You wanted to see me sir?

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: Jackson, looks like you got Elias' squad now.

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: Squad? I didn't know we was still referring to this platoon in terms of squads sir.

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: These two holes are yours...

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: Begging your pardon Lieutenant but my holes are far enuff apart you could run a regiment through there and nobody'd see them - I got five live bodies left...

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: I don't want to hear your problems, Jackson. You'll get new men any day. Time being you make do like everybody else.

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: Hey Lieutenant I didn't ask for this job, I...

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: I don't want to hear about it Jackson.

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: You don't want to hear about it?

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: That's right. I don't want to hear about it 'cause to tell you the truth, I don't give a shit okay... I just don't give a shit anymore.

lines.speaker: u7086
lines.text: Right...

lines.speaker: u7087
lines.text: This is one time we could sure use Elias.

lines.speaker: u7088
lines.text: But I tell you---if you'd only understand.

lines.speaker: u7095
lines.text: I understand, Betty.  I understand perfectly.

lines.speaker: u7089
lines.text: Do me a favor, Mitchell. Find yourself a nice secluded park bench.

lines.speaker: u7101
lines.text: Did I do something wrong?

lines.speaker: u7089
lines.text: I wouldn't know. Just do it somewhere else. There is such a thing as good manners.

lines.speaker: u7101
lines.text: How would you know, Brandon?

lines.speaker: u7089
lines.text: Want to walk out... or get thrown out?

lines.speaker: u7101
lines.text: You don't throw guests out, Brandon.

lines.speaker: u7089
lines.text: Don't bet on it. I'm eccentric.

lines.speaker: u7090
lines.text: I think we'd better discuss this in my office, Mr. Mitchell.

lines.speaker: u7101
lines.text: Nothing to discuss. Tomorrow the sun will shine even brighter. Be grateful for small mercies.

lines.speaker: u7095
lines.text: I needn't keep you any longer, Mr. Clarendon.

lines.speaker: u7091
lines.text: Thank you. It is rather late... and I'm not young anymore. Good night.

lines.speaker: u7095
lines.text: What's the face for, Driscoll?

lines.speaker: u7092
lines.text: Magruder's conked out.  Adrenaline injections, oxygen tent.  He may come out of it and he may not.  As a source of quick information, we can't forget him.

lines.speaker: u7095
lines.text: We don't need him.

lines.speaker: u7096
lines.text: I need a receipt.  Sign your name across the flap.

lines.speaker: u7093
lines.text: Open it and count it.

lines.speaker: u7096
lines.text: When you sign for it, you count it.  It's your dough.

lines.speaker: u7094
lines.text: Greer and Goble in the Call Building, San Francisco.  Just like you thought...Two murders in two days.  Different places, different methods, different people. Nothing connects them, but a telephone number.

lines.speaker: u7095
lines.text: A think wire---but very, very strong.  Let's get out of here.

lines.speaker: u7100
lines.text: Get out of here!

lines.speaker: u7095
lines.text: What are my orders, sir?

lines.speaker: u7100
lines.text: You think I'm wrong about this bit of a girl.  Go out and prove it against me!

lines.speaker: u7099
lines.text: You're very attractive, my dear. And you look very unsophisticated.

lines.speaker: u7101
lines.text: Unsophisticated?  If I knew about this babe...

lines.speaker: u7106
lines.text: Then I began to listen to what the well-off were saying about the poor now  the war had just ended, and the language was much the same as it had been before the first Reform Act.  A small minority thought that England was really theirs, they had made it, they owned it.  The rest, the wage earners, were foreigners, outsiders intent on wrecking it all.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: Didn't Evelyn Waugh say that the country under Atlee seemed to be under enemy occupation?

lines.speaker: u7106
lines.text: Did he?  I left school and worked for the Labour Party.  My older brother, George, had just been killed in Greece, and he'd been an active member.  I hero-worshipped him.  He was 25 years old ...  It was an exciting time for us, those first couple of years after the war.  We thought the country was about to become a true democracy.  I can understand why people of your generation want to write about that time.  They feel betrayed.  They want to know what went wrong.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: What went wrong?

lines.speaker: u7106
lines.text: Oh, many things.  Inertia ... Stalin and the Cold War... a failure of nerve.  We took the seediest, most inefficient fifth of the economy into State care, paid out millions for it, put the same old duffers in charge.  A new broom with very old bristles.  When the Tories were returned, I went and sat in the BM and wrote my little book on Chartism.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: Terrific.

lines.speaker: u7107
lines.text: But what we need is national coverage.  It's difficult with this Falklands madness going on. Do you think you might be able to do something when you get back?

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: I'll suggest it.  Remember though, we're news, not features.  It might help if you could get yourselves attacked by the police.  Anyway, I'll be back with this soon. Thanks.

lines.speaker: u7108
lines.text: Aha.  James giving some woman the old heave-ho.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: Exactly that.

lines.speaker: u7109
lines.text: Congratulations.  Who with?

lines.speaker: u7112
lines.text: A glamorous young lady way above his station...

lines.speaker: u7110
lines.text: James... I can't begin to tell you how pleased we all are.  Congratulations, and I really mean it.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: u7110
lines.text: It's everything we wanted.  A very good read.  A terrific piece of work.  So, here's to you and Suez.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: And to history.

lines.speaker: u7113
lines.text: Susan told me that your visits to Norfolk had ... well, an ulterior motive.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: She said that?

lines.speaker: u7113
lines.text: You weren't really interested in Suez at all.  Incredibly enough, you were interested in my wife.

lines.speaker: u7111
lines.text: Now listen...

lines.speaker: u7113
lines.text: No, no, let me go on before you get the wrong idea.  Ann and I have kept to our separate bedrooms for the last three years.  And I can't imagine that Susan hasn't hinted at the kind of life I lead in London.  I'm not telling you how to run your affairs.  I'm just saying ... I don't mind.  I'm giving you permission.

lines.speaker: u7116
lines.text: It was incredible.  He came back, made a pompous little bow and said, 'My dear girl you may film me all afternoon if you wish.' And he's promised not to talk to the Press.

lines.speaker: u7112
lines.text: It's because he desires you.  The women get all the breaks at these conferences.

lines.speaker: u7116
lines.text: It's true!  I was here last year doing a piece, remember?  I was in the bar with all these Northern trade unionists and their sponsored MPs.  They were all incredibly fat and beery, huge trousers and braces. And so sweet.  They all stood round me like children saying 'You! Working for television?  You're just a young thing.'  They wouldn't let me buy drinks even when I told them the programme was paying. They kept looking at my pass which was pinned here and saying  'Oo, can I?'

lines.speaker: u7112
lines.text: Then one of them was sick all over your new dress.

lines.speaker: u7116
lines.text: No, he wasn't.  He just lowered himself into a bar stool and said...  'Oo I do feel bad.  I 'ad three pints of lager and six onion bajees!'

lines.speaker: u7116
lines.text: Don't you want to walk, Tom?

lines.speaker: u7117
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u7116
lines.text: Actually, I've been once today already.  I'll stay here with him.

lines.speaker: u7118
lines.text: And I always knew I could count on you, Agent Utah.

lines.speaker: u7123
lines.text: I'm not FBI anymore.

lines.speaker: u7118
lines.text: You never were...

lines.speaker: u7123
lines.text: I asked them to give me a couple minutes...

lines.speaker: u7121
lines.text: You sure he isn't out back?  You mind if I go take a look?

lines.speaker: u7119
lines.text: Look, I don't know anything about your dog, okay--

lines.speaker: u7121
lines.text: Well is there anyone else here that might have seen him?

lines.speaker: u7119
lines.text: There's nobody else here...

lines.speaker: u7121
lines.text: Harp, let me tell you something.  I was an agent in this bureau when your mommy was still wiping your shinny pink ass, and you know one thing I learned in all those years that you still haven't?

lines.speaker: u7120
lines.text: What that?

lines.speaker: u7123
lines.text: Angelo!  Don't fire!

lines.speaker: u7121
lines.text: Kid, get outta the way!!

lines.speaker: u7123
lines.text: NOOO!!

lines.speaker: u7123
lines.text: I work bank robbery.  Guys I'm after are surfers.  I needed you, at first, but not--

lines.speaker: u7122
lines.text: Fuck you, Johnny Utah.  Fuck you!! Don't you have a soul?  Goddamn you to hell!

lines.speaker: u7123
lines.text: Bye.

lines.speaker: u7124
lines.text: Wait!  Jesus Christ!  You're fucking crazy, you know that? You go in there you're gonna eat it on the rocks.  Here, follow me.

lines.speaker: u7130
lines.text: Billy... What the hell's wrong with you?

lines.speaker: u7125
lines.text: Something... in the trees...

lines.speaker: u7126
lines.text: Take a position over there. I'll work around towards you. When I flush him, you nail him...

lines.speaker: u7127
lines.text: ... Right, I got a score to settle for the Bro...

lines.speaker: u7126
lines.text: We both got scores to settle.

lines.speaker: u7130
lines.text: I'm sorry, Bull. It's never easy. He was a good soldier.

lines.speaker: u7127
lines.text: The best friend I ever had.

lines.speaker: u7128
lines.text: You lift off in three hours.  There's one other thing.

lines.speaker: u7130
lines.text: What's that, General?

lines.speaker: u7128
lines.text: Someone else will be going in with you.

lines.speaker: u7129
lines.text: How could anyone get through this, carry Blain out, right under our noses without leavin' a trace?

lines.speaker: u7130
lines.text: He knows our defenses.

lines.speaker: u7129
lines.text: Why didn't he try to kill one of us last night?

lines.speaker: u7131
lines.text: Your uncle will like this.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: He's not really my uncle.

lines.speaker: u7131
lines.text: They never are, dear.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: You don't know anything about me.

lines.speaker: u7132
lines.text: I'd like to find out.  You don't know anything about me either. That's why people have lunch.

lines.speaker: u7141
lines.text: You broke my nose.

lines.speaker: u7133
lines.text: I think I broke my hand.  You're fired.

lines.speaker: u7141
lines.text: Edward, we've been together ten years.

lines.speaker: u7133
lines.text: And I don't like what we've become.  I'll cover any losses you have on this one.  Now get out, you asshole!

lines.speaker: u7141
lines.text: All this because of that whore!

lines.speaker: u7133
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Couple a hours.

lines.speaker: u7135
lines.text: Yeah.  Well... I gotta split. Goodbye's make me crazy.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Cool your jets a second.  Here's some money.

lines.speaker: u7135
lines.text: No.  You took care of rent, that's enough.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: I want to.  For food, got it? Eat something before the wind blows you away.

lines.speaker: u7135
lines.text: I'm gonna pay you back next time I see ya, babe.  Just wait, I'm gonna do something real nice for you some day.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Yeah, what?

lines.speaker: u7137
lines.text: Rent.  You're late.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Don't give me that.  Kit gave it to you yesterday, cash.

lines.speaker: u7137
lines.text: Kit give me nothin'.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: You bullshittin' me?

lines.speaker: u7137
lines.text: Of rent I do not bullshit.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Is that all?  You just fold back the bedspread?

lines.speaker: u7138
lines.text: I also place las chocolates on the pillow.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Oooh, I love those.

lines.speaker: u7138
lines.text: I leave extras, miss.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Thanks!  Consuelo, are all rich people so lazy they can't do this on their own?

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Hi, Barney!

lines.speaker: u7139
lines.text: Miss Vivian.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Look I just wanted to say goodbye.

lines.speaker: u7139
lines.text: Mr. Harris doesn't check out until tomorrow.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Yeah, well, I check out today.

lines.speaker: u7139
lines.text: You're not accompanying him to New York?

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Come on, Barney, you and me live in the real world.  You don't know how to treat a girl like anything but a lady, Mr. Thomas.

lines.speaker: u7139
lines.text: Certain ladies make that very easy... Vivian.  John, call a limousine for our guest, please.  Have it take her anywhere she wishes to go.  Bill the hotel.  See you again sometime soon.

lines.speaker: u7140
lines.text: Yes?

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Do you remember me?

lines.speaker: u7140
lines.text: No, I'm sorry, I don't.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: I was in here yesterday.

lines.speaker: u7142
lines.text: Get out!

lines.speaker: u7141
lines.text: Don't worry.  I'll pay for it. What a you charge?  Huh?  Twenty, thirty, fifty bucks, <u>maybe</u>?  Are you a fifty dollar whore?

lines.speaker: u7156
lines.text: You don't believe me?

lines.speaker: u7143
lines.text: You survived the Fire Swamp. You must be very brave...  ... but nobody withstands The Machine. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           69.

lines.speaker: u7144
lines.text: But it did. I was there. This old man said, "Man and wife."

lines.speaker: u7156
lines.text: Did you say, "I do"?

lines.speaker: u7144
lines.text: Well, no, we sort of skipped that part.

lines.speaker: u7156
lines.text: Then you're not married -- if you didn't say it, you didn't do it  -- wouldn't you agree, Your Highness?

lines.speaker: u7148
lines.text: He's getting away from me, Fezzik. Please. FEZZIK!

lines.speaker: u7145
lines.text: I'll be right back.

lines.speaker: u7153
lines.text: Maybe you could come over and read it again to me tomorrow.

lines.speaker: u7146
lines.text: As you wish...

lines.speaker: u7152
lines.text: Now, where is that secret knot? It's impossible to find.  Are you coming down into the Pit? Westley's got his strength back. I am starting him on The Machine tonight.

lines.speaker: u7147
lines.text: Tyrone, you know how much I love watching you work. But, I've got my country's five hundredth anniversary to plan, my wedding to arrange, My wife to murder, and Guilder to frame for it. I'm swamped. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           75.

lines.speaker: u7148
lines.text: I want to duel him left-handed.

lines.speaker: u7155
lines.text: You know what a hurry we're in.

lines.speaker: u7148
lines.text: Well, it's the only way I can be satisfied. If I use my right -- tch -- over too quickly.

lines.speaker: u7155
lines.text: Oh, have it your way.

lines.speaker: u7149
lines.text: You guessed wrong.

lines.speaker: u7155
lines.text: You only think I guessed wrong --  -- that's what's so funny! I switched glasses when your back was turned. You fool.

lines.speaker: u7154
lines.text: Bye-bye, boys.

lines.speaker: u7150
lines.text: Have fun storming the castle.

lines.speaker: u7154
lines.text: Think it'll work?

lines.speaker: u7150
lines.text: It would take a miracle. Bye!

lines.speaker: u7154
lines.text: Bye.

lines.speaker: u7151
lines.text: You feeling any better?

lines.speaker: u7153
lines.text: A little bit.

lines.speaker: u7151
lines.text: Guess what.

lines.speaker: u7153
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u7151
lines.text: Your grandfather's here.

lines.speaker: u7153
lines.text: Mom, can't you tell him that I'm sick?

lines.speaker: u7151
lines.text: You are sick, that's why he's here.

lines.speaker: u7153
lines.text: He'll pinch my cheek. I hate that.

lines.speaker: u7151
lines.text: Maybe he won't.

lines.speaker: u7158
lines.text: Smasheroo.  Smasheroo.

lines.speaker: u7166
lines.text: Oh, I'd better hurry back.  I don't want to miss one minute of it.

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: Hindenburg...

lines.speaker: u7159
lines.text: Hindenburg...

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: The Graf Spee...

lines.speaker: u7159
lines.text: The Graf Spee...

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: The Blue Max...

lines.speaker: u7159
lines.text: The Blue Max...

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: And last, but not least, Adolph... you know who.

lines.speaker: u7159
lines.text: And last, but not least, Adolph... you know who.

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: Heil you know who!

lines.speaker: u7159
lines.text: Heil you know who!

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: Good.  Good.  Now ve sign the contract.

lines.speaker: u7160
lines.text: Okay.

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: Where are you going vit the light?

lines.speaker: u7160
lines.text: I need it.  How'm I gonna find the fuse?

lines.speaker: u7165
lines.text: Oh, ve come vit you.  All for one and all in the light.

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Lorenzo Saint DuBois.  But everybody calls me LSD.

lines.speaker: u7162
lines.text: What have you done, LSD?

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Six months, I'm out on probation, but it's cool now, baby.

lines.speaker: u7162
lines.text: I mean in show business.

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Oh, in show business.  Well, let's put it this way, my next job will be my debut.

lines.speaker: u7162
lines.text: What do you do best?

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Hey, man, I can't do that here, that's what they put me away for.

lines.speaker: u7162
lines.text: Oh, sing.  Sing!

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Hey, baby, that's where they put me, Sing-Sing.  How'd you know that, you been up?

lines.speaker: u7162
lines.text: Sing a song!  Just sing a song!

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Where's Goebbels?  Where's my little Joe?

lines.speaker: u7163
lines.text: Send for Goebbels.

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: He's the only cat left that still grooves me.

lines.speaker: u7164
lines.text: Heil, baby!  I just finished the morning propaganda broadcasts.

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: What did you tell the people?

lines.speaker: u7164
lines.text: I told them we invaded England.

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Hey, baby, that's good!  How'd we come out?

lines.speaker: u7164
lines.text: We won.

lines.speaker: u7167
lines.text: Groovy!

lines.speaker: u7169
lines.text: You came up here on a hunch, Miss Crane? Nothing more? No phone call... from him, or from your sister herself?

lines.speaker: u7173
lines.text: Not even a hunch. Just hope.

lines.speaker: u7169
lines.text: With a little checking, I could get to believe you.

lines.speaker: u7173
lines.text: I don't care if you do or... I want to see Mary... before she gets in any deeper...

lines.speaker: u7170
lines.text: I think you'd better give it a trial spin. Don't want any bad word of mouth about California Charlie.

lines.speaker: u7175
lines.text: I'd really rather not. Please.  Can't we just settle this and...

lines.speaker: u7170
lines.text: I'll be perfectly honest with you, Ma'am. It's not that I don't trust you, but...

lines.speaker: u7175
lines.text: But what?  Is there anything so terribly wrong about... making a decision and wanting to hurry? Do you think I've stolen... my car?

lines.speaker: u7170
lines.text: No, M'am. I was only about to say, I've sent my mechanic out to give your car a little test... that's all.

lines.speaker: u7175
lines.text: I'd like to be ready when he gets back.

lines.speaker: u7170
lines.text: Okay. If you'll come along...

lines.speaker: u7171
lines.text: Aren't you going to take the pills?  They'll knock that headache out.

lines.speaker: u7175
lines.text: I don't need pills... just sleep.

lines.speaker: u7174
lines.text: Call her sister! If no one's answering at the house....

lines.speaker: u7172
lines.text: I called her sister, Mr. Lowery, where she works, the Music Makers Music Store, you know? And she doesn't know where Mary is any more than we do.

lines.speaker: u7174
lines.text: You better run out to the house. She may be... unable to answer the phone...

lines.speaker: u7172
lines.text: Her sister's going to do that.  She's as worried as we are.

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: It's regular. Okay?

lines.speaker: u7173
lines.text: I could stand something regular.

lines.speaker: u7179
lines.text: May I see your license?

lines.speaker: u7175
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u7179
lines.text: Please.

lines.speaker: u7181
lines.text: Went out before service.

lines.speaker: u7176
lines.text: Have you two had breakfast?

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: You look frightened. Have I been saying something frightening?

lines.speaker: u7177
lines.text: I don't know what you've been saying.

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: I've been talking about your mother... about your motel. How are you going to do it?

lines.speaker: u7177
lines.text: Do what?

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: Buy a new one! In a new town! Where you won't have to hide your mother!

lines.speaker: u7177
lines.text: Shut up!

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: Where will you get the money to do that, Bates... or do you already have it... socked away... a lot of it...

lines.speaker: u7177
lines.text: Leave me alone!

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: ...Forty thousand dollars!

lines.speaker: u7177
lines.text: Leave me alone!

lines.speaker: u7182
lines.text: I won't have you bringing strange young girls in for supper...  ...by candlelight, I suppose, in the cheap erotic fashion of young men with cheap, erotic minds!

lines.speaker: u7178
lines.text: Mother, please...

lines.speaker: u7182
lines.text: And then what? After supper, music? Whispers?

lines.speaker: u7178
lines.text: Mother, she's just a stranger... hungry, and the weather's bad...

lines.speaker: u7182
lines.text: Mother, she's just a stranger!  As if men don't desire strangers, as if... oh, I refuse to speak of disgusting things because they disgust me! You understand, Boy?

lines.speaker: u7182
lines.text: Go on, go tell her she'll not be appeasing her ugly appetite with my food... or my son! Or do I have to tell her, cause you don't have the guts? Huh, boy? You have the guts, boy?

lines.speaker: u7178
lines.text: Shut up! Shut up!

lines.speaker: u7180
lines.text: No mother.

lines.speaker: u7181
lines.text: You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was illusion there and I don't believe in ghosts, so there it is!

lines.speaker: u7183
lines.text: By gosh, them stiffs are get- tin' heavier and more of 'em every day. They even got the coroner working overtime.

lines.speaker: u7184
lines.text: Yeah, between the gangsters and the autos, we won't need another war to carry off the population.

lines.speaker: u7183
lines.text: You didn't even mention the suicides. Did you notice the beaut that came in today?

lines.speaker: u7184
lines.text: Did I?

lines.speaker: u7183
lines.text: That's the one that's got the coroner doing nightwork.

lines.speaker: u7184
lines.text: What--special autopsy?

lines.speaker: u7185
lines.text: Imagine--she was alive. What a horror. Could have been buried alive. She must have run away from the morgue.

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: Never mind your theories. Was she ever conscious?

lines.speaker: u7185
lines.text: Just before she died she came to--

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: Did she talk?

lines.speaker: u7185
lines.text: Said "doctor"--[something]

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: [Was it] "Meirschultz"?

lines.speaker: u7191
lines.text: That's what I said. Now, lis- ten to me. I want you to help me take this woman down stairs. I will give her a shot. You can take care of her till I get help.

lines.speaker: u7186
lines.text: How about me getting the help. She's quiet now, isn't she?

lines.speaker: u7187
lines.text: Yes--I can't stand it-- everybody wants papers-- oh, oh

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: Take him to the psychopathic hospital.

lines.speaker: u7193
lines.text: Sure--they're sorta queer, I'd say. They's lots of queer goings on up there. They even brought a dog back to life once.

lines.speaker: u7188
lines.text: That sounds to me very remarkable.

lines.speaker: u7193
lines.text: It may be, but to my notion, those that monkeys with what they got no business to get queer sooner or later.

lines.speaker: u7188
lines.text: Maybe you're right.

lines.speaker: u7193
lines.text: I know I am. Why, I even heard a shot up there last night.

lines.speaker: u7188
lines.text: Why didn't you notify the police?

lines.speaker: u7189
lines.text: Oh, him. He has a cat of his own. But his assistant--he's the cat-hatenest man I ever saw. Goofy, if ya ast me.]

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: By the way--did you hear a shot last night?

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: Take me down there.

lines.speaker: u7191
lines.text: It won't do any good. They are a pair of would-be mur- deresses fighting it out.

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: Man, you're crazy. What kind of a place is this?

lines.speaker: u7191
lines.text: Oh, <U>I'm</U> crazy, am I? Let me tell you something.  Those women have--the gleam--

lines.speaker: u7190
lines.text: Come on, we're wasting time.

lines.speaker: u7191
lines.text: [Something very important. I have been threatened;] Mrs. Maxwell, my assistant's wife, is crazy.  She thinks I mur- dered her husband. [She wants to murder me.] I want you to help me quiet her-- give her a shot from this hypo. [Keep it hid till we get her] down in the basement-- there is a secret vault [there]. We will put her there till we get your husband--[then turn her over to the authorities. Then we will both be free.]

lines.speaker: u7192
lines.text: It sounds all right, except for the fact that she's crazy. It seems to me she has the right idea--.

lines.speaker: u7191
lines.text: Oh, so you feel that way too . Motions to other room. Stay in there--I'll call you when needed.

lines.speaker: u7194
lines.text: What is it now?

lines.speaker: u7197
lines.text: I'm losing my blood!

lines.speaker: u7194
lines.text: You're losing your blood?

lines.speaker: u7197
lines.text: Yes!

lines.speaker: u7194
lines.text: Nonsense! ... It's here! ... Your blood ...

lines.speaker: u7198
lines.text: Your father?

lines.speaker: u7195
lines.text: Yes!

lines.speaker: u7198
lines.text: The master ... is asleep!

lines.speaker: u7196
lines.text: There's no child here, and no dogs either.

lines.speaker: u7197
lines.text: No?

lines.speaker: u7196
lines.text: No!  Good night!

lines.speaker: u7200
lines.text: By the time we return there, all the preparations for the blood transfusion are completed.

lines.speaker: u7199
lines.text: Joseph returns from the room where Gisle is. He has evidently succeeded in calming her. He goes and sits in the chair where Nikolas sat. He rests his head in his hand. He sees the open diary and begins reading it.

lines.speaker: u7200
lines.text: The blood transfusion is now in progress. The only words are curt orders like: 'Now! - Quickly! - That's enough! - Give it to me! - Sit still!' etc.

lines.speaker: u7199
lines.text: Joseph is reading the diary, which arouses his interest more and more. It is as if he finds a connection between what he reads and the fearful events that have taken place around him. An extract from the diary is shown.

lines.speaker: u7200
lines.text: The blood transfusion continues. Marc has positioned himself outside the circle of light from the lamp, so that he can see Nikolas in bright light, while he himself sits in the dark. Nikolas watches Lone's face anxiously and closely during her struggle with death. Life slowly seems to return to her, and her breathing becomes more peaceful. She opens her eyes and looks at the people round her, but she is much too enfeebled to speak, and closes her eyes again. Marc keeps a close watch on Nikolas, who grows paler and paler. His eyes swivel slowly from Nikolas to the patient and back to Nikolas again.

lines.speaker: u7199
lines.text: Another fragment of the diary is shown [having to do with vampires].

lines.speaker: u7200
lines.text: The blood transfusion is completed. While Marc himself is looking after the patient, the nurse leads Nikolas into an adjoining room, where she makes him sit down and prepares his bandage. The doctor stands bending over Lone.

lines.speaker: u7201
lines.text: You killed him!  Come on with the rest of it. You killed him!

lines.speaker: u7212
lines.text: No -- I didn't. It was Igor at the waxworks.

lines.speaker: u7201
lines.text: But you were in on it -- you worked for him.

lines.speaker: u7212
lines.text: No -- the only thing I did for him was to keep track of the man named Worth that runs the place where you arrested me tonight.

lines.speaker: u7201
lines.text: You lie!

lines.speaker: u7212
lines.text: It's Igor at the Wax Museum! You'll find your judge embalmed in wax! He's a statue of Voltaire, with all the other corpses! The whole place is a morgue -- do you hear? -- a morgue!

lines.speaker: u7202
lines.text: Please, oh, please, I haven't done anything to hurt you.

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: And I have no desire to hurt you. You will always be beautiful. Think, my child, in a thousand years you will be as lovely as you are now.

lines.speaker: u7203
lines.text: Hey, what do you think you're doing? Put that stuff back!

lines.speaker: u7206
lines.text: Nothing doing. This is my percentage. You birds are going to get yours. And anyhow, I found this dump.

lines.speaker: u7204
lines.text: That's what I said.

lines.speaker: u7206
lines.text: I'm going to get even with you, you dirty stiff! I'll do it!

lines.speaker: u7205
lines.text: You didn't happen to be going to Worth's place, did you?

lines.speaker: u7212
lines.text: No, sir, I'm sure it wasn't there.

lines.speaker: u7205
lines.text: You used to go to Worth's place a whole lot. What makes you sure it wasn't there?

lines.speaker: u7212
lines.text: Well, maybe it was. I don't remember.  You got to do something for me, I can't stand it any longer -- I can't!

lines.speaker: u7213
lines.text: What is it? What happened?

lines.speaker: u7206
lines.text: Don't ask any questions. Come on!

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: You are too gracious. These things have some merit, I suspect ... but this--  ... I am convinced, is fine.

lines.speaker: u7207
lines.text: Even those delicate veins, the texture of this flesh -- I have never seen anything more exquisite.

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: My partner believes that I should build a horror chamber, immortalizing the hideous crimes and criminals of London. At such times Marie Antoinette has reassured me, she has promised me recognition for the devotion I gave to her.

lines.speaker: u7207
lines.text: She will undoubtedly keep her promise. If you'll grant me the privilege, I'd like to submit this work to the Royal Academy when I get back.

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: You will have won the undying gratitude of us all.  Is that not so, Marie Antoinette?

lines.speaker: u7207
lines.text: I regret I can't spend the time I'd like with your exhibition, but I'm going to worry the life out of you when I come back.

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: It will always afford me great pleasure to see you.

lines.speaker: u7207
lines.text: Good night, sir.

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: Good night.  And I am very grateful to you.

lines.speaker: u7212
lines.text: I'd know him anywhere.

lines.speaker: u7208
lines.text: Don't lose sight of him. This is the most important thing in my life.

lines.speaker: u7214
lines.text: Yep. Everything settled.

lines.speaker: u7213
lines.text: Good. Well, I'll be seeing you.

lines.speaker: u7214
lines.text: I'm glad they didn't hold you downtown.

lines.speaker: u7213
lines.text: They didn't have a leg to stand on. There's no case against me. It's a clumsy thing to have happen, but nothing to worry about.

lines.speaker: u7214
lines.text: Well, any time I can do anything for you --

lines.speaker: u7213
lines.text: Thanks.

lines.speaker: u7217
lines.text: Mia...?

lines.speaker: u7215
lines.text: Yes....

lines.speaker: u7217
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u7216
lines.text: So I can move on.  You too.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: Yes?

lines.speaker: u7218
lines.text: Is Rose here?

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: She must have gone out for a walk with the children.

lines.speaker: u7218
lines.text: Well, I got to see her.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: She isn't here. And I'm sorry, but Mr. Hillyer doesn't want her to have callers during working hours.

lines.speaker: u7218
lines.text: Where is she?

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: I said she isn't here. NOW you go home. Be a nice boy and go home.

lines.speaker: u7219
lines.text: They're filthy, Mother.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: Sex isn't ugly, sex is one of the most beautiful things in life, the creative power of the universe is behind it.

lines.speaker: u7219
lines.text: I know, Mother.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: But we must respect that power, we must be in awe of it.

lines.speaker: u7219
lines.text: I am in awe of it, Mother.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: I don't think you are sufficiently in awe of it. Get the castor oil.

lines.speaker: u7219
lines.text: Oh, Mother, not the castor oil.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: This isn't punishment, I don't believe in punishment. It's for your health. Obviously you're sick if you can act like that.

lines.speaker: u7223
lines.text: Why is it taking so long?

lines.speaker: u7220
lines.text: Here comes Daddy.

lines.speaker: u7221
lines.text: Rose... I hate to be mean, but...  Oh, nevermind, forget it.

lines.speaker: u7227
lines.text: What was it, Mr. Hillyer?

lines.speaker: u7221
lines.text: Nothing, Rose.

lines.speaker: u7222
lines.text: You might see her. She writes your Daddy, and she and that doctor came to see him, didn't they? I wish you'd tell her something... I never could write letters.

lines.speaker: u7229
lines.text: What do you want me to tell her, Dave?

lines.speaker: u7222
lines.text: Oh, to hell with it, never mind. Don't tell her anything. Don't even tell her you saw me.  Got to run, Buddy, I'll miss my plane.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: What's the matter with him?

lines.speaker: u7223
lines.text: I don't know. I think he's cryin'!

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: I will not cry like a woman. If I'm upset it's because of what my husband said, not because of you. You can't make me cry like a woman, a woman has got just as much intelligence and self-control as a man. And you get this in your head. If you hurt that girl, I'll hire lawyers and sue you for malpractice for every penny you have got, I'll do my level best to ruin you. Do you understand me?

lines.speaker: u7224
lines.text: Yes, I understand you, but you have misunderstood me completely.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: I understand you perfectly. You leave that girl alone, you wretched man, or you will be sorry.

lines.speaker: u7224
lines.text: Actually of course I won't operate, I don't do major surgery. Dr. Hardy will operate and of course he'll be guided by your wishes in this respect.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: Let him be guided not by my wishes and not by Rose's wishes, although I am sure they are identical. Let him be guided by the wishes of the creative power of life itself, because that is what has spoken through me tonight.

lines.speaker: u7225
lines.text: Well, she finally let me look in her mouth. Is it true she's never been to a dentist?

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: She was raised on a poor dirt farm. I'm sure she's never seen a dentist or hardly even a doctor.

lines.speaker: u7225
lines.text: Well, she has one mouth in ten thousand, I don't see teeth like that once in ten years. Her trouble is an impacted wisdom tooth, but there isn't a cavity in her head, not a single one. She has perfect teeth.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: But the wisdom tooth will have to be pulled?

lines.speaker: u7225
lines.text: Yes, and it's very bad. It probably should be done at the hospital under general anesthesia.

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: That would scare her to death. She's terrified of hospitals. To her, a hospital is where you go to die.

lines.speaker: u7225
lines.text: I think you're right, it would be harder on her. But you'd better call Mr. Hillyer, she's going to need help to get home.

lines.speaker: u7227
lines.text: You'll never guess what happened!  I have met Mr. Right! I been with him all day and he loves me, I know he does, he loves me and he's going to marry met Be's practi'cly ast me already!

lines.speaker: u7226
lines.text: Well... well, that's wonderful, Rose.

lines.speaker: u7227
lines.text: And who do you suppose he is? That policeman who arrested me, the one I bit! He is Mr. Right!

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: Hasn't he got enough problems, or didn't you notice that's not cream soda on his breath?

lines.speaker: u7230
lines.text: ... okay... you made your point.

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: We'll take the CalTrust heist, but if it's no good, we will hunt you down, and Billy-Boy will pull out your spine and he will beat you to death with it.

lines.speaker: u7231
lines.text: Fair enough.

lines.speaker: u7232
lines.text: Three hundred kilos of White Lady hidden inside a giant bust of Abraham Lincoln.  A parade float.

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: What... ?

lines.speaker: u7232
lines.text: Abe Lincoln...

lines.speaker: u7233
lines.text: It's bone dry out there.  Everybody's hurting.  The stuff floating around's been cut so many times it's like powdered sugar, but Zimnermann's gonna fix it.

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: I need the "when" and the "where."

lines.speaker: u7233
lines.text: I don't know, okay?  All I know is Butch Cassidy's back in town.

lines.speaker: u7234
lines.text: He tried to kill us.

lines.speaker: u7238
lines.text: We've got the tape to prove it.

lines.speaker: u7238
lines.text: He went to pick up lunch.

lines.speaker: u7235
lines.text: Well, shake a leg.  Get these files downstairs...  And, quit listening to your fucking voodoo music.

lines.speaker: u7238
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: Don't you condescend to tell me how or why to honor Independence Day, and don't tell me I'm overreacting when I'm trying to bust the guy responsible for half the filthy junk coming into this city!

lines.speaker: u7236
lines.text: You're about an inch away from insubordination!

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: Well... seeing how you just suspended me, what's to stop me from calling you a crazy bastard, you old fart?

lines.speaker: u7236
lines.text: Till the last firework fizzles out tonight, detective, you sit a desk. And, after that, I'll decide if you keep your shield.

lines.speaker: u7239
lines.text: Where's your pet gorilla and the female Uncle Tom?

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: They're... around.

lines.speaker: u7239
lines.text: Yeah?  So, what do you want to ask today that I can't answer?  I'm a busy man.

lines.speaker: u7237
lines.text: The way Zimmermann takes such good care of you and this drug-peddling "escort service" of yours, I figure you got the scoop on the pharmaceuticals arriving tonight.

lines.speaker: u7239
lines.text: Well, let me tell you how it is...

lines.speaker: u7241
lines.text: The shield is down! Commence attack on theDeath Star's main reactor.

lines.speaker: u7247
lines.text: We're on our way. Red Group, Gold Group, all fighters follow me.  Told you they'd do it!

lines.speaker: u7249
lines.text: But you can't let her get involved now, Ben. Vader will destroy her.

lines.speaker: u7242
lines.text: She hasn't been trained in the ways of the Jedi the way you have, Luke... but the Force is strong with her, as it is with all of your family. There is no avoiding the battle. You must face and destroy Vader!

lines.speaker: u7243
lines.text: Shhh. You have hibernation sickness.

lines.speaker: u7245
lines.text: I can't see.

lines.speaker: u7243
lines.text: Your eyesight will return in time.

lines.speaker: u7245
lines.text: Where am I?

lines.speaker: u7243
lines.text: Jabba's palace.

lines.speaker: u7245
lines.text: Who are you?

lines.speaker: u7244
lines.text: Oh, no, my young Jedi. You will find that it is you who are mistaken...about a great many things.

lines.speaker: u7252
lines.text: His lightsaber.

lines.speaker: u7251
lines.text: Oh, Princess Leia, are you all right?

lines.speaker: u7245
lines.text: Let's see.

lines.speaker: u7252
lines.text: That is correct, Commander. And he is most displeased with your apparent lack of progress.

lines.speaker: u7246
lines.text: We shall double our efforts.

lines.speaker: u7252
lines.text: I hope so, Commander, for your sake. The Emperor is not as forgiving as I am.

lines.speaker: u7253
lines.text: There it is!

lines.speaker: u7247
lines.text: All right, Wedge. Go for the power regulator on the north tower.

lines.speaker: u7253
lines.text: Copy, Gold Leader. I'm already on my way out.

lines.speaker: u7249
lines.text: Yes. It's you Leia.

lines.speaker: u7248
lines.text: I know. Somehow...I've always known.

lines.speaker: u7249
lines.text: Then you know why I have to face him.

lines.speaker: u7248
lines.text: No! Luke, run away, far away. If he can feel your presence, then leave this place. I wish I could go with you.

lines.speaker: u7249
lines.text: No, you don't. You've always been strong.

lines.speaker: u7248
lines.text: But, why must you confront him?

lines.speaker: u7249
lines.text: Because...there is good in him. I've felt it. He won't turn me over to the Emperor. I can save him. I can turn him back to the good side. I have to try.

lines.speaker: u7249
lines.text: Well, I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u7254

lines.speaker: u7677
lines.text: His father walked out on his mother a couple of months after he was born. Louisa was Henry's younger sister, and she and the baby moved in with us. Four or five years go by, and then one day Cyrus shows up out of the blue, tail between his legs, wanting to patch things up with Louisa. I thought Henry was going to tear Cyrus apart when he saw him walk through the door. They're both big men, those two, and if they ever started to tangle, you'd see some teeth jumping on the floor. I guarantee it ... So Cyrus persuaded Louisa to go out with him to talk things over in quiet. And the poor girl never came back.

lines.speaker: u7682
lines.text: You mean she just ran off with him and left her little boy behind?

lines.speaker: u7677
lines.text: Don't put words in my mouth. What I'm saying is she drove off in Cyrus's car and went to the Five-Spot Lounge with him for a drink. What I'm saying is that he imbibed too much in the way of alcohol and that when they finished their little talk three hours later and got back in the car, he was in no shape to drive. But he drove the car anyway, and before he could get her back to where she lived, the damn fool ran a red light and went straight into a truck. Louisa got thrown through the windshield and was killed. Cyrus lived, but he came out of it a cripple. His left arm was so mangled, the doctors had to cut it off. Small punishment for what he did, if you ask me.

lines.speaker: u7682
lines.text: Jesus.

lines.speaker: u7677
lines.text: Jesus had nothing to do with it. If He'd been involved. He would have seen to it that things worked out the opposite from what they did.

lines.speaker: u7682
lines.text: It can't have been easy on him. Walking around with that on his conscience all these years.

lines.speaker: u7677
lines.text: No, I don't suppose it has. He was broken up like nobody's business in that hospital when he found out Louisa was dead.

lines.speaker: u7682
lines.text: And he's never tried to get in touch with his son?

lines.speaker: u7677
lines.text: Henry told Cyrus he'd kill him if he ever showed his face around our house again. When Henry makes a threat like that, people tend to take him seriously.

lines.speaker: u7678
lines.text: I don't like this. I don't like it one bit.

lines.speaker: u7683
lines.text: Louisa Vail. Remember her, Cyrus?

lines.speaker: u7678
lines.text: You shut your mouth! You shut your mouth now!

lines.speaker: u7684
lines.text: You can do whatever you want with your own life. We're thinking of the baby, that's all. We want you to get yourself cleaned up for the baby. Before it's too late.

lines.speaker: u7679
lines.text: Baby? And what baby is that?

lines.speaker: u7684
lines.text: Your baby. The baby you're carrying around inside you.

lines.speaker: u7679
lines.text: Yeah, well, there ain't no baby in there now. You dig? There's nothing in there now.

lines.speaker: u7684
lines.text: What are you talking about?

lines.speaker: u7679
lines.text: An abortion, stupid.  I had an abortion the day before yesterday. So you don't have to bug me about that shit anymore.  Bye-bye, baby!

lines.speaker: u7680
lines.text: Hey, Jimmy. You got the time?

lines.speaker: u7681
lines.text: Huh?

lines.speaker: u7680

lines.speaker: u7681
lines.text: Tick-tock, tick-tock.

lines.speaker: u7680
lines.text: So what's the time?

lines.speaker: u7681
lines.text: Twelve-eleven.  Twelve-twelve.  Twelve-twelve.

lines.speaker: u7682
lines.text: I'll take the iced coffee.  You only live once, right?

lines.speaker: u7688
lines.text: If you're lucky.  Then again, it depends on what you call living.

lines.speaker: u7682
lines.text: I don't mean to pry, but I see a kid walking around with a big knapsack on his back, and I begin to wonder if all his worldly possessions aren't stowed in there. Are you in some kind of trouble or what?

lines.text: $1200 an acre, that's what I paid Ole, won't take a dime less.  You got no choice on that.

lines.text: Didn't say I was buyin' did I? What you want down?  Just bein' curious, is all.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: With no bone or scalp or hair present.  Would it be more probable that the blood came from crushing a man's skull...

lines.speaker: u7691
lines.text: I'm a hemotologist, not a detective.

lines.speaker: u7702

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: Just three questions.  The Miyamoto family bought your seven acres for $4500?

lines.speaker: u7692
lines.text: Tried to.  Defaulted on their payments.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: Second question.  What did Ole Jurgensen pay you per acre?

lines.speaker: u7692
lines.text: A thousand.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: So that makes what would have been $4500 into $7000, doesn't it?  If you sent the equity back, you had a profit of $2500.

lines.speaker: u7692
lines.text: Is that your third question?

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: It is.

lines.speaker: u7692
lines.text: You done your math right.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: Thank you, Mr. Gillanders.  Thank you for coming down, in this cold weather.

lines.speaker: u7693
lines.text: Well, it does seem mighty warm in here.  Specially for Mr. Hooks.

lines.speaker: u7694
lines.text: Did you write that column?

lines.speaker: u7697
lines.text: I did.  But the jury won't s...

lines.speaker: u7694
lines.text: It's not for the.  They only get to convict him.

lines.speaker: u7695
lines.text: Your father fought at Belleau Wood, it took him years to get over it.  Nightmares, tears, b...

lines.speaker: u7697
lines.text: ...but he found you.

lines.speaker: u7696
lines.text: Well, the sheriff found <u>two</u> batteries in your well.  If you left one with Carl Heine, how is that possible?

lines.speaker: u7698
lines.text: I had a spare battery in my shed. I brought it down, and put it in just before the sheriff showed up.

lines.speaker: u7697
lines.text: We don't let go, you s...

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: It's a rare thing.  Takes a turning point.

lines.speaker: u7698
lines.text: You think that <u>is</u> the truth.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: I told your wife.  Trials aren't always so much about actual truth. As about what folks <u>believe</u> is true. That's sad.  And it's real.

lines.speaker: u7698
lines.text: And what do you believe?

lines.speaker: u7701
lines.text: One D-6 and one D-8 in the well. And a dead D-8 on the deck.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: Which you inferred was replaced by the D-6, which must have been a spare.

lines.speaker: u7701
lines.text: What else could it be?

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: Even though a D-6 is too big, and the flange had to be banged out to squeeze it in.  Which makes it a peculiar choice. For a spare.

lines.speaker: u7701
lines.text: <u>You</u> said that.  That was <u>your</u> testimony.

lines.speaker: u7702
lines.text: The question is more about the <u>defendant's</u> attitu...

lines.speaker: u7704
lines.text: That's all he said.

lines.speaker: u7707
lines.text: Melton, on the double!  Up a chain!                                   MELTON  Sir!     MELTON takes a few easy strides, gracefully catches a chain mid- stride, and smarts up, climbing easily and twice as fast as TODD.     CHURCH, SLOAN, and RUBRICK crane their necks as the two men struggle upward toward the rafters.     Three quarters of the way up, MELTON comes even with TODD, then passes him. MEKUM, watching, smirks.     CHURCH is watching too, and he's still not satisfied.  His brow is knit, something's bothering him.     ANGLE HIGH ABOVE, AMONG THE GIRDERS     Stonefaced, MELTON is resting an a "platform" on the chain, sixty feet up, beneath the girders, swaying gently.     His stony gaze is on the next chain where TODD is arriving at a "platform" on an adjacent chain...only three feet away.     Their eyes meet, TODD and MELTON alone together sixty feet up, three feet apart.  Neither man blinks, neither man flinches, neither man reveals anything at all...     LOW ANGLE, LOOKING UP     CHURCH considers the men high above, then to MEKUM.                                   CHURCH                    What about...spirit?

lines.speaker: u7707
lines.text: Spirit?                          Oh!  You mean "AQ"..."aggressive qualities"?

lines.speaker: u7706
lines.text: Whatever the latest jargon is.                                   MEKUM Much better, much higher.  For example, where your old ones expressed ninety percent of their sexual energy in aggressive physicality, these new ones are ninety-nine percent without sexual inclination.  It's <u>all</u> aggression.                                   SLOAN                          <u>Real</u> men!                                   CHURCH                          At ease, Lieutenant.                          What if they fought?     A sudden silence.     SLOAN raises her eyebrows, gives RUBRICK a look.     Frowning thoughtfully, MEKUM looks up. MEKUM You mean up there?                                   CHURCH                                             Go ahead, Rube.  Tell Todd to take him. MEKUM No!     They all look at MEKUM.  Is this the chink in the armor?  The new soldiers can't fight?                                   CHURCH                    "No"? MEKUM Not fair.  No contest.  Send two more of your old ones up.     Now CHURCH, RUBRICK, and SLOAN are stunned.  They exchange a glance.                                   MEKUM Go ahead.

lines.text: I called Mama - she was so happy she cried - she wants you to have her wedding gown - it's white lace.

lines.text: Osgood - I can't get married in your mother's dress.  She and I - we' not built the same way.

lines.speaker: u7717
lines.text: We can have it altered.

lines.speaker: u7712
lines.text: Oh, no you don't!  Look, Osgood - I'm going to level with you. We can't get married at all.

lines.text: Why not?

lines.speaker: u7712
lines.text: Well, to begin with, I'm not a natural blonde.

lines.speaker: u7717
lines.text: It doesn't matter.

lines.speaker: u7712
lines.text: And I smoke. I smoke all the time.

lines.speaker: u7717
lines.text: I don't care.

lines.speaker: u7712
lines.text: And I have a terrible past.  For three years now, I've been living with a saxophone player.

lines.speaker: u7717
lines.text: I forgive you.

lines.speaker: u7712
lines.text: And I can never have children.

lines.speaker: u7717
lines.text: We'll adopt some.

lines.speaker: u7712
lines.text: But you don't understand!  I'm a MAN!

lines.speaker: u7717
lines.text: Well - nobody's perfect.

lines.speaker: u7713
lines.text: You don't want me, Sugar - I'm a liar and a phony - a saxophone player - one of those no-goodnicks you've been running away from -

lines.speaker: u7722
lines.text: I know.  Every time!

lines.speaker: u7713
lines.text: Do yourself a favor - go back where the millionaires are - the sweet end of the lollipop - not the cole slaw in the face and the old socks and the squeezed-out tube of toothpaste -

lines.speaker: u7722

lines.speaker: u7720

lines.speaker: u7718
lines.text: Yeah.  You never know who's going to be next.  Okay, Spats.  Report to the Sergeant- at-Arms.

lines.speaker: u7720

lines.text: Theres a reason I always tell that Tony Pee-Pants story, you know.

lines.text: Before Tony, you and your sister were best friends. I couldnt split you up. If your sister ate the spinach, you ate the spinach. If you threw up--.

lines.speaker: u7729
lines.text: Mom, please.

lines.speaker: u7726
lines.text: Anyway, when that boy came over, it was the first time you ever did anything without her.  And Amy wasnt just jealous...she was sad and lonely. She missed you.

lines.text: She did?

lines.speaker: u7726
lines.text: So she flirted with Tony, and you got mad and sent him away. Who did that leave?  You and Amy. Reunited.

lines.speaker: u7728
lines.text: Nothing.

lines.speaker: u7727
lines.text: Doesnt look like nothing.

lines.speaker: u7729

lines.speaker: u7728
lines.text: I shagged Amy. Two years ago. Thats why I ended it. And then, after you left, sod it, we kept at it like rabbits until we both realized it was absolutely mad. And, you know, morally wrong. Then there was that one other time. And that was it.

lines.speaker: u7729

I could have you arrested for that -- and if you give out that information to anybody, that's exactly what I'm going to do -- and I'll tell everybody in this town how you got the information and who you got it for! You won't have a friend left in this county to bring you a piece of candy!

lines.speaker: u7748
lines.text: Whatcha got there?

lines.speaker: u7743
lines.text: Seems this piece of mail came to Mr. Howard's place this mornin' and he had me to bring it over here.

lines.text: Well, let me have it.

lines.speaker: u7743

lines.text: Mama, what was we laughin' for?

lines.speaker: u7750

lines.text: Hi ya, Rebecca...

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: Tired.

lines.speaker: u7745
lines.text: Somebody told me Nathan was back. How is he?

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: Why don't you pay him a visit, Mr. Howard? He'll tell you all about it.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: Where you goin'!?

lines.speaker: u7748
lines.text: To the commissary to get this boy some clothes! I'm gon' get everybody somethin'!

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: But, Nathan--

lines.speaker: u7748
lines.text: Don't tell me nothin' 'bout what we owe ol' man Howard! I'll do the owing, and let him worry 'bout the collecting! Come on, David Lee!

lines.speaker: u7749
lines.text: No, I ain't got no word yet, Rebecca. I went to the courthouse yesterday to see 'bout it, but they just won't tell me nothin' about what labor camp Nathan was sent to. I'm sorry, Rebecca.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: It's a shame, Reverend. It's a damn shame.

lines.speaker: u7749
lines.text: I hope you don't take to bitterness, Sister Morgan. I tell you like I tell all the women in this church who got the same trouble you got. No matter what the trial or what the misery is, I tell 'em to stay with God.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: Yeah, he'll crawl into my bed tonight, lie close to my body and keep me warm -- and rectify the evil in the men who live over us in this valley.

lines.speaker: u7749
lines.text: It's not that simple, Sister Rebecca -- the Lord works in mysterious ways -- we come into this life with nothin' and we'll leave it with nothing.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: Is that a blessing, Reverend?

lines.speaker: u7751
lines.text: Howya do, Rebecca. I sorta been expectin' you this mornin'.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: I wanta see Nathan.

lines.speaker: u7751
lines.text: I wish I could, Rebecca, but I can't let you.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: I don't understand that, Sheriff Young.

lines.speaker: u7751
lines.text: It's the rules and I gotta follow 'em. No visitin' 'cept holidays and Sunday -- and no womenfolk anytime.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: You mean to tell me I can't see my own husband?

lines.speaker: u7751
lines.text: That's the way they do things here in Landsdown. I just follow orders.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: I got to see my husband, Sheriff Young!

lines.speaker: u7751
lines.text: I'd like to help you, Rebecca. But all that would do, is git us both in trouble.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: Will they give him a trial?

lines.speaker: u7751
lines.text: Shore thing -- next week sometime, and as soon as I git the day, I'll ride out and let you know 'bout it.

lines.speaker: u7750
lines.text: You gotta low-life job, mister sheriff!

lines.speaker: u7770
lines.text: The clitoris?! I DID IT!! I FOUND THE CLITORIS!!

lines.text: Now go, your friends are in danger... The USO show is a mile east of here, just over that ridge. The clitoris has spoken.

lines.text: Wendy, Mkay, if you want to start getting political, I'll throw your skinny little butt right back into rehab. Mkay?

lines.speaker: u7755

lines.speaker: u7759
lines.text: Baba mama!

lines.speaker: u7760

lines.text: Mom, I'm a man. Just a man. And I'm going to have fun with profanity just like you and dad did when you were little.

lines.speaker: u7762
lines.text: I don't care if it's dangerous! Desperate times call for desperate measures, Mr. Mackey. Perhaps I need to remind you of your situation.

lines.text: You're quite a purveyor of filth, little boy!

lines.text: THAT'S IT!  I HAVE HAD ENOUGH!!!!
