lines.speaker: u8342
lines.text: I'm on the run!

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: What's happened?

lines.speaker: u8342
lines.text: The Gestapo found our weapons. They've arrested Janina and Andrzej. They're bound to find out about this place, too - you must get away at once.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Where do you want me to go?  Look at me. No, no, I'm not leaving. Can't I take my chances here?

lines.speaker: u8342
lines.text: That's your decision.  But when they storm the flat, throw yourself out of die window - don't let them get you alive. I have poison on me, they won't get me alive either!

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Halina?

lines.speaker: u8343
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Funny time to say this.

lines.speaker: u8343
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: wish I knew you better.

lines.speaker: u8343
lines.text: Thanks.

lines.speaker: u8344
lines.text: We're recruiting.

lines.speaker: u8345
lines.text: Who's recruiting?

lines.speaker: u8344
lines.text: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...

lines.speaker: u8345
lines.text: Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!

lines.speaker: u8344
lines.text: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.

lines.speaker: u8345
lines.text: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...

lines.speaker: u8344
lines.text: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?

lines.speaker: u8345
lines.text: Yes, please.

lines.speaker: u8344
lines.text: I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Very appropriate.

lines.speaker: u8345
lines.text: Yes, that's why I brought it.

lines.speaker: u8346
lines.text: No one thought they'd hold out so long.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: should never have come out. I should've stayed there, fought with them.

lines.speaker: u8346
lines.text: Wladek, stop that. It's over now. Just be proud it happened. My God, did they put up a fight.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Yes, so did the Germans.

lines.speaker: u8346
lines.text: They're in shock. They didn't expect it. Nobody expected it. Jews fighting back? Who'd have thought?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Yes, but what good did it do?

lines.speaker: u8346
lines.text: What good? Wladek, I'm surprised at you. They died with  dignity, that's what good it did. And you know something else?  Now the Poles will rise. We're ready. We'll fight, too. You'll see.

lines.speaker: u8347
lines.text: I have to say you look terrible. What's the trouble?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: You've heard the rumours they're going to resettle us in the East?

lines.speaker: u8347
lines.text: Rumours, rumours, you take it all too much to heart, Wladek.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: I've been trying to get a certificate of employment for my father. I've managed to get certificates for me and the rest of the family but I need one more for my father. I've been trying all the firms, the shops...

lines.speaker: u8347
lines.text: Why didn't you come to me?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: I didn't know you were in the certificate business.

lines.speaker: u8347
lines.text: I'm not, but Majorek is.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Can you help? I've no money...

lines.speaker: u8347
lines.text: Please, don't insult us.  Can you do something for him?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Jurek? Wladek Szpilman.

lines.speaker: u8348
lines.text: Wladek! How are you?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Fine, we're fine, thank you, and you?

lines.speaker: u8348
lines.text: Fine, we're fine in the circumstances. But I can guess what you've called about. There's nothing we can do; they won't reopen the station--

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Yes, I know, but Jurek, Jurek...

lines.speaker: u8348
lines.text: ...not even music, nothing, no radios for the Poles. But I'm sure you'll find work, Wladek, a pianist like you.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Maybe, maybe not, but, Jurek, don't be offended, I didn't call to discuss my future career.

lines.speaker: u8349
lines.text: If I play like an angel, why don't you listen?

lines.speaker: u8353
lines.text: I was listening, Kitten.

lines.speaker: u8349
lines.text: Liar, you fell asleep. Pig!

lines.speaker: u8350
lines.text: I tried your friends. They're not at that address any more.  But.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: You made contact?

lines.speaker: u8350
lines.text: Be ready to leave in two days' time. Same place as last night.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: I'm sorry, I did my best, I thought the certificates would save us all.

lines.speaker: u8352
lines.text: Stop it, Wladek.

lines.speaker: u8354
lines.text: You don't want to worry about that. My grandfather was jilted by his girl friend when he got jaundice.  In my opinion, jaundice is not very serious. Drink up.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Why didn't you come sooner? It's been over two weeks.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: What about you?

lines.speaker: u8356
lines.text: I've got another one.  Warmer.  What will you do when it's all over?

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: I'll play the piano again. On Polish radio.

lines.speaker: u8356
lines.text: Tell me your name. I'll listen out for you.

lines.speaker: u8355
lines.text: Szpilman.

lines.speaker: u8356
lines.text: Szpilman.  Good name for a pianist.

lines.speaker: u8357
lines.text: Well, that is a strong opinion.

lines.speaker: u8359
lines.text: Yes, it's unholy.

lines.speaker: u8358
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u8359
lines.text: She says, throw it overboard. She doesn't want it. She says it's spoiled

lines.speaker: u8358
lines.text: I have the key here, look, I'll have it mended...

lines.speaker: u8359
lines.text: Mama.

lines.speaker: u8362
lines.text: Take this to Baines. Tell him if he ever tries to see her again I'll take off another and another and another!

lines.speaker: u8363
lines.text: Yeh, go ahead.

lines.speaker: u8384
lines.text: At the finish, it's Single Action by two, Fasanella second, Visitation third.  Line on Single Action... 3 to 2. Hell with it, that's no good.

lines.speaker: u8364
lines.text: Jesus, what a bundle.  Did you know he was that loaded?

lines.speaker: u8386
lines.text: Hell no, I just cut into him.  I woulda settled for pawning one of them shoes.

lines.speaker: u8365
lines.text: Paltrow, Sterling, Furey, and the Big Alabama are in from New Orleans. Fiskin and the Boone Kid from Denver, and Phillips, Barnett and Limehouse Chappie from New York. Those and the guys outside should give ya 30 or so to choose from.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: Good, have 'em down at Stenner's old Pool Hall before 3:00.  We're gonna run through the route tonight.

lines.speaker: u8365
lines.text: Okay, Twist, but you know if this blows up, I can't do ya no good downtown.  Gondorff is Federal.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: Don't worry about it, pal.

lines.speaker: u8366
lines.text: Straighten up, kid.  I wouldn't turn ya out if ya weren't ready.  I got a guy named Henry Gondorff I want you to look up.  There ain't a better insideman alive.  He'll teach ya everything ya gotta know.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: You'll take a cut of what I make, won't ya?

lines.speaker: u8366
lines.text: I'm out, Johnny.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: If that's the way you want it.

lines.speaker: u8366
lines.text: That's the way I want it.

lines.speaker: u8373
lines.text: I just got the count.  We'll put the take on the 4:15.

lines.speaker: u8367
lines.text: We'll be waitin'.

lines.speaker: u8368
lines.text: Buck Duff.  I was in Maxwell's boost in Troy.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: You the Duff that didn't come up with his end when Little Jeff was sent up?

lines.speaker: u8368
lines.text: Wasn't no problem a mine.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: He was a con man, wasn't he?

lines.speaker: u8368
lines.text: He was a tear-off rat.  He got what he deserved.  No sense helpin' pay his bills.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: Shove off, Duff.

lines.speaker: u8369
lines.text: What the hell you gonna do when Snyder rushes his finger right to Lonnegan?  You're committin' suicide, kid.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: Aw Christ, it doesn't make no difference now.  If Snyder knows about it so does everybody else. He never gets anything first...Damn, there's no answer at Luther's.

lines.speaker: u8369
lines.text: Listen to me, Hooker.  What ever you do, don't go back to your place tonight, don't go anyplace you usually go, ya hear me?  Get outa town or somethin', but...

lines.speaker: u8370
lines.text: I know I give him four threes.  We can't let him get away with that.

lines.speaker: u8377
lines.text: What am I supposed to do?  Call him for cheating better than me?

lines.speaker: u8371
lines.text: We bought ya a tap into Moe Anenberg's wire.  He's got eyes at every track in the country.  You'll get race results, odds, scratches, pole positions, everything; and just as fast as Western Union gets 'em.

lines.speaker: u8380
lines.text: Does J.J. know how to use this thing?

lines.speaker: u8371
lines.text: All he's gotta do is read.

lines.speaker: u8372
lines.text: A half mill on an eight to one shot. You're dumber than I thought, Lonnegan.

lines.speaker: u8377
lines.text: You're more gutless than I thought.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: She coulda killed me last night.

lines.speaker: u8374
lines.text: Too many people coulda seen ya go in her room.  She was a professional. Used to work in the Dutch Schultz gang.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: Who are you?

lines.speaker: u8374
lines.text: Gondorff asked me to look after ya.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: How do I know you're tellin' the truth.

lines.speaker: u8374
lines.text: Don't have much choice, do ya?

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: Will you wait until the chump is played?

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: Hell yes.  We don't care about the mark.  He deserves what he gets.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: I mean completely played.  Until he's beat and the score is taken. You come in before we beat him and I'll kill him.  You'll have a tough time explaining that, won't ya.

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: All right, Hooker, but you take it on the lam, and we'll shoot you down on sight.

lines.speaker: u8375
lines.text: Just as long as I get to finish the play.

lines.speaker: u8377
lines.text: All right, Riley.  What the hell happened?

lines.speaker: u8383
lines.text: We missed him.

lines.speaker: u8377
lines.text: You weren't hired to miss him.

lines.speaker: u8383
lines.text: There wasn't any way he coulda known we was in there.  We made a clean pick on the lock and didn't leave no footprints in the hall. Somebody musta wised him up.

lines.speaker: u8377
lines.text: Yeh, and what does Cole say about that?

lines.speaker: u8383
lines.text: I don't know.  He took it hard.

lines.speaker: u8377
lines.text: All right, get outa here.  You're outta work.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: We'll take it.  You manage the building at the end of the alley?

lines.speaker: u8381
lines.text: For fifteen years.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: I'll need a room over there that faces this way.  How much a week?

lines.speaker: u8381
lines.text: Only rents by the month.  Two hundred and fifty for the two of them.

lines.speaker: u8387
lines.text: This is the last time I expect to see you down here.

lines.speaker: u8381
lines.text: Never heard of the place.

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: Do ya know him or don't ya?

lines.speaker: u8385
lines.text: Yeh, but I don't know where he is.

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: Well we do.  He's chummin' around with a Big C named Henry Gondorff. Ring any bells?

lines.speaker: u8385
lines.text: Sure.  Every bunco man in the country knows Gondorff.

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: There's word he's gonna run a con on the North Side here.  We got a year-old Florida warrant on him, but it's a thin beef, and he can beat it in court unless we catch him cold.  All we want you to do is pick up Hooker for us.

lines.speaker: u8385
lines.text: Why don't you pick him up yourself?

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: Cause the stoolies are used to street dicks jumpin' him.  If word gets around that Feds are in on it too, Gondorff'll fold up the whole thing.

lines.speaker: u8385
lines.text: Wouldn't that be too bad.  You'd hafta move outa this nice office ya got.

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: Don't crack wise to me, flatfoot. I spent a lotta time in dumps like this, eatin' Gondorff's dust while the bunco squad gets rich tippin' him off.  But it's not gonna happen this time.  We're not even gonna let the police know we're here.  If you keep your mouth shut and do a job, there'll be a promotion in it for ya.  And you better take it, cause I can make ya work for us without it.

lines.speaker: u8385
lines.text: What the hell good is Hooker to ya?

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: He's gonna set up Gondorff for us.

lines.speaker: u8385
lines.text: He'll never do it.

lines.speaker: u8382
lines.text: I think he will.

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: There's a physiological as well as a psychological angle in my father's relationship with Julia Wolf that the police have overlooked.  And I think it explains everything.  You see, my father was a sexogenarian.

lines.speaker: u8388
lines.text: He was?

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: Yes.  He admitted it.

lines.speaker: u8388
lines.text: Sexogerarian, eh?  Yes.  Yes.  But I can't put that in the paper.

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: Why not?

lines.speaker: u8388
lines.text: You know how they are... sex...

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: Then just say he was sixty years old.

lines.speaker: u8388
lines.text: Is that what it means?

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: Of course.

lines.speaker: u8389
lines.text: Mind if I look around?

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Help yourself.  Oh, Tom, show this gentleman...

lines.speaker: u8390
lines.text: Darling, don't cry.  Please.  I know it's terrible.  But isn't it really better this way?

lines.speaker: u8391
lines.text: Oh, Andy, Andy!

lines.speaker: u8391
lines.text: Poor Dad, does that still bother you?

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Only in bad weather.

lines.speaker: u8391
lines.text: But it isn't bad weather now.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Better get home before it is.

lines.speaker: u8391
lines.text: Goodbye, darling.  Don't you dare forget...  December 30th.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Goodbye, my boy.  Take care of Dorothy.  Show her that there is such a thing as a happy marriage.

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: Shrapnel!

lines.speaker: u8392
lines.text: Must have been in the war.  That might account for the cane and his limp.

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: Yes... yes.

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: I saw him too... he was wearing a green suit with a white tie...

lines.speaker: u8398
lines.text: What are you talking about, Gilbert? You weren't there!

lines.speaker: u8393
lines.text: know.  But I saw him -

lines.speaker: u8402
lines.text: I can't remember offhand, Lieutenant.  Maybe I was over at Charlie's shooting pool. Maybe I was here.  She'd remember.

lines.speaker: u8394
lines.text: How'd you like to be thrown in the can on account of not remembering?

lines.speaker: u8402
lines.text: Just give me a minute....  I'll remember. I'm not stalling, Lieutenant.  You know I always come clean with you.  Gee, it'd serve me right if you had pinched me...  that's the afternoon I was.... wait, I'll show you...!

lines.speaker: u8398
lines.text: and there she was lying dead.  The police said she'd probably been killed about ten minutes before I got there.

lines.speaker: u8395
lines.text: I thought you said you weren't going there.

lines.speaker: u8398
lines.text: Why, you said...

lines.speaker: u8395
lines.text: Never mind.

lines.speaker: u8396
lines.text: That's a fine thing to throw up to me after all I've been to you....

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Hello ....  give me ....  Well ....  ?

lines.speaker: u8396
lines.text: I'll give it back to you ....  all I've got ....twenty-five thousand...

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: You're going to return every cent of it!

lines.speaker: u8396
lines.text: I can't! I haven't got it!

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: What did you do with the rest?

lines.speaker: u8396
lines.text: I never had it.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Then someone was in with you.  Who was it? -- Who was it?  I'll answer that --  Hello ...  hello ...

lines.speaker: u8397
lines.text: I have no right to answer that.

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: What about it, Tanner.  Isn't that the truth?

lines.speaker: u8398
lines.text: Nobody told me.  I did see him!

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: What did he pay you, Mimi, to stick to that story?

lines.speaker: u8398
lines.text: It isn't a story - it's true.  I did see Wynant.  He's not dead.

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: You're lying, Mimi.  But then, you'd do anything for money.  You're getting a good price for saying you saw Wynant and you figure you won't get anything if he's dead.

lines.speaker: u8398
lines.text: I'm lot going to stay here to be insulted -

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: Macaulay, you drew up Wynant's will.  Mimi was cut off, wasn't she, if she re-married?

lines.speaker: u8399
lines.text: What am I?  The fall guy?

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: I hope you won't let this news spoil your dinner.  Nice food, isn't it?

lines.speaker: u8404
lines.text: That's what Mr. Wynant said to me. If she re-married, all the money was to go to the children.

lines.speaker: u8400
lines.text: You shouldn't let that keep you from telling truth, Mimi.  Mrs. Jorgensen -  Were you ever divorced from Chris Jorgensen?

lines.speaker: u8401
lines.text: Was he a good detective?

lines.speaker: u8403
lines.text: I wouldn't know.  That time he caught me was a accident.  I led with my right.

lines.speaker: u8404
lines.text: Well, congratulations.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: I'm going to give her a wedding present.  Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.  I can drop them on my way to...  That's funny....  Where are those bonds?

lines.speaker: u8404
lines.text: Bonds, sir?

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: I know I left them there.

lines.speaker: u8404
lines.text: Maybe Miss Wolf has them.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Maybe she has.

lines.speaker: u8404
lines.text: You're forgetting the check for your suitcase.  It's at the Grand Central.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right --

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Where are you going?

lines.speaker: u8405
lines.text: Home!

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Home?

lines.speaker: u8405
lines.text: I'm fired.

lines.speaker: u8406
lines.text: Who fired you?

lines.speaker: u8405
lines.text: You did.

lines.speaker: u8408
lines.text: Where were you going?

lines.speaker: u8407
lines.text: Baghdad.

lines.speaker: u8408
lines.text: What's in the other direction?

lines.speaker: u8407
lines.text: This road, it leads straight to Kuwait.

lines.speaker: u8408
lines.text: Turn the car around.

lines.speaker: u8407
lines.text: Please, I beg of you.  The American army is there.  I am Iraqi.  They will kill me.

lines.speaker: u8408
lines.text: Nobody's going to hurt you.

lines.speaker: u8409
lines.text: He's not slowing.

lines.speaker: u8408
lines.text: He's going to slow down.

lines.speaker: u8410
lines.text: When my Shi'ite friends saw that they had shot an American they were very apologetic.  Turns out we've been kicking ass in this little war.  They figure we've finally gotten Saddam off their backs.  They brought me to their camp, cleaned me up, fed me... I'm their new best buddy.  America number one, Joe. But there's something the Shi'ites can't figure out:  They can't figure out why my two buddies, two fellow Americans, left me out in the desert.  They can't seem to figure out what those same two guys were doing in an Iraqi outpost.  It's almost as if they were Iraqi spies, or something.  And I've got to tell you they hate anything that's got to do with the Iraqis.  See how I mean?

lines.speaker: u8409
lines.text: We had to take shelter in the checkpoint. Jesus, Wes, I killed the Iraqis in there.

lines.speaker: u8410
lines.text: You actually got around to killing someone.  I'm impressed.  I guess you're only half a bitch.

lines.speaker: u8412
lines.text: 4000 degrees is usually the point of....?

lines.speaker: u8413
lines.text: Vocasity

lines.speaker: u8412
lines.text: No, Tetanty.

lines.speaker: u8414
lines.text: THX!

lines.speaker: u8415
lines.text: We must escape.  We have plans. We can leave.  We must wait until...

lines.speaker: u8420
lines.text: Incredible!

lines.speaker: u8420
lines.text: I've got it!  Astounding!

lines.speaker: u8416
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u8420
lines.text: No one could have imagined anything one-thousandth as fantastic as the sober facts uncovered by patient inquiry.  This world is in a state of static-mobility:  we are at the same time moving and standing still.

lines.speaker: u8417
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u8419
lines.text: Look!

lines.speaker: u8418
lines.text: Just look at all those people.

lines.speaker: u8419
lines.text: I thought of something.....

lines.speaker: u8421
lines.text: You are engaged in an unauthorized procedure.  Check cybernetic manual F-45.  If you do no have an F-45, you are in violation.  This is a double A restricted precinct. Remain where you are.  Authorities will arrive shortly.

lines.speaker: u8419
lines.text: You should know better than that!

lines.speaker: u8422
lines.text: Coffee, Mike?

lines.speaker: u8428
lines.text: No thanks, Bev.

lines.speaker: u8428
lines.text: Dispatch, this is Reilly.

lines.speaker: u8423
lines.text: Go ahead.

lines.speaker: u8428
lines.text: Patch me through to the Bomb Squad.

lines.speaker: u8423
lines.text: Aren't you on suspension?

lines.speaker: u8428
lines.text: Just do it.

lines.speaker: u8423
lines.text: Hang on.

lines.speaker: u8431
lines.text: Jesus...

lines.speaker: u8424
lines.text: Reilly! He's loaded!

lines.speaker: u8430
lines.text: Drop it.

lines.speaker: u8425
lines.text: Take him!

lines.speaker: u8426
lines.text: I'm filing charges against that mother-

lines.speaker: u8432
lines.text: Can it, Pluchinsky. And shove some cotton up your nose.

lines.speaker: u8427
lines.text: Oh shit...

lines.speaker: u8431
lines.text: Fuck factor ten.

lines.speaker: u8432
lines.text: Reilly, what's happening? Reilly! Reilly! Do not engage. We're five minutes-

lines.speaker: u8428
lines.text: We'll keep him pinned in, you guys hurry up!

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: What?  I may lose it again? But I haven't found it yet! I'm sorry. Goodbye!  Yes?

lines.speaker: u8433
lines.text: So you lost a handbag, madame?

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u8433
lines.text: And it had diamonds in the back.

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u8433
lines.text: And diamonds in the front.

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u8433
lines.text: Diamonds all over.

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Well, have you found it?

lines.speaker: u8433
lines.text: No!  But let me tell you--any woman who spends a fortune in times like these for a handbag--phooey, phooey, phooey!

lines.speaker: u8434
lines.text: M'sieu Giron is downstairs.

lines.speaker: u8437
lines.text: Tell M'sieu Giron I can't see him now. Impossible!  And, Jacques. Dismiss the car! Madame is not going.

lines.speaker: u8434
lines.text: Yes, M'sieu Laval!

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: With the compliments of Colet and Company!

lines.speaker: u8435
lines.text: He bows, goes. Door shuts behind him.

lines.speaker: u8436
lines.text: He's really not a bad fellow.

lines.speaker: u8441
lines.text: Just dull.

lines.speaker: u8436
lines.text: Insignificant ... He's a secretary, always <u>was</u> a secretary, always <u>will</u> be.

lines.speaker: u8441
lines.text: Funny--the first time I saw him I thought he was a doctor!

lines.speaker: u8436
lines.text: Doc--!

lines.speaker: u8437
lines.text: Goodbye...

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Goodbye.

lines.speaker: u8437
lines.text: It could have been marvelous ...

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Divine ...

lines.speaker: u8437
lines.text: Wonderful ... But tomorrow morning, if you should wake out of your dreams and hear a knock, and the door opens, and there, instead of a maid with a breakfast tray, stands a policeman with a warrant--then you'll be glad you're alone.

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: But it could have been glorious.

lines.speaker: u8437
lines.text: Lovely.

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Divine ... But that terrible policeman!

lines.speaker: u8437
lines.text: Goodbye ...

lines.speaker: u8444
lines.text: Oh, no, it's the way you lead.

lines.speaker: u8438
lines.text: No, madame, it's the way you <u>follow</u>.

lines.speaker: u8444
lines.text: No, m'sieu!

lines.speaker: u8438
lines.text: Yes, madame!

lines.speaker: u8444
lines.text: Well, the evening is still young. Let's go down to the living room and talk it over.  It's only ten o'clock.

lines.speaker: u8439
lines.text: Madame Colet, I've enjoyed the confidence of your family for more than forty years.  I was a school friend of your husband's ...

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: I know!

lines.speaker: u8439
lines.text: Madame, let me ask you: Who is M'sieu Laval, anyhow? Where does he come from? What is he?

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: He is my secretary! I hope that answers all your questions, M'sieu Giron.

lines.speaker: u8439
lines.text: You know what Paris is saying about the Countess Falconier and her chauffeur?

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Jacques!

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: I think you'd better go.

lines.speaker: u8440
lines.text: Ever had a romance with a crook?

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: I beg your pardon!

lines.speaker: u8440
lines.text: Let me give you a little advice. When you embrace him, be sure to put on your gloves. It would be too bad if your fingerprints were found ...

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Mademoiselle Gautier--or whatever your name is--I thank you for your advice, but I must ask you to go. You've got your money--

lines.speaker: u8440
lines.text: I don't want your money!

lines.speaker: u8441
lines.text: Your bag?

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Yes, my bag!

lines.speaker: u8441
lines.text: Didn't you take it with you?

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Apparently not. Don't you know where it is?

lines.speaker: u8441
lines.text: No--I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: But you saw it here.

lines.speaker: u8441
lines.text: Yes, I saw it--but--

lines.speaker: u8443
lines.text: Well, where is it?

lines.speaker: u8446
lines.text: Good luck to you, Rose.

lines.speaker: u8462
lines.text: And to you, Mr. Andrews.

lines.speaker: u8447
lines.text: Holy shit.

lines.speaker: u8460
lines.text: Don't drop it Rose.

lines.speaker: u8447
lines.text: Rush her.

lines.speaker: u8460
lines.text: It's hers, you schmuck.  Look, Rose, I... I don't know what to say to a woman who tries to jump off the Titanic when it's not sinking, and jumps back onto it when it is... we're not dealing with logic here, I know that... but please... think about this a second.

lines.speaker: u8458
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u8448
lines.text: That's the shape my hand's gonna be when I hold that thing. You understand? I'm not leaving here without it.

lines.speaker: u8458
lines.text: Look, Brock, she's going to do this her way, in her own time. Don't forget, she contacted you. She's out here for her own reasons, God knows what they are.

lines.speaker: u8449
lines.text: I told you you wanted to take this call.

lines.speaker: u8460
lines.text: Alright. You have my attention, Rose. Can you tell me who the woman in the picture is?

lines.speaker: u8450
lines.text: You're a good liar.

lines.speaker: u8455
lines.text: Almost as good as you.

lines.speaker: u8450
lines.text: I always win, Jack. One way or another.  Pity I didn't keep that drawing. It's going to be worth a lot more by morning.

lines.speaker: u8451
lines.text: The boats are all going.

lines.speaker: u8455
lines.text: We gotta get up there or we're gonna be gargling saltwater. Where's Tommy?

lines.speaker: u8452
lines.text: Oy, mate... that was a close shave.

lines.speaker: u8456
lines.text: Smell ice, can you? Bleedin' Christ!

lines.speaker: u8461
lines.text: I don't understand a one of you. What's the matter with you? It's your men back there! We got plenty a' room for more.

lines.speaker: u8453
lines.text: If you don't shut that hole in yer face, there'll be one less in this boat!

lines.speaker: u8454
lines.text: Why have we stopped?

lines.speaker: u8464
lines.text: We've struck ice.

lines.speaker: u8454
lines.text: Well, do you think the ship is seriously damaged?

lines.speaker: u8464
lines.text: Excuse me.

lines.speaker: u8455
lines.text: You must do me this honor... promise me you will survive... that you will never give up... no matter what happens... no matter how hopeless... promise me now, and never let go of that promise.

lines.speaker: u8462
lines.text: I promise.

lines.speaker: u8455
lines.text: Never let go.

lines.speaker: u8462
lines.text: I promise. I will never let go, Jack. I'll never let go.

lines.speaker: u8457
lines.text: I don't think I've ever seen such a flat calm, in 24 years at sea.

lines.speaker: u8464
lines.text: Yes, like a mill pond. Not a breath of wind.

lines.speaker: u8457
lines.text: It's make the bergs harder to see, with no breaking water at the base.

lines.speaker: u8464
lines.text: Mmmmm. Well, I'm off. Maintain speed and heading, Mr. Lightoller.

lines.speaker: u8457
lines.text: Yes sir.

lines.speaker: u8464
lines.text: And wake me, of course, if anything becomes in the slightest degree doubtful.

lines.speaker: u8458
lines.text: I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u8460
lines.text: We were pissin' in the wind the whole time.

lines.speaker: u8462
lines.text: Don't come any closer.

lines.speaker: u8460
lines.text: You had it the entire time?!

lines.speaker: u8463
lines.text: Rose, get in the boat!

lines.speaker: u8462
lines.text: Goodbye, mother.

lines.speaker: u8478
lines.text: Did you find it?

lines.speaker: u8465
lines.text: No!--Did <U>you</U> take that bracelet?

lines.speaker: u8478
lines.text: No-o!

lines.speaker: u8465
lines.text: Where's Lother?

lines.speaker: u8472
lines.text: Where'd you get it?

lines.speaker: u8466
lines.text: Lifted it out of a guy's cabin last night.

lines.speaker: u8472
lines.text: What did you want a gun for?

lines.speaker: u8466
lines.text: Stick-up. Needed dough to get ashore.

lines.speaker: u8472
lines.text: Is that why you killed Lee Lother?

lines.speaker: u8466
lines.text: Guess again, copper.

lines.speaker: u8472
lines.text: Get moving--

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: I won't--I'll ask for one right now.  Sally tells me she's in love with you.

lines.speaker: u8467
lines.text: She did?

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: Yes--but don't ask me why--because I could never tell you. I don't know what most guys want out of life--but <U>that</U> would be enough for me--I wouldn't care about-- easy money--or--showing off my smart brains--I'd just like to live <U>my</U> life so nothing I did would bounce back and ruin <U>hers</U>--Do I make myself clear?

lines.speaker: u8467
lines.text: Very clear. That's one favor I'll be glad to do you.

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: O.K., kid--  I'm only sorry for one thing.

lines.speaker: u8467
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: If you hadn't agreed--I was going to throw you overboard--

lines.speaker: u8471
lines.text: Oh, there you are--

lines.speaker: u8468
lines.text: That's right--you're the one I was looking for.  You'll excuse me.   How about you and I being alone?

lines.speaker: u8471
lines.text: Not now, Toots--Which is the right way to say this? You're dumber than me--or--you're dumber than I?

lines.speaker: u8468
lines.text: Let me see now--Don't tell me--  You're dumber than me and I'm dumber than you. I don't get it.

lines.speaker: u8471
lines.text: Never mind.

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: What happened to you?

lines.speaker: u8473
lines.text: You've got a gun, haven't you, Chad? Will you let me have it?

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: What for?

lines.speaker: u8473
lines.text: Don't ask any questions--just give it to me.

lines.speaker: u8469
lines.text: Easy kid--easy....  Come on--I want to talk to you.

lines.speaker: u8470
lines.text: I know he is. You change those clothes and then come to my cabin. I'll expect you around twelve o'clock.

lines.speaker: u8475
lines.text: Not a chance--I'm through.

lines.speaker: u8472
lines.text: Well, I'll be a son of a sea cook!

lines.speaker: u8474
lines.text: What's the matter?

lines.speaker: u8472
lines.text: Nothin--  --I just remembered the name of a guy that owes me fifty bucks.

lines.speaker: u8475
lines.text: I'm all right.

lines.speaker: u8473
lines.text: You saw him sitting out there in front, didn't you?

lines.speaker: u8475
lines.text: I was in his cabin--

lines.speaker: u8473
lines.text: What!--are you crazy?

lines.speaker: u8475
lines.text: I'll explain later--

lines.speaker: u8473
lines.text: If he comes near you again, I'll break his neck--

lines.speaker: u8476
lines.text: I tell yuh I ain't got no bracelet--

lines.speaker: u8477
lines.text: I saw him take the bracelet out of that shoe.

lines.speaker: u8476
lines.text: Yer crazy!--I ain't got no bracelet.

lines.speaker: u8477
lines.text: Then why did you run away?

lines.speaker: u8476
lines.text: Because you ran after me.

lines.speaker: u8479
lines.text: Oh, my God...

lines.speaker: u8484
lines.text: Does it hurt?  A lot?  Good.

lines.speaker: u8480
lines.text: Easy.  I just wanted to tell you Things're about to start changing Around here.  Lots of so-called Hard cases and tough-nuts swagger Around this town but none of 'em's got a clue about the real play.  None of 'em.

lines.speaker: u8487
lines.text: I don't understand.

lines.speaker: u8480
lines.text: You will after tonight.  Bet on it.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Look, I don't want any trouble With you but that's my horse and I mean to have him back.  One way Or another.

lines.speaker: u8481
lines.text: Come and get him.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Look kid, I know what it's like, I was a kid, too.  Even stole a Horse once.  But you can't--

lines.speaker: u8482
lines.text: Let me, let me, yeah!  Die, you Bastard...

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: No...

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Forget it.

lines.speaker: u8483
lines.text: Excuse me?

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: I said forget it, answer's no, I Don't want the job and that's Final.  I'm going to Tombstone and Nothin' short of dyin's gonn Stop me.  Good day.

lines.speaker: u8483
lines.text: But wait, you don't understand-

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: No Marshal, you don't understand. I'm through with lawing, I'm Through with the whole Proposition.  Forever.  I did my Duty, now I'd like to get on with My life.  That is if you don't Mind.  Jesus.  Good day now.

lines.speaker: u8483
lines.text: I see, off to strike it rich, Huh.  All right, fine, wish you Luck.  Tell you this though, never Was a rich man yet didn't wind up With a guilty conscience.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Already got a guilty conscience, Might as well have the money too.

lines.speaker: u8484
lines.text: I don't believe it.  He's clean!

lines.speaker: u8495
lines.text: What?  But I saw 'em-

lines.speaker: u8484
lines.text: I'm telling you, there isn't a Mark on him.

lines.speaker: u8485
lines.text: All right, I'm on fire!  Black Seven, seven stickin' spades. Let's go!

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: I'm your man...  You win again.  Well played, sir. You are on fire.

lines.speaker: u8485
lines.text: Told you.  I'm red hot, I'm Blazin'!  Now, red seven.  Seven Stinkin' diamonds.  Look out!  Five Thousand!  Let's go!

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Awful lot of money.

lines.speaker: u8485
lines.text: Can't take the heat, get outta The kitchen.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: You're the doctor.  sad news, friend.

lines.speaker: u8485
lines.text: Damn!  All right, wait a minute...

lines.speaker: u8495
lines.text: We're the law, ain't we?  Well the Law don't ride around vermin-

lines.speaker: u8486
lines.text: It rides right at 'em.  Like McMasters said, see it through to The end.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: I have nothing left.  I have Nothing to give you.  I have no Pride, no dignity, no money.  I Don't even know how we'll make a Living.  But I promise I'll love You every second of your life.

lines.speaker: u8487
lines.text: Don't worry, Wyatt.  My family's rich.

lines.speaker: u8488
lines.text: Those Cowboys're tellin' Everybody in town they're gonna Clean you out.  They're down in That lot right now behind the OK Corral.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Don't worry, Doc, it's not your problem. You don't have to mix up in this.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: All right, look.  I can make it Right, I can make this up to you, Mattie.  I can, I swear.

lines.speaker: u8490
lines.text: Will you go to her and tell her Right in front of me she's Nothing to you?  Right out loud so I can hear?  Tell her she's Nothing, tell her she's nobody, Just dirt?  Will you do that?

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: I don't like it.

lines.speaker: u8491
lines.text: Might as well hear him out. Anyways, what choice we got?  But no matter what happens, see It through to the end.  If you don't I'll curse the day I ever laid eyes on you.

lines.speaker: u8492
lines.text: You were right, Wyatt.  They got Me good.  Don't let 'em get you Too.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Will somebody get the damn dog out-

lines.speaker: u8492
lines.text: Remember about the light you're Supposed to see when you're dyin'?

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Easy Morg, don't think about that now.

lines.speaker: u8492
lines.text: Isn't true.  I can't see a damn thing.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Go ahead.  Skin it.  Skin that Smoke wagon and see what happens.

lines.speaker: u8494
lines.text: Listen Mister, I'm getting' tired-

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: We should get moving.

lines.speaker: u8495
lines.text: Doc's just in no kinda shape.

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Virgil?

lines.speaker: u8496
lines.text: Wyatt...

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: Why don't you just leave it alone?

lines.speaker: u8497
lines.text: No, I gotta do something.  I don't Suppose you'd card-

lines.speaker: u8498
lines.text: None of my business, Fred.

lines.speaker: u8510
lines.text: At least we know where the gold is. When are the recovery ships due?

lines.speaker: u8499
lines.text: 36 hours. They've already sailed from the Persian gulf.

lines.speaker: u8510
lines.text: I expect to have that gold recovered in 36 hours. Until then, I'm imposing my own electronic silence: For the sake of the economy, not a word to NATO, the press, the CIA.  ...And so long as Commander Bond here seems to be such an expert on these matters, I want him to go along as an observer. Are we agreed?

lines.speaker: u8508
lines.text: Tsi tien, Mr. Bond.

lines.speaker: u8500
lines.text: Tsi tien, Professor Wu.

lines.speaker: u8516
lines.text: You won't get away with this!

lines.speaker: u8502
lines.text: Good-day, Miss Winch. I advise you to get some steam up - before you run aground.

lines.speaker: u8504
lines.text: The Canadian Prime Minister wants to set a lunch -

lines.speaker: u8506
lines.text: Pencil it in for the next trip -

lines.speaker: u8504
lines.text: The American presidential candidate called to complain about that sex story -

lines.speaker: u8506
lines.text: Send him a $10,000 campaign contribution, and explain I have no control over what my journalists write -

lines.speaker: u8504
lines.text: Your bankers want an answer about the Brazilian TV stations

lines.speaker: u8506
lines.text: No -

lines.speaker: u8504
lines.text: The Queen invited you to dinner -

lines.speaker: u8506
lines.text: Yes -

lines.speaker: u8504
lines.text: And the 9:30 news meeting is waiting.

lines.speaker: u8506
lines.text: Excellent.

lines.speaker: u8505
lines.text: A dead head.  Water logged timber. Floats straight up. You sometimes see them on the east side of the channel - from the logging camps on Sumatra - but they don't usually float this far west.  Muncy! Engines to half!

lines.speaker: u8507
lines.text: Aye-aye sir. Engines to half.

lines.speaker: u8505
lines.text: Chew up a log like that in the propeller, you end up with enough paperwork to go from here to London. Twice.

lines.speaker: u8506
lines.text: Mr. Stamper will escort you to the plane.

lines.speaker: u8512
lines.text: Thank you sir! Thank you!

lines.speaker: u8518
lines.text: Soviet SB-9 nuclear torpedo. Yield, one kiloton.

lines.speaker: u8509
lines.text: Will the cruise set it off?

lines.speaker: u8518
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u8524
lines.text: I don't want to wear out welcome, but you can stay in someone's heart longer than you can stay in their house. Come with us, boy. We are going to have a good time.

lines.speaker: u8521
lines.text: This would be a bad time for me to leave.

lines.speaker: u8524
lines.text: We are going where the action is. Ain't that right, Okra?  Let's play for a couple of bucks unless you want to start off with two bits and work our way up.  What would you give to be rich?

lines.speaker: u8522
lines.text: You know it is against the city ordinance to keep chickens or live stock.

lines.speaker: u8523
lines.text: I always had chickens, ducks and whatnots.

lines.speaker: u8522
lines.text: Not anymore, not in the city.

lines.speaker: u8523
lines.text: We grow most of our own food. The money I get from social security, my pension and my wife's work, keeps us living on the edge. What choice do people like us have.

lines.speaker: u8522
lines.text: Well, you just have to move further out.

lines.speaker: u8523
lines.text: Now how far would further out be?

lines.speaker: u8522
lines.text: I'm not here to argue, sir.

lines.speaker: u8524
lines.text: Boy, I thought you were about to cross the river.

lines.speaker: u8523
lines.text: I tell you, I feel like a ghost.

lines.speaker: u8524
lines.text: Did you have your child at home?

lines.speaker: u8527
lines.text: No. No. No. No. I had my Child at Cedars and Sinai. And that ain't no county hospital. You have to have cash or check before you come in the door.

lines.speaker: u8524
lines.text: Some folks take that natural stuff too far.

lines.speaker: u8527
lines.text: Junior's wife kept her afterbirth' in the refrigerator. That's why I do not eat over there now.

lines.speaker: u8524
lines.text: Country people got so many strange ways,

lines.speaker: u8533
lines.text: You know Okra asked me to marry him the other evening.

lines.speaker: u8525
lines.text: Rush your mouth, girl. No, he didn't. He cannot be that big of a damn fool.

lines.speaker: u8533
lines.text: I asked Harry about it. He didn't own up to it. He said he didn't know what got into Okra.

lines.speaker: u8525
lines.text: He's just raffish. Harry put him up to it. Before evening sun sets, I would have his belongings back on Route 55, that old fox.

lines.speaker: u8533
lines.text: I can't accuse him just dry long 80.

lines.speaker: u8525
lines.text: Everybody who have been associated with Harry end up with pennies over their eyes.

lines.speaker: u8533
lines.text: What must I do?

lines.speaker: u8525
lines.text: If it was left up to me, I would poison him.

lines.speaker: u8532
lines.text: You shouldn't talk about the boy's father in front of him. This is family business and we have to pull together.

lines.speaker: u8526
lines.text: Whether the boy hears it or not, the man is still a jackass. Everyone should have some mother wit.

lines.speaker: u8529
lines.text: What are you doing?

lines.speaker: u8530
lines.text: Counting the gray hairs in your head.

lines.speaker: u8529
lines.text: Counting the what? What does that have to do with the price of butter?

lines.speaker: u8530
lines.text: I was just trying to make conversation.

lines.speaker: u8529
lines.text: Where is Skip?

lines.speaker: u8530
lines.text: He is in his pigeon cage.

lines.speaker: u8529
lines.text: I'm sorry he got those birds.

lines.speaker: u8530
lines.text: You know the man next door is near death.

lines.speaker: u8531
lines.text: I didn't mean for you to pay me for that.

lines.speaker: u8533
lines.text: I know you didn't but you have been so thoughtful.

lines.speaker: u8531
lines.text: But when your sunflowers come up, I'll pay you for them.

lines.speaker: u8533
lines.text: I planted a row just for you and you don't owe me anything.

lines.speaker: u8534
lines.text: Which one can I open first?

lines.speaker: u8540
lines.text: Let's let Molly open one.

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: Say, isn't that mistletoe?

lines.speaker: u8535
lines.text: Mm-hmmmmm.

lines.speaker: u8536
lines.text: Me?  No, no, no, no...  Are you?

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: Now Buzz, what could Andy possibly get that is worse than you?!

lines.speaker: u8537
lines.text: Oh, that is disgusting.

lines.speaker: u8539
lines.text: Murderer!

lines.speaker: u8538
lines.text: MOM!!  MOM!!

lines.speaker: u8543
lines.text: She's lying!  Whatever she says it's not true!

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: No wait!  You don't understand! Buzz is out there!  We've gotta help him!!

lines.speaker: u8539
lines.text: Toss 'im overboard!

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: No, no, no, wait!

lines.speaker: u8544
lines.text: I got it, Woody!

lines.speaker: u8541
lines.text: He got it, Woody!

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: Buzz.  Buzz Lightyear.  You are not worried, are you?

lines.speaker: u8542
lines.text: I can't quite make out --

lines.speaker: u8543
lines.text: W-w-w-we?

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: That's right.  Your toys.

lines.speaker: u8544
lines.text: I can't hold on much longer!

lines.speaker: u8545
lines.text: Slink!  Hang on!

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: I already lost everything once.

lines.speaker: u8546
lines.text: So did I.

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: But then I had a brother and a sister left.

lines.speaker: u8546
lines.text: So had I.

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: Everything is gone, now.

lines.speaker: u8546
lines.text: Nothing is left but us.

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: They're going to fly everywhere. Mean things. They should have taken us.

lines.speaker: u8547
lines.text: We're too young.

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: I'm not too young. Juliet was my age.

lines.speaker: u8547
lines.text: Juliet who?

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: In the play. She was married, by my age. And Mummy. Mummy wasn't much older than me when she got married. Well, not that much older.

lines.speaker: u8549
lines.text: Oh no you can't. Get on with the painting.

lines.speaker: u8548
lines.text: It's all right, Finn.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: I... I don't really know.

lines.speaker: u8550
lines.text: Is she in any kind of therapy... professional help?

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: No, of course not.  She's one of the top students at her school.

lines.speaker: u8550
lines.text: Well, I hope it stays that way.

lines.speaker: u8564
lines.text: If Manolo hadn't gone and told them what he did then Salazar and Madrigal would never have been brought to justice.  He did a great thing for Tijuana.  He did a great thing for Mexico.

lines.speaker: u8551
lines.text: I want to believe you.  I really do.

lines.speaker: u8564
lines.text: You will believe me, because it's true.

lines.speaker: u8555
lines.text: Arnie, do think there's a difference between a reason and an excuse, because I don't think there is.

lines.speaker: u8552
lines.text: Carl --

lines.speaker: u8555
lines.text: Goodbye Arnie.

lines.speaker: u8556
lines.text: He didn't hang around us.  He's like one of those hippie kids.  I'm not part of that group.  It was a party in all these rooms.  His girlfriend who I barely know was completely hysterical... He's blue, he's puking... We didn't want to get in trouble, but what were we supposed to do?  I mean, what would you have done if you had been us?

lines.speaker: u8553
lines.text: How well do you know this boy, Seth, who was driving?  You know the police have charged him with a DUI and possession of marijuana.

lines.speaker: u8556
lines.text: He's a friend.  He's also like the only one who was dealing with the situation.  He'd definitely had a few beers, but it's not like he wanted to drive.  We didn't know what else to do.  It wasn't my pot.

lines.speaker: u8554
lines.text: We'll get through this, I promise. I'll make it up to you --

lines.speaker: u8563
lines.text: How?  Supportive letters from prison while I'm being kicked out of our home?  Do you have any idea what is happening out here?  Our credit cards are maxed. The people at the bank, you should see their faces when I walk in there. I have a letter from the government telling me that anything I sell from our house will be taken against an income tax lien.  Our friends are behaving like the crowd at a public hanging.  Nobody will help us.  Nobody will take us in.  Nobody wants anything to do with us.  So tell me, Carl, how you're gonna make it up to me.  Tell me again how we'll get through this, and maybe while you're at it you can put your hand up against the glass so we can have a tender moment of connection.

lines.speaker: u8554
lines.text: Helena --

lines.speaker: u8563
lines.text: Tell me what to do, Carl.  I need guidance, not a fucking platitude.  I'm not bringing a child into the kind of life I grew up with.  I won't do it.  I want our life back.

lines.speaker: u8573
lines.text: Did Courtney Love play Nancy in Syd and Nancy?

lines.speaker: u8556
lines.text: I think so.  If she didn't she should have.  I've only got maybe an hour.  Then volleyball practice is over and I have to be home.

lines.speaker: u8573
lines.text: Why?  Nobody's there.

lines.speaker: u8557
lines.text: Remember when we sat on that mob guy, that chef, for like six months?

lines.speaker: u8561
lines.text: Oh, man, I've never eaten so good in my life.  Why don't you develop a useful skill?

lines.speaker: u8557
lines.text: Yeah, like turning into a beautiful woman.

lines.speaker: u8558
lines.text: What do you think it is?

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Depends who it's from.

lines.speaker: u8558
lines.text: Your friends at Warren, Putnam and Hudson.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: You can learn a lot about somebody from this stuff.  Three categories: you like me, you hate me, you want something from me.  Definitely third category.

lines.speaker: u8558
lines.text: What would a law firm want from the new drug Czar?

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Depends on the state.

lines.speaker: u8558
lines.text: Arizona.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Medicinal marijuana initiative.  Or am I being cynical?

lines.speaker: u8563
lines.text: Women's room, stall two.  Should we stop for ice-cream?

lines.speaker: u8559
lines.text: Yeah!

lines.speaker: u8560
lines.text: They're going to walk right past me.

lines.speaker: u8563
lines.text: What are you?  A mouse?  Get out of the car and do it.  This is your chance.

lines.speaker: u8571
lines.text: Can't you for a second imagine none of this had happened?  That my drugs had gone through.  What would have been the harm?  A few people get high who are getting high anyway. Your partner is still alive.  We avoid having breakfast together. Don't you see this means nothing? That your whole life is pointless?

lines.speaker: u8561
lines.text: You're breaking my heart.

lines.speaker: u8571
lines.text: The worst thing about you, Monty, is you realize the futility of what you're doing and you do it anyway. I wish you could see how transparent you are.  This food tastes like shit.

lines.speaker: u8561
lines.text: So go shower already.

lines.speaker: u8571
lines.text: You only got to me because you were tipped off by the Juarez Cartel, who's trying to break into Tijuana. You're helping them.  You work for a drug dealer too, Monty.

lines.speaker: u8572
lines.text: I want to know who is responsible for this treatment.

lines.speaker: u8562
lines.text: Yes, sir!

lines.speaker: u8572
lines.text: We aren't barbarians.

lines.speaker: u8562
lines.text: Yes, sir!

lines.speaker: u8572
lines.text: Bring this man a change of good clothes.  Has he eaten?

lines.speaker: u8562
lines.text: I don't know, sir.

lines.speaker: u8572
lines.text: You will dine with me from now on.

lines.speaker: u8563
lines.text: You will help me with my other problem.

lines.speaker: u8567
lines.text: Deliver that safely to Tigrillo in San Diego.  And we have a deal.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Let me ask you a hypothetical question: if Salazar worked for Madrigal and the Juaraz cartel, and he went out of power, would it mean the Juarez Cartel is losing influence?

lines.speaker: u8564
lines.text: It could mean that, yes.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: That would probably mean the Tijuana Cartel is gaining power?

lines.speaker: u8564
lines.text: It's possible.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Is it possible to have a Drug Czar in Mexico who isn't connected in some war to one of the cartels?

lines.speaker: u8568
lines.text: My work keeps me young.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Which part, getting terrorists loose on bail or freeing convicted murderers on technicalities?

lines.speaker: u8568
lines.text: The worst serial killer in history - who?  Gacy - right?  Killed forty two people.  Our government killed fifty thousand in Vietnam and lied about it every day.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Michael, you represent drug dealers, not civil libertarians.

lines.speaker: u8568
lines.text: We kidnapped Noriega out of Panama. Is that covered in your Constitution? Because it isn't in mine.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Noriega is a criminal.

lines.speaker: u8568
lines.text: Noriega was head of a sovereign nation who made the mistake of doing business with the U.S.  Government.  So, no, I don't have a problem waking up every day and fighting our government, fighting people like you, trying to keep this system a little bit honest.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Last I read your clients were chopping people up with chainsaws and delivering illegal narcotics into this country.

lines.speaker: u8568
lines.text: I hope when you were on the bench, Judge Wakefield, you didn't handle the presumption of innocence in the same fashion.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: If I ever return to the bench, Counselor Adler, I hope I have the pleasure of hearing your arguments.

lines.speaker: u8569
lines.text: The busiest land border crossing in the world.  Over forty-one thousand vehicles per day, twenty-two thousand pedestrians on foot.  I think we do a pretty good job but we know a lot of drugs are still getting through.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Any idea how much?

lines.speaker: u8569
lines.text: I've read official estimates but I wouldn't bet my house on them.  I've heard the entire cocaine supply for the United States can fit into four tractor-trailers.  At least a half-dozen of those cars right out there are carrying a load of dope, with drivers employed by people who don't give a damn if they're caught or not.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: What do you look for?

lines.speaker: u8569
lines.text: We ask questions and measure the answers.  When something doesn't ring true, a fact that doesn't make sense, a slight hesitation, then it's off to secondary for a closer look.  Before NAFTA we had about 1.9 million trucks a year.  Now it's almost double.  Pretty soon there'll be Mexican truck companies that will have as much freedom in crossing the border as American truck companies.

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Any way we can do it better?

lines.speaker: u8569
lines.text: Sure.  More money in intelligence on their side of the border.  So we have a better idea who we're looking for.  More dogs.  More people. Supposed to be getting some giant x- ray machines to run the trucks through.  Outside of martial law that's about the best you're gonna do.  But, I should tell you, there are two things that really have us on edge right now.  In the last six months seizures have tripled, even though we're pulling over the same number of cars.  What does that tell you?

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: That triple the amount of stuff is going through.

lines.speaker: u8569
lines.text: Right.  But, that's not the biggest problem.  One of our Intel officers picked up information from DEA that traffickers have come up with a process, a chemical process, to turn coke into something else.  It doesn't smell like coke.  It doesn't look like coke.  And what's worse, it doesn't react to field test.  It could be anything.  Maybe it's already happening.  I mean, how would we know?

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: Who do we interface with on their side?

lines.speaker: u8577
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: u8570
lines.text: I mean, who runs interdiction on the Mexico side?

lines.speaker: u8577
lines.text: I don't know.  I don't think there's any one person.  See the problem is the Juarez cartel owns everything and everybody, all the property on the Mexican side, sometimes all the property on both sides.  Warehouses, transportation, even tunnels.  It's very organized.

lines.speaker: u8573
lines.text: What do we do?  Okay.  Fucked-up Bowman's turning blue.  Doctor.  We need a doctor.

lines.speaker: u8578
lines.text: Your dad's a doctor.  Call him --

lines.speaker: u8573
lines.text: He's a research doctor.  You're dad's a doctor, too --

lines.speaker: u8578
lines.text: What kind of research?

lines.speaker: u8573
lines.text: Mapping the fucking pig genome. We'll call your dad, he's a neurosurgeon --

lines.speaker: u8578
lines.text: It's three a.m.  I'm not supposed to be here.  I snuck out --

lines.speaker: u8587
lines.text: Cool down, Franco. The guy's sorry.

lines.speaker: u8579

lines.speaker: u8580
lines.text: Well, he's young and he's healthy.

lines.text: It's an interesting theory.

lines.speaker: u8581
lines.text: Actually it's a nightmare. I've been desperate for a shag, but watching him suffer was just too much fun. You should try it with Tommy.

lines.speaker: u8583
lines.text: What, and deny myself the only pleasure I get from him? Did I tell you about my birthday?

lines.speaker: u8583
lines.text: He forgot. Useless motherfucker.

lines.speaker: u8582
lines.text: Exactly. I'm not wanting a cat, she says. Get to fuck, right. So there's Tommy stuck with this kitten. You can imagine what happened. The thing was neglected, pissing and shitting all over the place. Tommy was lying around fucked out of his eyeballs on smack or downers. He didn't know you could get toxoplasmosis from cat shit.

lines.speaker: u8583

lines.text: Returned it? Where? To the video shop, Tommy? To the fucking video store? So every punter in Edinburgh is jerking off to our video? God, Tommy, I feel sick.

lines.text: Thank you, Mr. Murphy. We'll let you know.

lines.speaker: u8589

lines.speaker: u8586
lines.text: There's no need.

lines.speaker: u8589
lines.text: It's no problem.

lines.speaker: u8586
lines.text: No problem for me either.  Honestly, it's no problem.

lines.speaker: u8589
lines.text: I'd really rather take care of it myself.

lines.speaker: u8586
lines.text: Spud, they're my sheets.

lines.speaker: u8587
lines.text: Great.

lines.speaker: u8590
lines.text: And see when I get out of here. I've got plans. Going to get myself straightened out and head off to Thailand, where women really know how to treat a guy. See, out there you can live like a king if you've got white skin and a few crisp tenners in your pocket. No fucking problem.

lines.speaker: u8587
lines.text: Sure.

lines.speaker: u8590
lines.text: The strategy is this: get clean, get mobile, get into dealing, and this time next year I'll be watching the rising sun with a posse of oriental buttocks parked on my coupon.

lines.speaker: u8587
lines.text: Sounds great, Swanney.

lines.speaker: u8590
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u8590
lines.text: Sure will, pal, sure will.

lines.text: It's the great outdoors.

lines.speaker: u8588
lines.text: It's really nice, Tommy. Can we go home now?

lines.speaker: u8591
lines.text: It's fresh air.

lines.speaker: u8588
lines.text: Look, Tommy, we know you're getting a hard time off Lizzy, but there's no need to take it out on us.

lines.speaker: u8591
lines.text: Doesn't it make you proud to be Scottish?

lines.speaker: u8592
lines.text: What do you see as your main strengths?

lines.speaker: u8589
lines.text: I love people. All people. Even people that no one else loves, I think they're OK, you know. Like Beggars.

lines.speaker: u8592
lines.text: Homeless people?

lines.speaker: u8589
lines.text: No, not homeless people. Beggars, Francis Begbie -- one of my mates. I wouldn't say my best mate, I mean, sometimes the boy goes over the score, like one time when we -- me and him -- were having a laugh and all of a sudden he's fucking gubbed me in the face, right --

lines.speaker: u8592
lines.text: Mr. Murphy, {leaving your friend aside,} do you see yourself as having any weaknesses?

lines.speaker: u8589
lines.text: No. Well, yes. I have to admit it: I'm a perfectionist. For me, it's the best or nothing at all. If things go badly, I can't be bothered, but I have a good feeling about this interview. Seems to me like it's gone pretty well. We've touched on a lot of subjects, a lot of things to think about, for all of us.

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: I couldn't help but notice you pain.

lines.speaker: u8593
lines.text: My pain?

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: It runs deep. Share it with me.

lines.speaker: u8594
lines.text: What's Emergency Landing Plan B?

lines.speaker: u8601
lines.text: I don't have a clue.

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: What's going on?

lines.speaker: u8595
lines.text: I instruct you to surrender. You are under attack by Federation forces.

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: Do you realize what you've done? It wasn't bloodshed I wanted.

lines.speaker: u8596
lines.text: The Klingon, the Romulan, the Federation consuls. Now I know Enterprise is not exactly up to specs...

lines.speaker: u8598
lines.text: With all due respect, the Enterprise is a disaster. There must be other ships in the quadrant.

lines.speaker: u8596
lines.text: Other ships, yes. But no experienced commanders. Captain, I need Jim Kirk.

lines.speaker: u8598
lines.text: Oh, please.

lines.speaker: u8596
lines.text: Your orders are to proceed to Nimbus III, assess the situation and avoid a confrontation if possible. Above all, however, get those hostages back safely.

lines.speaker: u8598
lines.text: Have the Klingons responded?

lines.speaker: u8596
lines.text: No, but you can bet they will.

lines.speaker: u8598
lines.text: Understood. Kirk out.

lines.speaker: u8597
lines.text: Where did you get this power?

lines.speaker: u8600
lines.text: The power was within you.

lines.speaker: u8597
lines.text: I feel as if a weight has been lifted from my heart. How can I repay you for this miracle?

lines.speaker: u8600
lines.text: Join my quest.

lines.speaker: u8597
lines.text: What is it you seek?

lines.speaker: u8600
lines.text: What you seek. What all men have sought since time began - ultimate knowledge. But to find it we'll need a starship.

lines.speaker: u8597
lines.text: A starship? There are no starships on Nimbus III.

lines.speaker: u8600
lines.text: Perhaps I have a way to bring one here.

lines.speaker: u8597
lines.text: But how?

lines.speaker: u8600
lines.text: Have faith, my friend. There are more of us than you know.

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: What have I done?

lines.speaker: u8598
lines.text: Kirk to Enterprise. Listen carefully...

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: Spock...

lines.speaker: u8605
lines.text: No, no, no. Scotty - Scotty... There's so much I want to tell you.

lines.speaker: u8601
lines.text: Maybe you could wait until I'm a wee bit stronger I don't think I could take it in my present condition.  Or yours.

lines.speaker: u8602
lines.text: Sybok.

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: This is my doing. This is my arrogance... my vanity...

lines.speaker: u8602
lines.text: Sybok, we must find a way...

lines.speaker: u8604
lines.text: No. You must save yourselves. Forgive me, brother. Forgive me.

lines.speaker: u8607
lines.text: Well, I don't know...I just tried to run this program I've been working on, and I was denied access all of a sudden. I thought maybe I'd been laid off and nobody told me.

lines.speaker: u8609
lines.text: oh, you have Group 7 access, don't you?

lines.speaker: u8607
lines.text: Yeah...?

lines.speaker: u8609
lines.text: We have to close that down, just briefly. Security reasons.  Someone with that access has been tampering.

lines.speaker: u8607
lines.text: I hope you don't think it's me. I don't even balance my checkbook on downtime.  I've got a Honeywell at home for that.

lines.speaker: u8609
lines.text: No, no, I'm sure, but -- you understand. It should only be a couple of days. What's the thing you're working on?

lines.speaker: u8607
lines.text: It's called Tron. It's a security program itself, actually. Monitors all the contacts between our system and other systems... If it finds anything going on that's not scheduled, it shuts it down. I sent you a memo on it.

lines.speaker: u8609
lines.text: Mmm. Part of the Master Control Program?

lines.speaker: u8607
lines.text: No, it'll run independently. It can watchdog the MCP as well.

lines.speaker: u8609
lines.text: Ah. Sounds good. Well, we should have you running again in a couple of days, I hope.

lines.speaker: u8607
lines.text: Ok

lines.speaker: u8608
lines.text: Yes!

lines.text: I hope you've enjoyed being a command program, Sark. I wonder how you'll like working in a pocket calculator... maybe one of those watches that plays "Happy Birthday" to its User once a year.

lines.speaker: u8616
lines.text: Now, sir... We did take care of that User you sent us --

lines.text: We'll get them, sir... These things take time.

lines.speaker: u8614
lines.text: I don't have time, Sark. And neither do you. End of line.

lines.text: I have to find out what Alan wants... that comes first.

lines.speaker: u8634
lines.text: Yeah, well, just stay outta trouble. Remeber, you got a wife to think about. Quit fuckin' around.  I love you son.

lines.speaker: u8634
lines.text: It's about that pimp that was shot a couple of days ago, Drexl Spivey.

lines.speaker: u8653
lines.text: What about him?

lines.speaker: u8634
lines.text: Well, Ted, to tell you the truth, I found out through the grapevine that it might be, and I only said might be, the Drexl Spivey that was responsible for that restaurant break-in on Riverdale.

lines.speaker: u8653
lines.text: Are you still working security for Foster & Langley?

lines.speaker: u8634
lines.text: Yeah, and the restaurant's on my route. And you know, I stuck my nose in for the company to try to put a stop to some of these break-ins. Now, while I have no proof, the name Drexl Spivey kept comin' up Who's case is it?

lines.speaker: u8653
lines.text: McTeague.

lines.speaker: u8634
lines.text: I don't know him. Is he a nice guy? You think he'll help me out?

lines.speaker: u8653
lines.text: I don't see why not. When you gonna come round and see my new place?

lines.speaker: u8634
lines.text: You and Robin moved?

lines.speaker: u8653
lines.text: Shit, are you behind. Me and Robin got a divorce six months ago. Got myself a new place - mirrors all over the bedroom, ceiling fans above the bed. Guy'd have to look as ugly as King Kong not to get laid in this place. I'm serious, a guy'd have to look like a gorilla.

lines.speaker: u8637
lines.text: Where'd he come from?

lines.speaker: u8651
lines.text: I don't know. He just appeared as magic.

lines.speaker: u8637
lines.text: Well, don't just sit there, shoot him.

lines.speaker: u8650
lines.text: Don't blow it, Elliot. He's bluffin'. He just told you so himself.

lines.speaker: u8638
lines.text: You're an actor, so act, motherfucker.

lines.speaker: u8639
lines.text: You tell Jayne Kennedy to fuck it?

lines.speaker: u8642
lines.text: If it came down to who eats who, damn skippy.

lines.speaker: u8639
lines.text: With that terrible mug of yours if Jayne Kennedy told you to eat her pussy, kiss her ass, lick her feet, chow on her shit, and suck her dog's dick, nigger, you'd aim to please.

lines.speaker: u8640
lines.text: You gotta hold this for me.

lines.speaker: u8643
lines.text: You must be high. Uh-huh. No way.

lines.speaker: u8640
lines.text: Just put it in your purse.

lines.speaker: u8643
lines.text: I'm not gonna put that shit in my purse.

lines.speaker: u8640
lines.text: They won't search you. I promise. You haven't done anything.

lines.speaker: u8643
lines.text: No way, Jos.

lines.speaker: u8640
lines.text: Please, they'll be here any minute. Just put it in your bra.

lines.speaker: u8643

lines.speaker: u8640
lines.text: Put it in your pants.

lines.speaker: u8643
lines.text: No.

lines.text: You're the one who wanted to drive fast.

lines.text: Yes.

lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u8642
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u8646
lines.text: Do you know where we can find him?

lines.speaker: u8642
lines.text: He's at the Beverly Wilshire.

lines.text: Where's that?

lines.speaker: u8642
lines.text: Well, you go down Beechwood...

lines.text: We're very close!  Because of you!

lines.speaker: u8660
lines.text: This is it, James...what you've been working for.

lines.speaker: u8655
lines.text: Wow, a guy in a Chevy is chasing her and some other guy I can't see.

lines.speaker: u8661
lines.text: Hey, no problem, it's probably just another kidnapping featuring Jeffrey's shrink, pardon me, make that ex-shrink.  This is your leader, a certifiable lunatic who told his former psychiatrist all his plans for God knows what whacko irresponsible schemes, and now who knows what she's painted out there on our wall?

lines.speaker: u8657
lines.text: San Francisco, New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Rome, Kinshasa, Karachi, Bangkok, then Peking.

lines.speaker: u8656
lines.text: Meaning...???

lines.speaker: u8657
lines.text: That the virus was taken from Philadelphia to San Francisco, then to New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Rome, Kinshasa, Karachi, Bangkok, then Peking.

lines.speaker: u8656
lines.text: And your only goal is...???

lines.speaker: u8657
lines.text: To find out where the virus is so a qualified scientist can travel back into the past and study the original virus.

lines.speaker: u8656
lines.text: So that...???

lines.speaker: u8657
lines.text: Uh, so that a vaccine can be developed that will, uh, allow mankind to reclaim the surface of the earth.

lines.speaker: u8665
lines.text: But you know what's real now?

lines.speaker: u8657
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u8658
lines.text: He kidnapped you, Kathryn.  You saw him murder someone.  You knew there was a real possibility he would kill you, too.  You were under tremendous emotional stress.

lines.speaker: u8666
lines.text: For God sakes, Owen, listen to me -- he knew about the boy in Fresno and he says three billion people are going to die!

lines.speaker: u8658
lines.text: Kathryn, you know he can't possibly know that.  You're a rational person. You're a trained psychiatrist.  You know the difference between what's real and what's not.

lines.speaker: u8666
lines.text: And what we believe is what's accepted as "truth" now, isn't it, Owen?  Psychiatry -- it's the latest religion.  And we're the priests -- we decide what's right and what's wrong --we decide who's crazy and who isn't. ... I'm in trouble, Owen.  I'm losing my faith.

lines.speaker: u8663
lines.text: What...virus?

lines.speaker: u8659
lines.text: She knew about it, Jeffrey.  She knew you were going to try this.

lines.speaker: u8663
lines.text: What virus are we talking about, Dad?

lines.speaker: u8659
lines.text: You're insane, Jeffrey.

lines.speaker: u8663
lines.text: You "develop" viruses and you're calling me insane?  Typical.  What does this virus attack?  Don't tell me, you sick fuck, it doesn't matter.  Have I ever "developed" a virus?  Do I put helpless animals in cages and measure their reactions to electrical stimuli? Do I inject radioactive substances into living creatures and examine their bowel movements?  Wow!  And I'm crazy!

lines.speaker: u8659
lines.text: Please tell me, Jeffrey, what exactly are you going to do?  I don't have to tell you I'm afraid.

lines.speaker: u8663
lines.text: THIS IS A FUCKING EXPERIMENT!  YOU'RE OUR HELPLESS LITTLE TEST ANIMAL, DADDY. GOT THAT?  NOW -- WHAT FUCKING VIRUS HAVE YOU COME UP WITH, YOU DEMENTED FUCKING MANIAC?

lines.speaker: u8663
lines.text: WHO CARES WHAT PSYCHIATRISTS WRITE ON WALLS?  You think I told her about the Army of the 12 Monkeys?  Impossible!  Know why, you pathetically ineffectual and pusillanimous "pretend-friend-to- animals"?!  I'll tell you why:  because when I had anything to do with her six years ago, there was no such thing -- I hadn't even thought of it yet!

lines.speaker: u8661
lines.text: Then how come she knows what's going on?

lines.speaker: u8666
lines.text: That would explain the bruises, I guess.  The struggle.

lines.speaker: u8662
lines.text: You want to go in?  Examine him?

lines.speaker: u8666
lines.text: Yes, please.  You said he gave a name...

lines.speaker: u8662
lines.text: James Cole.  That's everything we got.  None of the James Coles on the computer match him. No license, no prints, no warrants.  Nothing. You want me to go in with you?

lines.speaker: u8666
lines.text: No, thank you.

lines.speaker: u8662
lines.text: I'll be right here...just in case.

lines.speaker: u8666
lines.text: Nine thirty

lines.speaker: u8667
lines.text: Might be tight.

lines.text: Tight?  My watch says 7:30.

lines.speaker: u8667
lines.text: On your normal mornin', okay, plenty a time, but today, gotta take inta account your Army-of-the-Twelve-Monkeys factor.

lines.text: What?  What did you say?

lines.speaker: u8667
lines.text: Twelve Monkeys, honey.  Guess you folks didn't turn on your radio this morning.

lines.text: Any parting words of wisdom?

lines.speaker: u8668
lines.text: Things ain't always the way they seem. You got to ask yourself; is it worth it?

lines.speaker: u8669
lines.text: And what are you?  A rocket scientist?

lines.speaker: u8672
lines.text: I got more brains than you've got teeth.

lines.speaker: u8669
lines.text: Put your money where your chicken- lipped mouth is.  I'll bet this mornings pay I'm right.

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: Please, you don't understand.  I have to get out of here.  They're going to come looking for me. They're going to kill me.  If I can't get this ticket then I'm going to have to do things to get out of here.  I don't want to hurt anybody, I just want to leave.

lines.speaker: u8670
lines.text: I'll give you the money!  Okay? I'll give you two-fifty.  Just . . . just, please.

lines.speaker: u8671
lines.text: Two-hundred dollars in hundred- dollar bills.  And this morning you was broke.

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: What's it to you?

lines.speaker: u8671
lines.text: I don't want no dirty money.  I run an honest business.

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: Honest like Al Capone on tax day. Where are my keys?

lines.text: Ned!  Now look at what you done! Are you all right?

lines.speaker: u8679
lines.text: I think I burned my gun hand!

lines.speaker: u8673
lines.text: It'd serve you right.  Jose, run get a mop and clean this mess up.

lines.text: John, if you don't throw me the keys, then I'll just walk away. Walk away and leave you here.

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: Walk to where?  We're fifty miles to the nearest town.  It's going to be over one-hundred degrees today.  How far do you think you're going to get?

lines.speaker: u8674
lines.text: Someone will find me.

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: Yeah, they'll find you.  Dried up and twice dead.

lines.speaker: u8674
lines.text: You idiot!  You'll kill us both!

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: At least I'll have company when I die.  Ain't that right, Jake?

lines.speaker: u8674
lines.text: For Christ's sake, John!  Throw me the keys!

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: What do you say, Jake?  Should we trust her?  No?  I didn't think so.

lines.speaker: u8674
lines.text: Fuck you!  Do you hear me, John!? Fuck you!  John . . . John!?

lines.speaker: u8675
lines.text: You'd tell me anything to save your pathetic life.

lines.text: You know what kind of woman Grace is.  You know how badly she wants to get the fuck out of Sierra.  What makes you think when you were planning on killing her she wasn't doing the same for you?  What's she to you, Jake; a woman who would have you dead?  Let me kill her.  All I want is two-hundred dollars to get out of here with.

lines.speaker: u8675
lines.text: Two-hundred dollars.

lines.speaker: u8677
lines.text: Two-hundred dollars . . . that's how I put a price on murder.

lines.text: Well, Ned, you'll want to tell me an' Mister Beauchamp here all about them two villainous friends of yours, I guess.  Bring him in, boys, for I will be glad to know the names and the whereabouts of those other two murdering sonsofbitches.

lines.text: You're a beautiful woman an'... if I was to want a free one, I guess I'd want you more than them others. It ain't... See... I can't have no free one on account of my wife...

lines.text: I admire that, you being true to your wife. I've seen a lot of... of men... who weren't.

lines.text: Uh... yeah. Yeah. She's uh... watchin' over the little ones.

lines.text: Hell, yeah. A bunch of us Bar T boys went out lookin' on account of them killin' one of our own. We come across this fucker on a roan goin' South an'...

lines.text: Huh? Oh.  Another one, huh? Shit, I guess I'm clean out of receptacles.

lines.speaker: u8719
lines.text: Uh... hang the... uh... carpenter. I...

lines.text: He said how you was really Three Fingered Jack out of Missouri... an' Bill said "Same Three Fingered Jack that dynamited the Rock Island and Pacific in '69 killin' women and children an' all?" An' Ned says you done a lot worse than that, said you was more cold blooded than William Bonney or Clay Alisson or the James Brothers an' how if he hurt Ned again you was gonna come an' kill him like you killed a U.S. Marshall in '73.

lines.text: Didn't scare Little Bill though, did it?

lines.text: N-no, sir?

lines.speaker: u8714

lines.speaker: u8714

lines.speaker: u8718
lines.text: K-k-kill somebody?
